name: Laimdota Straujuma
text: president-in-office of the Council. - Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Mr President of the Commission, i would like to begin by congratulating Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Dear Vice Presidents, Dear Commissioners, I am honoured to be here in Strasbourg today and to present the priorities of the Latvian Presidency to the Council of the European Union. Today is 25 years since Latvia regained its independence by getting rid of the Soviet totalitarian regime. Ten years have passed since Latvia joined the European Union and a year since membership of the euro zone. To take up the presidency in the Council of the European Union is not only a great honour, but also a great responsibility. How much this responsibility is, we felt particularly clearly on 7 January, which shook us all to the very foundations. I would therefore like to begin by expressing my solidarity and deepest condolences to France and to the French people. The attack in France is another attack on freedom of expression and European values. On Sunday I took part in a march in Paris. People of all nationalities, religions and cultures took to the streets in France and in the vast world to affirm aloud: we stand for values in a democratic world, for free self-expression of man, for the coexistence of peaceful cultures and religions. That is why I am using this Forum for representation of the peoples of Europe to call on each of us and every citizen to have even greater respect for another culture and for a new level of trust between peoples. At this time of tension, when terrorism would like to impose ever more escalation, growing clashes between religions, pushing us into violence, we need to be even more human. We must continue to be interested in other cultures so that our minds cannot be blurred by demagogy or a crooked interpretation of the facts. The European Union must be prepared to defend itself, its citizens and its values. All of us, all the Institutions of the European Union and all The Member States must join forces to ensure an adequate response from the European Union to the challenge that has been thrown at the european model of living together and, consequently, to all of us. From 2 to 4 May, a large forum dedicated to World Press Freedom Day will be held in Riga, where a wide exchange of views on the issues that are currently in place will be possible. We must have all the mechanisms at the disposal of the European Union in place for the fight against terrorism. Particular attention should be paid to the forthcoming European internal security strategy. For our range of instruments to be complete, it is important for all of us to ensure an effective exchange of information between the services involved. It is highly appreciated that the discussion on passenger name record (PNR) has been renewed. It is both site and time correct. We are talking here about a limited amount of data that would allow better tracking of certain movements of individuals. I am aware that this is an unequivocal issue. I would therefore like to assure you that, despite progress in the discussions on the creation of a passenger name record, the Latvian Presidency will continue to promote the Data Protection Pack as one of the key elements in the context of the digital priority. I am convinced that the European Parliament will be a close cooperation partner for the Council and the Commission, because only together will we be able to deliver a strong European Union response. I trust that Europe will be able to show unity and overcome these threats. I believe that we will not fall into the trap and allow terrorism to destroy our faith in each other, let us not allow people of different origins or religions to be put against each other in European society. Together, we will be able to safeguard European values. The future of Europe depends on this. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Latvia is holding the Presidency in a difficult and challenging time. The start of the Latvian Presidency coincides with the successful completion of the institutional transition into the European Union. We appreciate the work done by the Italian Presidency and the European Parliament and will continue to work to improve cooperation between all the institutions of the European Union. The impact of the financial crisis is still being felt in the European Union. The Member States and the Institutions of the European Union have worked hard to restore confidence in the financial markets. Member States are still continuing structural reforms. Europe is slowly but gradually returning to economic growth. This year, economic growth is forecasting in all Member States of the European Union. The European Union remains the world's largest economy with strong high-tech positions. The overall deficit level of the euro area countries continues to decline. However, this is also a good time to create a system that is resilient to potential challenges in the future. The euro area is expanding with new Member States. I would like to congratulate our neighbour Lithuania on joining the euro area by becoming its 19th member. The citizens of the European Union enjoy a level of freedom and prosperity that is denied to citizens in many other countries of the world. I am convinced that through targeted action, a belief in European values and a willingness to work together, the European Union is able to face up to the challenges, overcome the challenges and move forward. In these turbulent times for the European continent, it is important to remember that the European Union has brought peace and confidence to its people. All too often, we take it for granted. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. The citizens of the European Union are interested in concrete results that improve their daily lives. We can only achieve this by working together : the Council, the European Parliament and the European Commission. A great deal of work was done over the past year to formulate its priorities for the new institutional cycle for the European Institutions. We want to work on their implementation, while paying attention to the new challenges. The Latvian Presidency has outlined three clear lines of priorities: a competitive European Union, a digital European Union, an involved European Union at global level. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Firstly, we want to strengthen the competitiveness of the European Union and promote economic growth. Structural reforms, fiscal responsibility and investment are the 'three whales' on which the European Union's growth must be built in the coming years. Growth that provides new jobs instead of imposing new debts on future generations. We welcome the Investment Plan proposed by the President of the European Commission. We are ready to work actively for the European Fund for Strategic Investments to start operations in June. Yesterday, the Commission's proposal came out. We look forward to good cooperation with the Member States and the European Parliament to ensure a smooth legislative process. Creating an attractive environment for investment is our common responsibility. For a long time, there has been a need for an energy union in Europe. We need an energy policy based on solidarity, trust and security, better integrated energy infrastructure and more efficient governance. The creation of an Energy Union will be one of the priority issues during the Latvian Presidency. We will also continue to work on the completion of the single market, ensure coordination of the European semester processes within the Council. During the Latvian Presidency, we will review the Europe 2020 strategy, promote work on industrial competitiveness, work on strengthening Economic and Monetary Union. Let us pay particular attention to better regulation. Secondly, we want to make Europe more digitised. We want to make full use of Europe's digital potential and work on the creation of an effective digital single market. Online consumers should have equal access to goods and services at the best price, whether they live in Brussels or Bratislava, Riga or Rome. The security and reliability of the digital environment should also be promoted. This will help create jobs and boost growth, and transform Europe into the world's leading knowledge-based economy. We intend to work on a Digital Single Market strategy and we are expecting a concrete Commission proposal shortly. The Digital Programme Assembly in Riga will be a great opportunity to meet policymakers and business. The main elements of the Digital Single Market are data protection and balanced reforms in the telecommunications market. We will also focus on cybersecurity and consumer rights. Thirdly, we want to see the European Union more involved and accountable at international level. We will support the High Representative and the European External Action Service by strengthening the unity of the European Union and promoting regional stability and peace. Europe's neighbours will be a priority for our Presidency. We will support the work on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy. It is only natural that our main focus is on the East, but we will also work equally seriously on issues that are important to our neighbours in the South. The challenges of migration will be on our agenda. We will not be able to avoid negotiations on unprecedented events in our eastern neighbourhood. Russia's aggression against Ukraine is a threat to the foundations of European peace and the rule of law. It is completely excluded that the European Union will recognise the strongest rights that violate the territorial integrity of states. The strength of the European Union lies in the unity of action. In this context, I would like to thank the Member States and the Institutions of the European Union for their ability to remain united when decisions had to be taken on the European Union's response to events in Ukraine and Russian aggression. For many in the world, this is a surprise. The Latvian Presidency will actively work to keep this unity of the European Union unchanged. The Eastern Partnership summit will be held in Riga in May this year. The Riga Summit will make it possible to assess progress since the Eastern Partnership Summit in Vilnius. This must serve as a clear signal that the European Union supports the countries of the Eastern Partnership. We also need to look more broadly at the Central Asia region, where the presence and involvement of the European Union does not reach its full potential. We will be actively working to review the European Union's Central Asia Strategy. Strengthening the European Union's international role includes and global aspects. We will help to facilitate trade agreements with the United States, Canada and Japan. The ambitious transatlantic trade and investment partnership would not only bring more than €100 billion in benefits and stimulate the European Union's economy, but would also bring geopolitical benefits. 2015 is the European Year of Development. We will focus on the European Union's contribution to the UN Summit on Sustainable Development and Poverty Reduction Targets for 2015. The Latvian Presidency will work on shaping the common security and defence policy in line with global challenges.  Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. The aim of the Latvian Presidency is to build a competitive, digital and more internationally stronger Europe. Our aim is to safeguard the area of European values, freedom, security, justice and mutual tolerance that characterises Europe in the world. It is important for us to work in close cooperation with you. This is the main reason for my visit today: to strengthen our cooperation and to build a coherent agenda for the Council and the European Parliament. The Latvian Presidency is pragmatic and determined. The sparkstone that we have chosen as the logo of our Presidency was once an essential element of innovation. This brought about a major change for households across Europe. For me, the sparkstone means prosperity, stability and energy. I would like the Latvian Presidency to be associated with these values. We want to strengthen the European Union's progress towards development, strengthen faith in the European idea and inspire us to growth wise and far-sighted, to people close to Europe. Thank you!

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, we have reached a crucial moment in the recent history of the European Union. This is Latvia, which was not foreseeable, taking over the Presidency of the European Union. And already, as we quickly forget, we find this quite normal, obvious and natural, when it is a small miracle. Thirty years ago, no one in this Chamber or anywhere else could have imagined that Latvia would be responsible for presiding over the destiny of the European Union. As I said yesterday, this is a great moment in European history, since the Latvian Presidency perfectly symbolizes the reconciliation between European history and geography, thus putting an end to this disastrous post-war decree which called for Europe to be divided into two parts for the rest of history. The Latvians escaped the diktat of history and dictated the way forward to history. Therefore, the whole of Europe, the whole continent is indebted to Latvia, which is a great people and a great nation.  A week ago, we started the Latvian journey to Riga as the Commission travelled there to discuss with the Latvian Prime Minister and Ministers the work programme of the Latvian Presidency. This programme of the Latvian Presidency has all the support of the Commission, if only for the reason that the Latvian Presidency programme and the European Commission's work programme are strictly identical. This proves how good will and noble inspiration can be combined in Europe to ensure that Europe can move forward.  To enable the Latvian Presidency to work in good conditions, the Commission yesterday agreed on legislation and regulations in relation to the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. It is a piece of legislation that is characterized by the fact that it has to be part of special circumstances, because we have no time to waste. I would therefore call, as I did two weeks ago, our Latvian friends, as well as your Parliament, to speed up the work to enable the Strategic Fund to find its place in the arsenal of combating the crisis so that it can be operational by 1 July 2015.  In the aftermath, the Commission yesterday decided on a communication on the flexibility of and in the Stability and Growth Pact. I have just read the first articles in the international press and it gives me the opportunity to say that the Stability and Growth Pact remains the Stability and Growth Pact. We have not changed the rules. We have not made the Stability and Growth Pact a flexibility pact. It is not a flexibility pact, it is a stability and growth pact based on what I have described as a virtuous triangle of structural reforms, fiscal consolidation, which remains vital, and the revival of investment in Europe, so that we can have a growth situation in Europe that allows us to stimulate employment. Like the Latvian Presidency, the Commission attaches great importance to digital Europe. During the current semester, we will make the first proposals in this direction and I am planning to discuss digital Europe at the college meeting on 25 February.  We do not remain inactive with regard to the Energy Union. Rather, it is the Energy Union that will enrich the agenda of 25 February, with digital Europe scheduled for June. We were asked by the European Council in October to deepen economic and monetary union. Under the leadership of the President of the Commission, there will be a report by the four Presidents, the Eurogroup, the European Central Bank, the Commission and the European Council. We will present the first ideas in February, to deepen them until June. Parliament is obviously involved in the work of the four Presidents, since the Presidency of Parliament, which represents one of the main institutions of the Union, has its full role to play. Here, Madam President, Mr President, are a few remarks inspired by the Latvian Prime Minister's brief presentation. I am convinced that the Latvian Presidency and the Commission will be able to work closely together if not in complete complicity. Good luck!

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Prime Minister Straujuma, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work on the A warm welcome to the European Parliament and thank you for joining us, for presenting the latvian Presidency's programme. Latvia is a role model, a young country that has had to fight hard for its freedom and democracy, a country that knows the value of freedom of expression and freedom of the press and that this is not self-evident, and a country whose history reflects the core of the European Union, namely the pursuit of freedom, peace and shared prosperity. Especially at a time – as you pointed out – when we are being asked new questions in Paris, this reminder of the fundamental character of your country and of the fundamental character of our European Union is important. That is why there is hope that Latvia will take over the presidency. A second idea that suits the country and our current situation in Europe, namely that your country knows difficult times. In 2009, Latvia's economy collapsed with a 14 percent decline in economic power, and an economic tsunami swept across your country. Today, Latvia is back on a growth path. Gross domestic product has increased in recent years, in the next few years it looks even better in the forecast for your country's growth data, and unemployment is falling in Latvia. In this context, in difficult economic times, Latvia is also a glimmer of hope for the European Union as to how to get it right, how to build a real future. I would like to thank you for the objectivity with which you, Prime Minister Straujuma, have also presented the programme. The objectivity of working on the topics is the way to convince people that we are going to work. We in Europe, too, are now, after the phase of constitution – after we have put the Commission into office, the elections have been completed – now, in 2015, we are on our way back to the normal working process. The Latvian Presidency has an important role to play in this. You have mentioned security in creating a Europe of security. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we support you on the way to tackling the PNR issue. I would also ask you once again to take a close look at what we have already decided and also to promote, at the European Council meetings as a whole, that the existing measures should also be implemented and implemented. You mentioned the investment package. We are linking this to the reform agenda that is needed in the Member States. You referred to the Digital Agenda, a mega-theme of our time. I would like to thank you for saying clearly that you want to focus on the data protection regulation, that the data protection regulation, which is already on the table, which we are already legising, where we in the European Parliament have found a large majority for the data protection regulation, for the joint decision, is also moving in the Council and that we will soon really get fruitful discussions. , that is a matter of great concern to us. I would also like to combine the ambition of us Europeans that the European voice is heard in the global debate on how we deal with big data, how we deal with digitalisation. The European voice must be that not only freedom applies on the Internet, but that we want to set rules on the net, to protect our citizens on the net. You have mentioned competition, the internal market. I would like to take this up again, including the clear statement on TTIP, support for TTIP, in so far as we also have a discussion in Europe about social Europe, about the social cushioning of our citizens. For my group, it is important that we have the social debate. However, I would also like to say that the most important thing to create social security in Europe is to guarantee our citizens jobs. It is social to create work. This is the most important principle for creating social justice. That is why all the measures that strengthen the economy are also social policy. The last thought I want to raise is the Neighbourhood Policy, Russia – you mentioned it. Thank you for the clarity. Europe must stand together and continue on a common path together. The start is good, the Presidency has started well, the priorities are set correctly. Putting the citizens first, as you do, is the right accent these days. Europe now has Latvian leadership and is therefore in good hands. All the best!

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, as Mr Juncker said a few moments ago, you are taking over the Presidency at a crucial stage for the European Union, a phase of hope but also of fears and decisions that we will all take together will depend on the fate of our societies, we will choose whether to overcome fear or whether to win hope.  If, faced with the threat of terrorism, we choose to perch, then fear will prevail, if we choose to associate security and freedom, if we do not agree to distort our open society, based on integration, then we will make hope prevail. Europe is the land of human rights and fundamental freedoms if Europe abandons these values and betrays itself, so we want to respond to the demand for the protection of our citizens by remaining true to ourselves.  We need a new approach to security, europe's security is not just played out within our national borders – as you said very well. When war, for the first time since the 1970s, faces the borders of Europe, one cannot think of remaining with one's hands in one's hands! Your Presidency must push to overcome the resistance of the Member States and build a regional strategy that will wipe out terrorist forces in Syria, Iraq and Libya. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is also a breeding ground for radicalism. We ask you to support the efforts made by Vice-President Federica Mogherini to make Europe really play a mediating role.  We must also make better use of the data provided by the Schengen system in order to be able to identify foreign fighters. Let me be quite clear on this point: Schengen is not touched! There is no need to modify it, but only to apply it well! If you touch Schengen, you touch on the principle of freedom of movement within the European Union, which is a pillar of Europe.  On PNR, here too with the utmost clarity: we do not have negative ideological prevention, but our polar stars, which should be everyone's, remain valid, the protection of fundamental freedoms and human rights. If we do not want to give in to fear, we must also return to talk – as Mr Weber did – about social justice, five years of austerity have depressed our societies: yesterday was a good day for Europe, for the first time with the decisions of the European Union – I thank Mr Juncker, because he was once again speaking! – the conditions have been created for a change in economic policy. Mr Prodi said that the Stability Pact was stupid, with your decisions yesterday making the pact a little smarter, we are on the right track.

name: Roberts Zīle
text: ECR grupas vārdā. –  Priekšsēdētāja kungs, premjerministres kundze, Komisijas priekšsēdētāja kungs! Man tiešām ir liels saviļņojums runāt latviešu valodā tik svarīgā jautājumā šodien. Pirms 25 gadiem, pirms vienas paaudzes, daudzi no mums nevarētu iedomāties, ka šāds notikums varētu būt šodien šeit, Strasbūrā. Tādēļ es novēlu Latvijas prezidentūrai sekmes — esmu pārliecināts, ka tā būs — gan tajos jautājumos, kas jau ir ilgi plānoti, gan saistībā ar reakciju uz tādiem notikumiem kā notikumi Parīzē. Es domāju, ka prezidentūra būs ļoti veiksmīga. Dažām lietām, kas man liekas ļoti akcentējamas, es gribētu šodien arī pieskarties daudz dziļāk. Mr President, in this House we all care about growth and prosperity and the development of our economies. When we ask ourselves what could be the strongest instrument in, say, making transparent progress on TTIP – which is important not only from a geopolitical point of view and for the development of western values, but also for economic growth on both sides of the Atlantic, and of course in Europe – it will, I think, create more sustainable growth in Europe, if it is a successful process, than the Strategic Investment Plan – perhaps necessary but a bit ad hoc – which was approved yesterday by the Commission. I would like to point out that the Presidency has to work on this plan for six months to turn it into a reality. I do not want to go into too many details, but there are still a lot of questions about this investment plan. One of my main worries is that profitability-driven investment can create more disparities in the European Union than there are now and may perhaps cause a younger generation of Europeans to move to the most developed Member States in the future. We have to be very careful about such outcomes. The second issue, of course, is Russia and Ukraine. There have been some comments from responsible persons saying that we cannot impose more and more sanctions on Russia and that the only way to stop the madness is via negotiations. But when we talk about how we can help in dealing with negotiations in a situation of madness, the only way is to tell the mad ones what they want to hear and make promises that work on it, not in our favour. We can ask European citizens if this is what they expect from our behaviour as politicians in Europe or we can ask the Ukrainians if they are happy with European partners who just want to implement the Minsk Agreement and then quickly remove all the sanctions. But what about the rule of law, and behaviour which is not compatible with the 21st century; what about compliance with international treaties, and what about Crimea in that case? I believe there is an alternative option. An ʽengaged Europeʼ, which is also a priority of the Latvian Presidency, means that we will show solidarity with the Ukrainian nation and government. A stable, democratic and free Ukraine is a very good example for other Eastern Partnership countries to show that European values are real values. Eastern Partnership countries can choose this way – the western way – rather than its opposite, the Eurasian Union way, and it is I think very important that we understand this. Let us be under no illusions: the weaker the EU’s actions, the stronger the Eurasian Union will become. Coming back to values, the millions who marched in Paris in solidarity against terror last weekend, on Sunday, showed that European values are values for citizens and that we have to hold on to them very proudly and very strongly in the case of the situation in Ukraine too and in other Eastern Partnership member countries, and in our relationship with Russia.

name: Sophia in‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, President Juncker, ALDE welcomes the priorities of the Latvian Presidency: competitiveness, the digital economy, a stronger presence of Europe in global affairs. ALDE fully shares all of these objectives. But how serious are priorities if there is such a huge backlog in the Council, so many legislative proposals still pending and so many blocked for many, many years? The Council is a bit like the Bermuda triangle. We send in a legislative proposal and it disappears, never to be heard of any more. We do not want any more grand designs for the future; we need action. Do not talk about an investment plan but put your money where your mouth is, quite literally. Do not talk about the digital economy: just adopt the telecoms package and the data protection package. No lip service to security and law enforcement: just adopt the Europol Regulation. Do not talk about democracy: just adopt the Transparency Regulation. Let us stop talking and deliver. The Council is a legislator, so legislate. If no agreement can be found on a proposal then the Council should simply decide to reject it and not keep it pending for ever. ALDE welcomes the special summit on the security package next month, and we consider that sharing information must be the first priority. It must be stepped up drastically. It should never happen again that attacks take place and we realise afterwards that the killers were known to the intelligence services. That is unacceptable. We build a huge haystack of personal data but information is not being shared and information that is not being shared is useless information. ALDE wants real security for citizens, not fake security and politics of symbolism. On the particular issue of PNR, the facts are that PNR data are being collected and shared in Europe today. They are available to law enforcement and security authorities, so I can reassure those who are worried about that. But there is no proper legislative framework with all the required legal safeguards. A vote was taken in Parliament in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the proposals of the Commission and they were deemed inadequate, so now the ball is firmly in the court of the Commission and the Council. They should present a revised proposal and adopt the Data Protection Directive as quickly as possible and not just ask Parliament to vote again and again on identical proposals until they get the outcome that is to their liking. We should not make the same mistake as in 2005 when we adopted the Data Retention Directive under great pressure and it was subsequently scrapped by the courts last year, as we know. We cannot afford to be sloppy again, in particular when it is about our security. What irritates me, President Juncker, is that in the meantime, in the absence of an agreement on PNR, the Commission is simply pushing ahead, funding the creation of an EU PNR with EU money and creating a fait accompli. I wonder if this is the Commission’s idea of better law-making. I would call it legislation by stealth. Finally, I would call on the Latvian Presidency to make the adoption of the horizontal Anti-Discrimination Directive an absolute priority, Madam Prime Minister. Finally adopting a European law on equal treatment after so many years would really be the best possible answer to the homophobic and derogatory remarks of the President of Latvia on LGBTI people and the EuroPride event in June this year in Riga. Madam Prime Minister, I hope the Latvian Presidency will achieve that and put the European motto into practice. We are united in diversity – and I see you agree.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam Prime Minister, I listened carefully to your speech on the objectives of the Latvian Presidency. I have not heard you mention the word 'cohesion' once. I didn't hear you say a word about the risk of deflation. You have not once spoken of the alarming increase in unemployment and poverty within the European Union and in the euro area.  A day after the Commission's decision on some flexibility in the implementation of the Stability Pact – which, Mr Pittella, does not make it 'smart', just might make it less 'stupid', as Mr Pronti said – I did not hear you, Prime Minister, take a position. Do you think that investment should be excluded from the calculation of the Member States' deficit in order to boost growth? The theory that with harsh one-sided austerity, with cuts in wages, pensions and the social state will come investment is being tested for six years and has been disproved. Investment in the euro area is 15% less than it was in 2009. How will this development come about? On the Juncker package, you said, in general, that we support it. I have repeatedly said, on behalf of our group, that we consider it insufficient and we also consider the 1-to-15 leverage on which it is based to be unrealistic. But you, here, represent the Council. You have to tell us how you support it. Will the Council ask the Member States to pay extra resources, fresh money? How much and by what criteria? Where will the Investments of the Juncker Package go? Will they go to the countries facing the biggest problems of recession, unemployment, de-investment? Or "business as usual"?  I come to foreign policy for a moment. I listened with concern to a statement by the Latvian Foreign Minister that you would "break" the stereotypes in relations with Russia. What's that supposed to mean? The European Union needs to provide solutions where there are tensions along the path of politics and diplomacy. We have an interest in defuse this tension. To build peaceful relations based on the values and rules of democracy.  With regard to TTIP, apart from the fact that you strongly support it, what do you respond to objections to opacity and to those who disagree and say that the way they are preparing it will abolish pillars of European law for the benefit of multinationals? There is a need for a shift in the Economic Policy of the European Union to create sustainable growth in place of unilateral austerity, which is why we have heard nothing from the Latvian Presidency.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Prime Minister, welcome to this House. I have listened to you carefully and I have heard a language that I hear here every day. In the five years that I have been a Member of this Parliament, I have heard about budgetary responsibility, structural reforms and investment. With regard to investment, it is clear that this Commission has taken a serious look at it. But the rest - fiscal responsibility and structural reforms - is a common language and the objective of all these measures is the same: growth.  I would like to look at this growth for two minutes. If we look at 1985-2008, the 25 years before the financial crisis, what do we see? We have had an average annual growth rate of 2% in Europe and the OECD tells us that, over the past quarter of a century, we have seen a concomitant increase in inequality in Europe. But since the crisis, there is at least one European country, the one that has provided us with the current President of the European Council, which has a somewhat exceptional growth performance. This is Poland, with an average annual growth of 2.7% since the financial crisis. However, in Poland, the employment rate has not increased - 2.7% annual growth and no increase in the employment rate.  So let's see what happens in the United States, which grew by 5% last year. What do we see? 5% growth and a decrease in unemployment. However, the US Bureau of Statistics tells us: "Unemployment is falling not because the unemployed find work, but because they leave the statistics because they have given up looking for work". In other words, the employment rate is not increasing in the United States. And what about wages? Will they increase? Not at all, wages are falling!  With the recipes you are advocating, what do we see? That the problem is not solved and that inequality and poverty are increasing - 25% poverty and social exclusion in Europe. So I wonder when you say we have to go back to growth. I am glad to hear that this is the case in Europe, but - I have been wearing glasses for some time and they may not be good - I am not watching it, or it is a growth behind the comma. You say that market confidence has returned. I'd like to ask you a question. Are we elected to satisfy the markets? Wouldn't it be interesting to ask the question of the stupid trust of our fellow citizens? Do our citizens have confidence in the action we are taking to finally fulfil Europe's promise of shared prosperity, that is, prosperity for all, and not just 1%, 5% or 20% of the population? That's the question I'm asking you! I invite you to revisit your agenda and your language, and perhaps the structural reforms we need are not about lowering public services, wages and social protection. Perhaps it is structural reforms that put the economy back at the service of the common good.

name: Rolandas Paksas
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam Prime Minister, honourable colleagues, Madam Prime Minister, is my question: is it not time for today's fundamental review of the fundamental principles of the Presidency? Because, in most cases, the interests of the small Presidency are completely different from those of the major States of the Union, and we pretend that this is not the case. Because that small state is still a player in the big area of interest, which also formulates the agenda according to foreign fashions. And most importantly, the agendas of the Presidency of the European Union as a whole have one feature: they are extremely bureaucratic, they are extremely formal, and their decisions are never implemented.  Colleagues, we should recognise that the European Security Strategy, based solely on stability at the eastern borders of the European Union, is obsolete, and today we need a new strategy for living and surviving in the world of escalating conflicts. A strategy that is much more effective, inclusive and conciliating. Consensus, not a counter-evoked strategy. A strategy of peace and trust. Colleagues, jobs and growth need to be created. However, first of all, we should focus on creating a single energy market in the European Union as soon as possible, because it is a guarantee not only in the case of natural or economic, but also in the case of military or terrorist cataclysms. With regard to neighbourhood policy, I believe that we should focus not only on individual countries, but we should focus on neighbourly relations. It is the consensus with the state, its politician, every person, regardless of language, nationality or place of residence, the color of his skin or the religion he professes, that is the guarantee of our continued peaceful coexistence. These are the things that the Latvian Presidency should focus on today and all the countries of the Community should focus on this. Let us do this here today, all together and then individually in our own countries. And let god agree and agree.

name: Iveta Grigule (NI). -
text: Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating The list of specific priority areas of the Latvian Presidency is the expansion of relations with Central Asia. Today, central Asian countries need more than ever our help and support to help them balance the growing pressure from Russia. It is precisely strengthening cooperation links with these countries that will contribute to economic growth and job creation, not only within the European Union, but also in the region concerned. Our help is urgent to be able to meet the challenges of terrorism, border security and drug smuggling in the regions. Transport projects, energy and proactive European Union action in the search for new common lines of action are also crucial. Already today, this region has earned the attention of the world's major powers. China successfully develops trade links, becoming the most strategically important outlet for natural resources. Following the departure of NATO forces from Central Asia, Russia has increased its military presence in the region. America's interest in the region in the name of its stability and security is very high.  Therefore, in order to promote and expand cooperation with this region so important for Europe, we must be able to offer an individual cooperation mechanism to each of our partners. We must be able to seize every opportunity to strengthen and increase the reputation and reputation of the European Union in the region. We need to strengthen mutual trust. But we know that trust is based on respect for traditions and customs, on respect for culture and religion. And these challenges for the Latvian Presidency are powerful! Thanks for the attention!

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE). -
text: Mr President, President Juncker, Prime Minister Straujuma, colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-Neyra, for his excellent work. I think we have to ask ourselves, "Why are we here at all?" And the answer is, of course, that we serve our people. And what do our citizens say what is needed? Of course, these are jobs, and that is also security. The question is, how can we achieve these objectives? Much has been said by Mrs Straujuma in the context of the objectives of the Latvian Presidency. I would like to emphasise one other point.  On competitiveness. Of course, Europe must increase its competitiveness. But how to do it? The simple key is to break down the existing barriers. We know that in the digital market, including in the markets for goods and services, we have a shake-up, we have all sorts of restrictions. By breaking down these barriers, we will increase Europe's competitiveness. Secondly, we need to encourage investment. That is what we must do, of course. How to do it? In my opinion, the Juncker Commission's plan to free up private capital so that it flows back into our economy is the best proposal I have ever heard in a long time. The latvian Presidency's task is to bring this plan from the level of the idea to reality in order to free up private capital for investment. This will create jobs for us. And what about security? In safety, we have two aspects that are very important. One thing the Paris events remind us very well is internal security, security against terrorism. And here it is important for Member States to stick together, exchange information and work together to address these potential threats to our citizens. But there is also external security, where perhaps the biggest factor at the moment is energy security. This European Energy Union must be created. By joining our forces together, we will be much more secure, and I think that the Latvian Presidency is very well positioned to hold the European Union together so that we can achieve these objectives that we all need. Thanks for the attention!

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D). -
text: Mr President, first of all it is a great pleasure to have a woman prime minister at the head of the EU Presidency. Welcome, Madam Prime Minister. Let me tell you that your programme seems promising. But I would like to underline the main expectations and the main objectives of the S&D Group. We think we need a turning point in Europe. We need a big push for investments, and that is why we need to commit these funds for strategic investment as soon as possible – at the latest by June, as is being proposed by President Juncker. You can count on us for this, but you know very well that you need more national contributions to make this fund really work. Let me underline that I believe that investments should be driven by a powerful vision for a competitive economy in Europe, focusing on citizens’ well-being. We need new products and new services, and this also applies to the Digital Agenda. The Digital Agenda should become a leverage for well-being in Europe by providing new solutions. Last but not least, do not forget about jobs and quality jobs. In the end, Europe must remain a continent of high-quality jobs, for our young people but also for those who are in long-term unemployment.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! Madam Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for her Mr Weber was right to point out that you made a very objective speech. That was in stark contrast to the introductory speech by your predecessor, Mr Renzi.  Mr Renzi started here as a tiger, and I have to tell you that yesterday he said goodbye here, he ended up as a rabbit. Mr Renzi has imposed flexibility on Mr Juncker instead of reforms in Italy. Mr Renzi has ensured that a Stability and Growth Pact has now become a pact of flexibility and shrinkage. Prime Minister, the eurozone wanted to go towards Maastricht. Through Mr Draghi of the ECB and Mr Renzi from Italy, she is now heading for Rome. Help to get into the wheel and bring this euro zone back towards Maastricht.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I wish the Prime Minister the very best and offer her my congratulations on Latviaʼs programme. I still remember the event at the Baltic Prime Ministers’ meeting more than a year ago to which I was invited, and I felt some freshness in that room there with the three Baltic States. I must say that it is quite a success story for all three Baltic States, and I very much hope, Prime Minister, that you will bring some of that freshness into the European Union too. You have said that European citizens want concrete results; you have also spoken of the fact that we need further digitalisation of Europe. While yes, citizens want concrete results and your programme will be credible, what you have said today will be credible if we see the situation on roaming and net neutrality unblocked in the Council. This, I think, is an early message that you need to send in the very near future. We have also spoken about better regulation, and that is the second and final point I would like to raise, and on both I would appreciate a comment. Better regulation: the Commission has made progress in the last couple of years, and we feel that Vice-President Timmermans has a certain ambition. Parliament has made progress, but there is one institution in the European Union which has a zero record – and that is the Council. The Council is amending legislation and negotiating, and none of that is assessed. There is no impact assessment. I mean that if we are to have better regulation, there is no impact assessment in the Council; and if we are to have better regulation, the Council has to match the Commission and Parliament, otherwise it will not be better regulation, it will be no good regulation at all.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Latvia is presented to us as an example of success, but it is an example that we do not want from anyone, much less the people of this country. Following the 2008 crisis, the government, following the guidelines of the European Union, imposed a draconian austerity plan on the people. He fired a third of public servants, closed schools, hospitals, lowered wages by 30%, brutally increased taxes. As a result of these measures the country lost, in two years, a quarter of its wealth, lost 5% of its population with a forced emigration of more than 40 000 young people, in 2010 alone!  I wonder if this is the austerity model that has done so badly to its people that it wants to impose on the other Member States? In his priorities he talks about the competitiveness of the economy and foreign policy. The consequences of the European Union and NATO's intervention in Ukraine are well known. We are now paying a huge bill by importing what Ukraine was exporting to Russia, paying gas bills and lending behind loans. I'd like to know what assessment you make of this adventure.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, you concluded your speech, Madam Prime Minister, with a commitment to bring Europe closer to the people. Yesterday, in this House, everyone paid tribute to the European citizens who stood up against barbarism, against fear and for solidarity.  I will tell you about the transatlantic treaty, because we cannot pay tribute to the citizens of Europe when they stand up against terror and want to erase them when they rise up against it. There was a public consultation on the investor-state mechanism , known as "ISDS" - which will transfer the sovereignty of citizens to businesses. And the European Commission decided yesterday that 97% of respondents, or 145,000 citizens who spoke out against ISDS, had answered next to the question which was in fact about how to improve a system and not about the investment mechanism. From then on, Mr Juncker, who had opposed this system in front of everyone here, passed the baby on to Mr Timmermans, for whom we understood that better regulation was above all better regulation for business and not for citizens.  So, Madam Prime Minister, will the Council take into account the 97% of European citizens who have spoken out against ISDS and remove this chapter from TTIP?

name: Petr Mach (EFDD). -
text: Madam Prime Minister, you mentioned that Latvia ousted from the Soviet system 25 years ago, and you say in one breath that you will support the new European Investment Fund. Don't you see a little paradox in that? Do you really think that when politicians and officials decide or co-decide on investment, our economy will improve? Doesn't that feel like a return to the old system? You say in your speech that your goal is to increase competitiveness, that you want to push for digitisation and better regulation. Doesn't that remind you of an old Soviet phrase about improving systems? Aren't they just empty phrases? Are you saying that you want to push for a revision of the Europe 2020 plan, does this not remind you of the old Soviet five-year plans? After all, in 2000, the European Union set out what it called the Lisbon Strategy. Who can you remember – by 2010, it will become the world's most dynamic and competitive economy. And in 2010, the European Union became the slowest growing economy in the world. So let's make sure we don't go back to those Soviet times that didn't work.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI). -
text: Mr President, the Schengen agreements prohibit a State from monitoring people entering or leaving its territory, as long as it is a passage between two signatory countries. It therefore seriously weakens the surveillance of dangerous individuals crossing Europe.  All European capitals are alerting us to the presence of jihadists within the Schengen area. It is time to apply Article 2 of the Treaty: "When public order or national security require it, a contracting party may, after consultation with the other contracting parties, decide that, for a limited period, national border controls adapted to the situation will be carried out at internal borders." France has suffered several attacks by Islamic terrorists since December. Many French people were killed or seriously injured. What more serious event are you waiting for to suspend Schengen? This lax treaty has already allowed Mehdi Nemmouche, the perpetrator of the attack in the Jewish museum in Brussels, to freely cross the borders between France and Belgium.  Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to take all the necessary measures for public order and the security of each of our countries. It is time to suspend the Schengen Treaty and finally monitor our borders!

name: Herbert Reul (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Mr President of the Commission, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for her work on This was a very precise, very refreshing and credible start to your Presidency, I will say that. It was a different way of thinking. This was a thinking for a policy that relies on growth, on its own responsibility, on attracting investment, not just constantly talking about it, and then also providing proof that it can be done. You speak for a country – I think, with deserved pride – that has shown that you can overcome difficulties yourself, even if you make an effort, that you can get the sound financing of the budget, that you can get growth back, even if you are in trouble. This is a success – in contrast, by the way, to the view of my green colleague, who, I believe, is no longer here, growth is the opportunity for jobs and therefore for people's well-being. After all, people are interested in getting something done, not just that we are constantly discussing it and talking about delivering services. I think you can be proud of what you have done in your country. If the yardstick for your presidency is and if the yardstick is to create an investment-friendly climate in Europe, then, I can only tell you, you will have the full support of our group. That's exactly what works —that's your example—and what's going to be successful. That is also the difference from what we adopted yesterday as The Presidency. I agree with the points from this Parliament as well: this was general talk, but nothing was done. And you have only made a contribution and want to return what you have now done to the European family as a contribution. I hope, and hope, that what you intend to do – to create an investment-friendly climate, to ensure that people invest the money they have, because they have confidence in politics – will ultimately also mean an opportunity for the vast majority of people in Europe to get jobs, prosperity and satisfaction. I am grateful for your speech and Have a huge confidence in your Presidency. Take good care!

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D). -
text: Mr President, dear Mr Juncker, madam Prime Minister, it is a great honour for me to have my country Latvia as the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. It gives my country, its officials and politicians great responsibility, at the same time, a great advantage, and it gives Latvia the opportunity to show itself as a country and to present its vision for the development of the European Union. There are two roles in which the Presidency can position itself in this process. One of them is to become a simple moderator who accepts and entertains guests, organizes events. Well, this role is not bad, but I think that the Presidency must still have its vision for the future. It must show initiative, make efforts to bring this vision to life. There are many problems that Latvia could pay close attention to. In my opinion, combating unemployment, social exclusion and inequality could be at the heart of this Presidency. There are currently 24.6 million people in the EU who do not have a job. 25% of Europeans are at risk of poverty. And, for example, in my country, Latvia, 35% of the population lives in poverty. It would therefore be logical for Latvia to take on an additional engine role in solving this common problem by using the role of the Presidency. And a few more words about the Europe 2020 strategy. An ambitious target of 20 million people living in poverty was set at 20 million over a decade. Almost half of the time has passed to realise the strategy's objectives, but unfortunately the results still do not give rise to optimism. There could be two challenges to realising this strategy, either plans too ambitious or unrealistic, or its performance is not effective. I also call for this opportunity to be used. Thank you very much!

name: Sampo Terho (ECR). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, there is indeed a great deal of good in the programme of the Latvian Presidency, as has been said here. It is important that you keep the competitiveness of the economy on the agenda, because that is the basis for growth and employment. It is also based on the european community as a whole and on action. The internal energy market is a good priority. They contribute to the aforementioned competitiveness and self-sufficiency, as well as to our security. A digital single market is also a good objective. This is one of the key aspects of the internal market that is still completely unfinished. The development of the digital single market can specifically create the aforementioned competitiveness and growth in Europe. However, Madam Prime Minister, as a member of the pro-Eu reform group, you said the most important thing at the end of your speech. Europe must be brought close to its citizens. This is done by focusing on fewer issues in regulation than in the past, dismantling unnecessary existing regulations and respecting the democracy and independence of the Member States. This will improve the EU's performance and improve citizens' confidence in the European Union.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, Madam President, as you told us at the beginning of this speech, it is the European values that have been attacked in Paris. The values of freedom, freedom of expression, freedom of religion, freedom to live together in difference and freedom of conscience. To say no to terror and fanaticism, there was a tremendous mobilization, there was the expression of true European solidarity on the streets of Paris. You were there. And I think that this mobilization is now a demand for Europe to act. We must act, because the threats, both internal and external, are still before us. Europe's response must be a firm response within the natural framework of our rule of law. We need to strengthen the Schengen system and effective control of our external borders and improve coordination and information sharing, it is a no-brainer. This includes the European NRL that has been discussed. We must strengthen the powers of Eurojust and Europol, activate the appointment of a European prosecutor and we Europeans will have to take up the issue of the internet because it is now the recruiting ground for all terrorists and that we - Europe - must not and cannot accept it.  There is also an external component that we need to talk about. We need a common, coherent and concerted strategy on all the areas of conflict that today feed fanaticism and terrorism. I am thinking of course of Syria, Iraq, Yemen, Libya, the Sahel where France, I recall is today is on the front line. Here, too, European solidarity must be shown with France. Finally, the best way to fight fanaticism and terrorism is to be proud of who we are, what we are, what we stand for. Basically, the spirit of democracy is the best of the spirits of resistance.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, I am disappointed that the programme of activities of the Latvian Presidency fails to offer in any real sense an alternative to the fiscal austerity policies which have been championed by all the European institutions for far too long. The programme, of course, endorses President Juncker’s investment package without, on the other hand, any real commitment to move away from the austerity policies, which have basically caused absolute devastation to domestic economies across Europe. There are now serious questions to answer in terms of how this investment package is going to be funded, for example. As it stands, the presidency programme provides little evidence that peripheral countries like Ireland will benefit, in terms of jobs or economic growth, from the financial measures proposed in the package. What we really need is a rejection of austerity policies. We need, among other things, a new fiscal and social agenda to ensure that we have real and substantial economic growth for all the EU Member States.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, Madam President, I would like to remember for myself how, at the end of the 1980s, a small, bright star lit up on my map. It was Latvia. People's desire for freedom ignited this little star on my map. Your Presidency will see an important reform of the Eastern Partnership and the Rio Summit. I would like to hear a little more about how you are going to resolve this situation, where we have a lot of problems. Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the fact that our eastern partner countries have made very difficult choices if they have chosen the approach towards the European Union. At the same time, they have lost very important trade relations with Russia, because Russia has punished these countries for wanting to join the European Union. How are we going to solve the fact that accession to the European Union's neighbourhood and convergence with the European Union will not penalise these countries? Secondly, how do we keep all six Eastern Partnership Member States together when three have concluded association agreements, so that we do not split the Eastern Partnership into two groups? Thirdly, how do we restore respect for the principles of the Helsinki Final Act, which Russia is now blatantly violating? I believe that the Latvian Presidency will play a very important role in discussing these issues.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, your work can be encouraging or depressing, depending on your point of view, in other words, you will hardly be able to do worse than those who preceded you. Yes, because the Italian Government has made so many promises, but it has not brought home any results. We are talking about unemployment and development, we prefer to talk about development and not about growth: the great investment plan presented by Juncker is hailed by the Italian Presidency as a victory is, in fact, a bluff! Few resources, by the way, distracted by other chapters of expenditure and no concrete idea of development.  If we want to give Europe a future and really combat unemployment, we must give the territories the opportunity to invest. However, the long-awaited document on flexibility has not solved anything: the regions are unable to spend the money because of the noose of the Stability Pact which, let us say, has not been taken away. That is why we are asking you for a strong commitment, at least the cofinancing of the funds is being decomputed from the Stability Pact.  There is also a great deal to be done in the environmental field: the European Union has decided to curb the reduction of gas emissions and the construction of a greener and more resource-efficient economy. With what credibility are we going to Paris? With what credibility we can ask other countries, especially developing countries, to do more to combat global warming. I am also thinking of what is happening in the Mediterranean, where the oil race is divided, on drilling, the European Union is leaving the Member States carte blanche, and that is a great hypocrisy. So much is done for sustainable fishing, but if it is the drilling rigs that pollute and destroy the Mediterranean, what is Europe doing? Turn the other way! This hypocrisy also jeopardises important strategies, such as the strategy of the Adriatic-Ionian region.  Policies like this are important, yet in the Adriatic Croatia does? He recently gave the OK to 10 concessions to drill. To ensure that development and employment are really at the heart of the six-month period and within a framework of respect for the environment and resources, as well as for the peculiarities of the individual States: social, economic and cultural peculiarities of the territories.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacre in Paris has affected the heart of Europe and that of its citizens: our freedom, our values, our civilisation have entered the crosshairs of Islamic fundamentalism and none of us feel safer. Europe must wake up, they have declared war on us and we must fight in war! It is not enough to be in the front row, as you did, as European leaders did on Sunday in Paris, we need to act now because it is already too late! We need courage, in words and deeds! We must suspend the Schengen Treaty immediately because Europe has shown that it cannot protect its citizens.  And then, no more illegals! Because the police department has quantified that for every 1,000 illegal immigrants landed there is a potential terrorist. We need to finally set up the Strategic Counter-Terrorism Analysis Committee. Enough, talk about possible violations of privacy and freedom! Because it is islamic terrorists who are free! Europol is talking about 5 000 fighters who are or will arrive in Europe. We must remove security expenditure immediately from the Stability Pact.  Dear President, we need more courage, which I have not heard in your words, we need the courage of the Commission, the Council and we need the courage of the European Parliament, which unfortunately does not have the courage!

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Prime Minister, i would like to thank you very much I would like to congratulate the Latvian Presidency. A competitive, digital, globally engaged Europe – these seem to be the tasks that are still relevant. What we need is indeed what has been repeatedly emphasised – we want to have a sense of security in Europe in the first place and for citizens to have jobs. What is highlighted in the priorities of the Latvian Presidency is the focus on better regulation. This is also one of the European Commission's priorities for 2015. I support this argument, it must be said all the time, because instability in law-making is bad for the legislator, and it is also bad for successive Presidencies. If we change these rules during the game – we are discussing, among other things, the reform of carbon allowances – it will also show that consumers, and therefore also industry and therefore citizens, will not be happy about it.  I also welcome the importance of implementing the objectives of the Energy Union. It is not necessary to convince Latvia of how important this is. The importance of pro-growth policy, together with investment, was also underlined. We also discussed this yesterday when we talked about the Conclusions of the European Council of December. I am also convinced that everything about the development of the common market is perhaps the least controversial. The single market is perhaps the least controversial because of the effects it brings to all Member States, including those that are sceptical about the European Union.  I would also like to stress in particular the continuation by the Presidency of the strengthening of the neighbourhood policy. We look forward to the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga. It is also important for the Presidency to make the tpu negotiation process – that is, this free trade and investment agreement with the United States – a more transparent process, a process in which citizens will also know what the outcome will be.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this You take over the Presidency of the Council in difficult times. There are very, very many problems that are piling up. Terrorism in the European Union is, of course, a very big problem. Some Members have said, yes, we must now introduce monitoring instruments as quickly as possible and as much as possible. I think we have to be careful about that. It's not about how quickly you introduce something, it's about what makes sense. It is a fine line: on the one hand, to guarantee security – as far as possible – but also not to restrict what constitutes Europe: our civil liberties, our democracy.  And when I talk about democracy, I would like to mention something else: you talked about TTIP. I believe that special courts for corporations are not the rule of law today, that in such a case there is no equality before the law. We also need to discuss this. Of course, we need free trade, of course we need the Americans as partners – but only if we can preserve what makes Europe: our freedom!

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR). -
text: Grexit yes, Brexit no: those two points should be high on your agenda. Why? You can see that Greece's debt is over EUR 300 billion, which is almost twice the gross national product. In order to get close to a repayment, the country will have to score several percent of economic growth for many years. I'm afraid that's not going to work. Therefore, a grexit with a partial debt write-off and return to the old currency with devaluation is the best tool. Then there's some hope. There will be no such thing if the country remains under the heavy discipline of the demanding euro area. Furthermore, it is necessary to prevent the British from leaving the European Union at all times. Then the EU loses one of its core countries. This will have far-reaching financial and socio-economic effects, but also sociological effects. British sobriety and willingness to reform should be an example to many. We must keep that example in the EU. So there is a lot of work to be done for your presidency.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, in order to inspire confidence, the European Union must have the means to do so. You want to call for a competitive Europe and you are right because growth and jobs depend on it. And, like us, you welcome Jean-Claude Juncker's investment plan. Believe that we are mobilizing to quickly give you the legal tools you need. The scheme is based on the guarantee that the European Union will give to private investors who will be involved in sound but risky projects. The European Union must therefore be able to fulfil its commitments by replacing project holders who are in default.  In this regard, I would like to remind you, Madam Prime Minister, that the European Union is facing a sneaky debt, which probably amounts to almost 30 billion unpaid as of 31 December 2014. After six weeks of fruitless conciliations and arduous trilogues, we reached an agreement on the 2015 budget, conditioned by a plan to clear these debts.  Madam Prime Minister, I have not seen any trace in your program of this Council commitment. What is at issue here is the credibility of our commitment. The confidence of private investors depends on it, that is, the success of the Juncker plan. Madam Prime Minister, I wish you success!

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, the next six months will certainly be marked by the negotiations which are being carried out almost secretly for this Agreement on Trade and Investment between the European Union and the United States, the holy alliance of multinationals on both sides of the Atlantic, the breakdown of any legal rules that put obstacles to their profit rate. It is intended to place a heavy blow to labour rights, environmental and food standards, a blow to our public services and a blow to democracy, with arbitration courts that will have more power than democratically elected governments. With this treaty they pretend that we cannot make left-wing policies even if we win at the polls. A treaty to leave everything tied up, because they are afraid of governments that stop their privileges. They are afraid because the people are determined to regain their dignity. And we start from the south, through Greece.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE). -
text: Chairman! Mrs. Straujuma, i would like to thank you very well. Colleagues! As a Citizen of Latvia, I very much like our presidency to be successful. As a representative of the Group of the Regionalist European Free Alliance, I am very much a willed for the Latvian Presidency to promote the cultural and linguistic diversity of the European Union, given that all European cultures are equally valuable and respectable and that the concept of linguistic diversity applies not only to the official languages of the European Union, but also to regional languages and languages which are not officially recognised in the Member States. As President of the Russian Union of Latvia, I am very much happy to have the latvian ruling parties, inspired by their current high mission in the European Union, to review their policy of linguistic discrimination and segregation of citizens so far, to grant citizens the full rights of citizens of Latvia and guarantee the official status of Russian, which is the mother tongue of 40% of the population. I hope for this wish, because only societies that guarantee cultural diversity and promote mutual respect from representatives of different cultures are able to cope with today's challenges. This has been greatly demonstrated by recent events in France. I want us to do it.

name: Paul Nuttall (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I predict that the next six months will prove a rocky road for the Latvian Presidency. There will be many difficult issues to deal with, including Mr Juncker’s fantasy financial plan, Greece’s possible exit from the euro, dealing with the instability in Ukraine – encouraged by the European Union, of course – and finally, a continent coming to terms with the Islamic extremism that we witnessed last week. But in many ways Latvia is a microcosm of all that has gone wrong in the EU. Your economy tanked in 2008, followed by one of the worst recessions on the planet. You had to receive a bail-out even before you joined the ailing currency that is the euro – against the wishes of your people, of course. You are still the fourth poorest country in the EU. You have lost 20% of your population since 1992, so much so that the Baltic is now depopulating faster than anywhere else in the world. Your brightest, best and young are fleeing west in their droves. And where are they going? Well, considering that one in every 30 Latvians lives in the UK, that is pretty easy to answer. You have a brain drain, an ageing population, which means that there will be a skills, pensions and healthcare crisis not far down the road. In all, freedom of movement and the EU’s economic policies have been a disaster for Latvia, and may I suggest that you get your own house in order first before you take on the problems of an old, tired and out-of-date European Union.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Madam Prime Minister, I would like to thank you You are deeply shocked by your statement that it is a big problem that the European Union is not united enough and that it is not united enough against Russia. And he called it one of the most important tasks of the six months ahead to strengthen this unity, that is, the toughness of the action against Russia. Madam Prime Minister, I'm sorry for the sharp wording that you're coming to this. Don't you think that this kind of attitude increases tension, increases the Cold War atmosphere, predicts the immediatity of the threat of real war? When people living in increasing misery ask what the European Union is good for, despite all the hardships and pains, they always say that it is good for the preservation of peace. Do you really want to keep the peace? I ask you very much to reassure us about this and to answer my question about what you intend to do so that your country, Latvia, my country, Hungary and all of Europe can continue to live in peace. I look forward to your reply, Prime Minister.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the beginning of 2015 has brought dramatic events in France, and we are also seeing an upsurge in fighting in eastern Ukraine. Madam Prime Minister, Europe will need to respond during your Presidency to those and other challenges, offering our citizens more freedom through better security. The Latvian Presidency promises to be a challenging one, yet I am convinced it will be a fruitful time for the Union. While listening to your programme, Madam Prime Minister, I was happy to hear that your Presidency will focus on better exploitation of existing mechanisms and procedures and ways of improving them. This approach should be praised and encouraged. I also see a chance that in the coming months we will witness more cooperation between European institutions, leading to a better functioning of the Union. We look forward to a fruitful interinstitutional dialogue and joint action. I personally hope that you will manage to increase the appetite of the Member States for serious steps forward on eurozone economic governance. I hope to have a constructive debate on closer coordination of economic policies in the EMU in early 2015. I hope to see commitments to the streamlining of existing procedures within the European Semester and increasing the involvement of national parliaments in the process. I hope to see the strengthening of national ownership of structural reforms. You promised to put the spotlight on labour market issues. We need more investment in the employability of female workers and young people, especially in the context of emerging technologies and new sectors where growth will take place. Lastly, the first half of 2015 will also be also be a challenging one for the TTIP. The Commission has just released the results of its public consultation on ISDS with an overtly negative sentiment on its inclusion in the negotiated agreement. We will need to work together – all three institutions – to have an ISDS that will, at the end of the day, attract much-needed investment to Europe. I know there are many challenges on your table. I wish you a fruitful Presidency.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, after what has happened in my country, your Presidency, like the political programme of all Democrats, is being shaken up. But, like all parliaments in the world, it is up to us to be mobilized around what the values of the Democrats are. And, like all parliaments in the world that want to be democratic, we must arm democracy in the face of terrorists and we must do so in accordance with our values. That is why this Parliament will support an NRL if it allows us to defend our values and it is here in this Parliament that you will have to have this debate. Yes to a European NRL, a PNR that also defends the values of democracy and the protection of individual freedoms and data. Then, Madam President, there is a question in your Presidency that we democrats and socialists are waiting to see you seize with determination because it undermines our social model. That is the issue of taxation. This Parliament is convinced that, in the tax field as well, we need to act effectively at European level and, again, the work is completely open. We expect commitments from you in line with what this Parliament expects from the Commission's work programme. I wish you good luck!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the old political world of Europe, those who led the governments and institutions of the European Union, such as Mr Juncker, after filling European society with armies of the poor and unemployed, are now losing their hands and as young apprentice magicians promise an investment package that will supposedly lead to growth. But investments are not made with air, but with funds that the Juncker Plan does not have. Investments in the European South, which is affected by unemployment, will not be made unless the problem of public debt is solved, which, as a millstone, Prime Minister, crushes these countries. That is why the shameful debt in Greece must be erased and the public debt cut in the other countries of the European South must be cut. Because that is the only way to free up public funds that, instead of going into the pockets of loan lenders, will be invested in growth, which should not be aimed at the well-being of numbers and profits, but at creating jobs. Finally, growth will not be achieved without the abolition of austerity and the stimulation of demand.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, I too will talk about the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Treaty because it is one of your priorities and it is also one of mine, but in the total opposite direction.  You were just talking about investment, investment and more investment.
