But these treaties only benefit those above, to the detriment of people who suffer dramatically from the consequences of a crisis that has also not provoked.  European governments, in addition to cutting and cutting, have already paid more than EUR 3.5 billion , which is soon said – to private investors under ISDS-style clauses, which give multinationals a way to demand compensation from governments if new legislation is an obstacle to the return on their investments.  The Commission's consultation published yesterday clearly shows that there is enormous opposition — up to 97% — to ISDS mechanisms because they pose a threat to democracy, the environment, consumers, labour rights. They are quite an attack on the sovereignty of states. I would like you, Madam Prime Minister, to reconsider trade policy and prioritise people at once over the benefits of the great. Because the world is people's.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Council, first I think the Latvian Presidency needs a chapter on climate change. Preparing for Paris is not just a six-month story for the Luxembourg Presidency: it must be more present in your Presidency. The other big topic should be energy. With Russia we tend to have a conflicting relationship, so we need to review our energy policies. However, we have a kind of hypocrisy here: everyone is calling for an energy union but every government is saying ‘Do not interfere in my national energy mix’. The only way to overcome this blockage is a new style of governance in the energy field, and that new style of governance is regional cooperation on energy. Latvia has benefited, Madam President of the Council, from being involved in the EU’s Baltic Energy Market Interconnection Plan programme, in which we helped you in the Baltic regional market to get more gas pipelines and more electricity lines, and I think that, during your Presidency, you should promote this model of regional energy governance, because we need this for south-east Europe too. We are in a complete political vacuum after Nabucco and South Stream, so regional energy governance is the new form of governance which we need.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI). -
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European President for the You have certainly hit the mark with your objectives, which you have mentioned to us today for the Latvian Presidency, namely a competitive, digital and foreign policy-making Europe. These are priorities that are high on the European agenda. You certainly also have major challenges ahead of you in the energy chapter – as has just been mentioned – with the Energy Union in the first half of the year, which they can implement. However, I would recommend that you take another item as an agenda or as a priority: that is, that you sell your country, Latvia, as a best practice for a successful austerity policy. In a few years' time, they have managed to emerge from the crisis as a great winner. You managed to get it through with harsh austerity measures that you had economic growth of 3.8% last year, while the euro zone was 0.8%. This is a model for Europe, it is a model. With this model, they should make a roadshow across Europe so that countries can see how important it is to implement structural reforms in order to regain confidence and generate growth.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, as has already been reiterated, this Presidency begins in exceptional circumstances, as a result of the terrorist attack in Paris, which has shocked French citizens so deeply, but also the rest of the citizens of the European Union. This, in my view, urges the European Union to strengthen common instruments to prevent terrorist actions and to do so more efficiently. I am very interested in stressing that common instruments in this case are equal to more efficiency. That is why I think it is inexcusable, for example, that the European Union's national traveller registration plan is a reality as soon as possible. You, on the other hand, point out that a digital Europe is one of your priorities, and I cannot agree more. And I think this is because the competitiveness of the European economy is strongly determined by digital development. This means that security, trust, training and access to next-generation networks need to be addressed. There are two proposals, even three, on one of these key aspects that come from the previous legislature. You mentioned them yourself. There is the Data Protection Regulation, the Information Network Security Directive and also the Single Telecommunications Market Regulation, which affects such crucial issues as net neutrality and the end of roaming charges. The end of roaming costs, Madam President, will be an unequivocal and tangible signal to the whole European Union that there is added value. And in this sense, it is a decision that brings integration to the European Union and also allows SMEs and start-ups to better tackle and access a market of five hundred million people. An ancient Latvian proverb says that every man forges his destiny. The Latvian Presidency now has the opportunity to honour, pay tribute, to that proverb, and I am sure that it will do so by contributing to a much more competitive European market. Convinced I'm not going to save any effort on it. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Ms del Castillo, you mentioned making access for new start-ups to 500 million consumers easier within the European Union. The problem – as we see for example with the new VAT MOSS regulations – is that quite often we are making things much harder for consumers; we now have the requirements for VAT for online businesses to be paid to countries across Europe. We are making things harder for businesses. I have businesses in my constituency coming to me saying that they are going to have to close thanks to new EU legislation. Do you agree that is unacceptable?

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – I believe that legislative development must be made, where necessary, in order to avoid the extraordinary legislative fragmentation in the European Union with the aim of better developing the internal market and, in this case, the digital internal market. I have specifically referred to what the end of roaming burdens would mean for those most disadvantaged, from the point of view of economic resources, such as small businesses and start-ups, when, trying to access a potential market of 500 million consumers, they face excessively high internet communication costs. In that sense, I believe that the end of roaming will also be beneficial in developing the digital internal market.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, my colleague Pilar del Castillo said, referencing a Latvian proverb, which every man can face his destiny. I say: every man and every woman. And on this issue I want to talk about equality policies. I have been reviewing the Presidency's work programme and I have seen that there are very few references to the need to promote equality policies at European Union level. There is some reference to issues relating to equality and cooperation, and there is a section on the issue of women's participation in the board of directors, which we discussed yesterday. But there are many other issues on which this Presidency has to insist. We are talking about the largest social scourge in the world and in Europe at the moment, such as gender-based violence. We talk about the need to reconcile family and work life. Women are being the victims of this economic crisis, suffering from the cuts and deterioration of public services. We're talking about fundamental policies for women. And I give you a proposal, Madam Prime Minister: create a working group with the trio of presidencies so that we can unlock and continue the work on maternity leave, because I believe that it is fundamental and important for men and women, for conciliation in Europe, and is therefore a challenge that is in our hands today. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me that the difficulty that we find when we try to impose legislation and rules on equality is that often we focus too much on equality of outcome, whereas what we should be looking for is equality of opportunity, because not everyone is equal in whatever task they undertake to perform? You have the right to have an equal opportunity, but some will do better than others. That is human nature, and that is where government legislation falls down. Would you agree?

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – I will not allow us, with the excuse of human nature, to allow half of the European population to continue to suffer from a situation of inequality of opportunity. Of course, we are all different, but we are all the same in opportunities and rights, and today it is evidence that in the world and in Europe women suffer because they are an unequal part of the population.  Measures are therefore needed to enhance equality because otherwise we will be wasting half the resources, half of the European population. We're not going to allow excuses. We need to agree, as we have in other areas, to encourage women to be equal, both in the labour market and in terms of rights recognised for all European citizens.

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Prime Minister, i would like to thank you very much The Latvian Presidency is facing important tasks. First of all, it is about achieving two fundamental objectives. The first concerns the Union's energy security, the second relates to the provision of jobs and a decent standard of living for residents. We are talking primarily about rebuilding an industry that gives jobs and decent wages. The EU guidelines for the decommissioning of workplaces should be unequivocally opposed. Such an example is my country, Poland, where thousands of jobs have been job wiped out in recent m.in in the shipbuilding industry. For the same reason, the government is currently removing more jobs in the coal sector and heavy industry. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to take action to stop the deindustrialisation processes that increase unemployment and increase poverty. (The speaker agreed to answer the question raised by raising a "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – True, the deindustrialisation of Europe has led to a decline in jobs and, of course, we are all concerned about this. My question is: do you not think that trade defence rules should be adopted for the European Union's single market? Trade defence measures? Because you can't increase jobs in the industry if you don't have a market and you don't have a market because they are entering the European Union's single market for uncontrolled products.

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Full agreement, of course. Our aim is to create conditions so that the European Union can develop equally. I am talking here first and foremost about sustainable development. It must not be the case that in some countries the law allows some kind of facilitation for industry, for the development of jobs, and in others it is regarded as unacceptable. With this once and for all you have to stop.

name: Marcel de Graaff (NI). -
text: The terrible events in Paris and Nigeria over the past week have made it painfully clear that Islamic terrorism reaches from the heart of Africa to the heart of Europe. It sows death and destruction in the unsparing urge to subject the world to an Islamic caliphate. That is why the Latvian Presidency must be entirely focused on the fight against Islamic extremism. I call on the President to seek cooperation with Israel and Egypt, the two states that can provide stability in the Middle East. I would like to point to President Al-Sisi's address to the clergy at Cairo's Al-Azhar University, in which he called for a radical change in Islam, so that it becomes an example of peace and order for non-Muslims rather than a source of violence and chaos. I also point to his historic visit to the Coptic church at Christmas. I ask the Latvian President to pay attention to education in Egypt, which is essential to reverse the process of radicalisation. And I call for special attention to the fight against extremism in Libya. Libya is currently the area where terrorists have free reign, the area from which Mali, Nigeria and Egypt, as well as Europe are threatened by unscrupulous, heavily armed killers. That is why stopping mass emigration from North Africa under this Presidency must also be a priority. The European countries, Egypt and Israel, can fight [The President deprives speaker the word.]

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, as a French MEP I thank you for your participation in the historic March in Paris last Sunday. The march recalled the human chain that had connected the capitals of the three Baltic states fighting for their freedoms.  The tragedy in Paris will, of course, force the Latvian Presidency to introduce the fight against terrorism at the top of our European agenda. But from this example, my main point will be on the Eu's method of governance and its poor performance in communicating with the media and public opinion. What did we see until last year? From time to time, the European Council meets, setting itself a grandiose, distant and unrealistic goal. It adopts twenty pages of conclusions that no one reads, and then the Commission consults. It produces green books. Parliament passes resolutions and legislative implementation takes years, everything is lost in the sands, no one understands it.  That is why the Lisbon Strategy has failed, the agenda of the Europe 2020 strategy is failing and the Headline Goals military capability targets have never been implemented. That is why the Union has made a fool of itself in such vital areas as energy, asylum policy and immigration policy. We talk about it and we vote all the time, but we don't fix anything.  I am pleased that, under the leadership of the Jean-Claude Juncker Commission, this model of governance is beginning to change. Yesterday, the Commission adopted a comprehensive package of measures to support growth, which will be submitted to us as a whole. The European Council on 14 February will be devoted solely to terrorism, and then energy and the digital economy Will we organise all institutions together to deal with the major issues only, but one by one, in one go and in all aspects. Then national parliaments, the media and citizens will understand and regain confidence in Europe.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Straujuma, I congratulate Latvia, because the first Presidency is a serious test for a country that, together with joining the euro area, really crowns the inclusive process. And I believe that, in half a year' time, Lithuania and Latvia will together be able to welcome the two of the new member states of the European Union. It is very important that Latvia organises the Eastern Partnership Summit. This will be a continuation of the Vilnius Summit, because the geopolitical situation remains very difficult. It is therefore essential that we, the European Union, ensure strategic continued support for the Eastern Partnership countries. I call on Latvia to complete the development of a platform to combat illegal work. We must not only increase investment in Europe, but also effectively combat illegal employment, which takes not only national incomes, but also social protection for workers. As President, you have highlighted the importance of social protection and social services. This is indeed very important.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR). -
text: The Latvian Presidency will work for a 'Europe for its citizens', built on peace and freedom. The terrorist attack in Paris has shown that these values are by no means acquired. Together, we can come out stronger. We must continue to defend European values and freedoms, not only with words, but also with action. In concrete terms, I am thinking of better protecting our external borders and a European list of terror suspects. In addition, the Latvian programme includes the strengthening of the internal market, one of the cornerstones of the European project. A further completion of this is therefore indispensable. This is by no means a plea for more European legislation. No, we must go for less, but better regulation that focuses on growth, jobs and competitiveness.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE). -
text: Dear Prime Minister, I greet you with great respect in the European Parliament, and I am very pleased to hear in your speech the thoughts that have been made about how much has happened in your country since we joined in 2004, I must say, together. How they joined the eurozone and what challenges they now face with their first presidency in office. I will start by saying that we owe you a debt of gratitude and thank you for the behaviour, for the quick adaptation they have made to the terrorist attacks in Paris. And the series of measures that we have managed to take with the EU's interior ministers to increase the security of all of us and to ensure good cooperation between the judicial authorities. I've read your program and I can see how complex it is. As you said, they have made a huge commitment and this is very commendable. I would like this commitment to be fully discharged. I would like to highlight one point from this: the digital market. This rapid adaptation, which you mentioned, is very important in the digital market. The digital market is a huge reserve for the European Union. According to one study, €520 billion could be added to the GDP of the 28 countries, a tighter internal market, a better functioning internal market. It's a huge reserve right now. Not exploiting this opportunity is a mistake. I think that the programme of the presidency of the semester should be focused, and many others, of course, on exploiting this potential. During this period, all countries need this explicitly. I urge the Prime Minister to take the necessary steps and make suggestions. \*(The speaker agrees to answer a 'Blue Card' question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI)
text: Blue card question. - Dear Fellow Member, He praised the significant achievements of Latvia, who joined the European Union at the same time as our Hungary, as a common country. Among other things, it has joined the euro area, is very economically successful and so on. I ask you fondly, why do you know that you'Hungary in such a different situation? According to the wrong languages, it is possible that domestic politicians may have stolen less there in recent years since the so-called regime change than in our country. Or less served by their own state... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Blue card answer. - Thank you for the congresswoman's question. Congresswoman knows that there are no e-recipe. When we joined in 2004, we, too, looked forward to the future. Hungary also had a target date for joining the eurozone. In 2002, our country suffered a break in its life, after which our economy began to plunge. Much sooner, the crisis that started from the inside reached us. As a result of the socialist governments, we are almost bankrupt. Under these circumstances, let's be happy with where we are right now, and perspective... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask Madam Vice-President, if she was talking about the digital market, whether she could befriend a so-called Digital Union compared to the Single European Digital Market. In other words, given the one exception, would the same rules apply to the digital market in all countries?

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Blue card answer. – We are lagging behind in the digital market, for example in the United States of Europe. I believe that there must be sufficient moderation and gradation in this area. It would be obvious to take such a huge step as you are saying, I would be satisfied that, if, in this term, either during the Presidency-in-Office or looking at the next seven years, we could put the digital internal market at the heart of policies and achieve as much as possible what we have set out to achieve in our programme.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D). -
text: Sur President; Sinjura Prim Ministru, Il-Presidenza tal-Latvja se tibda fi żminijiet diffiżli, fejn l-instability tal-pajjiżi fil-Lvant u n-Nofsinhar, kif ukoll l-attivitajiet ta' extremists u terrorists qed iťassbu mhux ftit liσ-σittadini tagťna.  Napprezza nara li l-Presidency Latvjana gťamlet bťala prijorità l-impenn li l-Ewropa tkun punt ta' global referment u tindirizza l-problema tal-immigrazzjoni fil-qafas ta' solidarjetà u responsabilità minn kulťadd. However, donnu li l-Presidency Latvjana tat aktar importance lill-problema tal-Lvant tal-Ewropa, destination din hi wkoll tar-reťjun tal-Mediterran problem. Nistaqsi: kif ser jiżu indirizzati l-isfidi politièi, ta' sigurtà u ambjentali li jolqtu direttament pajjiżi bťal Malta, l-Italja u l-Greja? If naraw fl-aťar azzjoni serja fejn jidťol il-żarr tar-responsibilità minn kull Stat Membru, jew dan se jibqa' biss diskors sabiť imma fieragť? Rigward the-Frontex; if tara l-Presidency jekk dan huwiex effettiv u jekk hemmx il-bżonn li jinkludi pajjiżi Afrikani? Hemm bżonn li l-momentum li ntlaťaq mill-Presidency Taljana fl-oqsma li semmejt ikompli jikber biex il-beżgťat taż-żittadin jiżu addressed. Irridu nifhmu li dawn ....... (il-bqija tad-diskors ma jinstemax billi l-President qatgťalha l-mikrofonu).

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, I want to welcome Madam President, and if one could talk about a country's curriculum then 25 years on from secession from the Soviet Union, 10 years since joining the European Union and a year in the eurozone are really fascinating data. I want to thank you for that.  I especially understand you because I come from Croatia, a country that has come a similar path, but perhaps a little more complex than latvia's path. You've managed to become a role model country, and I really want to thank you for that. I would like to thank you for the speech you had here this morning, in which you said what your priorities are, but above all given the situation we are currently in and referring to the events in Paris and your priorities which will be greater humanity, greater solidarity, greater concern for other cultures and coexistence. That's what we all have to build. But of course all this will not be without an economically strong Europe. Therefore, your priorities are very important and I am particularly pleased that you support the Juncker Investment Plan, and most importantly, that your programme is compatible with the European Commission programme. This is the first time that, I hope, all institutions will somehow work together and that there are no major differences at the moment or between the Council and the Commission. You may hear some critical tones from this Parliament, but Parliament wants it well and is aware that we must work together, it is aware that we must have one mainstream that will make Europe truly competitive. What I also want to commend is my commitment to the digital union and the digital economy, but also to the Energy Union for known reasons. As for your global engagement, it is very important given your geopolitical situation, that is, the attitude towards the territorial integrity of Ukraine, which I consider very important. Also, it should not be forgotten migrations in the south. I really want to congratulate you, and I agree with the headlines that came out these days: "small country with big agenda".

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D). -
text: I would indeed like to congratulate my latvian neighbours, who have now become the great Presidency of the European Union, wholeheartedly. We have also been very pleased to see that Latvia has indeed followed these principles in its development in recent years: increasing its competitiveness, increasing people's confidence. And I think that Estonia and Latvia are also working very strongly together on the main point of your Presidency and in overcoming all the obstacles to digital development that we are seeing now.  It has already been said that the Council is currently in the hands of the European Parliament. We are ready, the Commission is ready, so we very much hope that Latvia will also take these things to the point in the Council so that we can start with a trilogy about data protection concerns. I am very pleased to see that Latvia has planned a number of such events where different countries meet in Riga and can exchange their experiences, and I look forward to the digital agenda meeting. I very much hope (the speech was interrupted)

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister how happy I am that Latvia is here as a European leader because, Madam Prime Minister, your country has not only overcome its occupation in times past, but it has indeed proven how to come out of economic crisis, how to conduct structural reforms and how to balance the budget and regenerate growth. Your predecessor, Mr Dombrovskis, has proven that this is doable, and that austerity and growth are not exclusive but are actually complementary. Your task is to resist attempts to transform the Stability Pact into a sort of flexibility pact. It is crucial for Latvia to keep the EU united in relations with Ukraine and Russia, because our unity and consistency are the only means to enhance the EU’s political impact and moral credibility. Even limited sanctions have had a greater effect than expected. Now there is a temptation to relax them, even before the Minsk Agreements have been fully implemented. I think this is, above all, a battle of nerves, and I trust that Latvians have got strong nerves. One of the Latvian priorities should be to overcome the fragmentation of the digital single market. The EU needs an ambitious strategy on clearing the main bottlenecks like data protection, authors’ rights, applying common European sales law, achieving agreements on the telecom single market, and the rest. Finally, I hope that the Riga Summit in May will send our Eastern partners – which have successfully done their homework, of course – a clear message on that EU perspective, and that the visa-free regime with Georgia could also be agreed to. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Kelam, you gave us Latvia as an example of the fact that growth and fiscal stability can be reconciled, but I fear you are unaware that Latvia started from a public debt that was almost non-existent, at only 8% of its Gross National Product, in 2007 and has now soared to levels above 40%. If it had started at levels of 100%, the ejection that would have occurred due to austerity and the reduction of the national product would have driven it out of the markets and made it impossible for latvian adjustment to succeed.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think it is true about balancing economic policy. I am happy that Latvia and Estonia have not expanded – this is easier for us. It was easier to come out of the economic crisis. But there are differences of course. We have solidarity with Greece. Greece is continuing its reforms, hopefully, and we look forward to Greece overcoming its debt problems with the solidarity of the European Union.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Straujuma for outlining her plans to this Parliament. On behalf of the British Labour delegation I welcome much of what you will be prioritising for the coming months, Prime Minister, especially on issues such as energy security and the implementation of the Investment Plan. However, much like the Commission work programme, it is not what is in the programme that is disappointing but what has been left out. The question I would like to ask is: why will no-one in the Council or the Commission put forward a real plan to reform the EU’s exploited social model? For instance, where is your commitment to take action on zero-hour contracts, to protect those who are under contract without any guarantee of paid work? Where is the commitment for a full revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to help those who have seen wages being undercut? Unemployment is high across all parts of the EU, but even those people in employment are feeling squeezed and vulnerable. We must take action in this area, otherwise we will miss a vital opportunity. It is our responsibility to show by our actions that this EU works for everyone. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I find it, I must say, astonishing to hear a Labour MEP in this Chamber talking about zero-hours contracts because, of course, Tony Blair, in 1995, pledged that if he came to power, the Labour Party would end zero-hours contracts. Well, you had 13 years in power; you did not do it then. Are you actually going to do it if you get back into power this time?

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – We have actually been talking about zero-hours contracts for a long time. I have not heard UKIP talk about it. We have said quite clearly that we will stop the abuse of zero-hours contacts. That is something we are determined to do and it is something everybody in Britain should be determined to do.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in- I think it is absolutely right to focus on the issue of employment, the revitalisation of industry. This includes, of course, good trade agreements, because we have a very export-oriented economy and are involved in the global value chain. Imports are already up to 40% of the value of our exports. So we need clear and good trade agreements. I would therefore urge you to check that we are not questioning good trade agreements, particularly with regard to TTIP and CETA, by – I believe – politically and economically unnecessary out-of-court investment arbitration. These out-of-court investment arbitration sputeities do not help to make a single investment in Europe, the US or Canada, which we do not need. Therefore, let us not jeopardise the agreements by such arbitration bodies!

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, the Latvian presidency is beginning at a very delicate stage for Europe: we will have to tackle terrorism with effective joint action – I hope that this action will be based on intelligence and the construction of a culture, indeed on strengthening the culture of freedom. Woe betide us if it calls into question the fundamental freedoms for European citizens, if it were to reduce their rights, if it led to a reversal of democracy rather than its strengthening!  At the same time, we will have to tackle the problem of growth together: Europe has not emerged from the very serious crisis that has affected it. We need targeted investment policies and we need flexibility in the management of each country's public expenditure and accounts, certainly within a defined framework, but with the flexibility and reasonableness that is needed. We need growth for our children, your semester will be very demanding for this reason too.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D). -
text: Latvia begins its journey with a certain bitterness. Not because of you, Madam President. Riga will urgently need to add a global and social dimension to the Presidency. The escalation of intolerance, nationalism, extremism and other extremist behaviour is a cause for great concern today. We need to look for the causes of radicalisation in our society and take responsibility. It is a fore-up to us that we pay too little attention to multiculturalism and the integration of immigrants into our society. We need to put more effort into reassuring and establishing a ceasefire between the West and the Muslim world, and the first such brave step would be – to bring the people together – recognition of Palestine. I was shocked by the recent french media reporting that violence among children is escalating in schools and that some even refused to join a minute's silence. Europe also earns a red card for its harsh austerity measures, especially at the expense of education and social, especially for the most vulnerable groups in our society.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, it is good that Latvia is leading Europe, because this shows how the unity of Europeans – I come from the South, from Italy – can make history walk and that a woman who heads the Council is a sign of women's leadership. I hope and ask you to guide the Council in continuity with the work of the Italian Presidency, which has strongly placed and pursued the priority of growth and investment, because we need strong European economic governance aimed at growth, work and not depressing Europe and clogging it up.  What you say is important on industrial policy, because we must strengthen our continent's production capacity by maintaining innovation in the most excellent sectors but spreading it in all sectors – I would also like to point out to you the importance of made in, as other Members have done. On digital, I say to you that the closure of the Telecom package is important for the European Parliament, which has spoken clearly: zero roaming, accessible and safe services for citizens and investments in broadband. A final word on EXPO and the Millennium Goals that are also included in its work plan.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, the EU is confronted with many domestic challenges. During the debate this morning we have identified the priority issues and the way ahead, but today we cannot decouple domestic priorities from external challenges. The political and security landscape on the very doorstep of the Union is one of crisis and outright conflict, both to the east and to the south. If the EU’s success or credibility is determined in our own neighbourhood, then today the Union is called upon to make the ultimate effort for peace and prosperity on the European continent. I know that the Eastern Partnership summit in Riga constitutes a top priority for the Latvian Presidency. I am glad that Commission Vice-President Timmermans is here, because the Commission is already working on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This year we have a unique opportunity to make a fresh start. The Union needs bold action within and beyond its borders. Prime Minister, I wish you and the Latvian Presidency every success in this important test.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D). -
text: Mr President, in the European Year of Development the priority given by the Latvian Presidency to the digital agenda deserves to be welcomed. Some look at digital as a strictly technological platform. It is on the energy and digital platform that the European Union has to find answers to our challenges of growth, jobs, connectivity and security. The European Union has been a loser in the technological cycle that is now coming to an end. That's why we were exposed, economically and socially, and we were diverted to the geostrategic periphery. The new technological cycle is an opportunity, an opportunity in terms of security, an opportunity in cybersecurity, an opportunity in data protection, an opportunity to create more transparency, market regulation, taxation, an opportunity for the creation of new products, new wealth-generating services, job-generating services. Madam President, the success of your agenda will also be the success of the European Year of Development and will have implications inside and outside the European Union. Best wishes.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D). -
text: Mr. Speaker, Madam Prime Minister, the success of the investment plan to boost growth and jobs is a priority in your program and I welcome that. But a stimulus package needs fresh money and - as we see in the montage and discussions around the Juncker plan - it is difficult. For several years now, we have been calling on the Council on the urgency of the Union to regain its own resources. It is a prerequisite for taking the Union budget out of the logic of just return, a deadly logic that kills all Community ambition.  The payments crisis is nothing more than a devious indebtedness of the Union and the unpaid bills, which are heavier year after year, are fuelling mistrust and discredit towards our institutions. Your Presidency will have to work on concrete solutions proposed by the Commission. The proposed timetable on the payments crisis and the first progress report of the high-level group on own resources should, it seems to me, be one of your priorities.  Madam Prime Minister, with the heavy task of prioritizing the work of the Council... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Madam Prime Minister, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, in yesterday's debate on the previous Council, the Council in December, I pointed out that the Commission had shown promptness, passion and determination to carry out its work, had presented the investment programme in time, had , yesterday , approved the regulation of the Fund for Strategic Investments and, above all, had declared and implemented its willingness to work with Parliament through the ordinary legislative procedure. However, the December Council was not an equivalent Council in ambition and commitment. No commitments were made to allocate public funds to this investment fund, to this investment plan. I call on the Latvian Presidency to use, from the outset, its pressure on the Member States to contribute these funds to the investment plan. With regard to the European Year of Development, the preparation of two very important development summits, such as the Climate Change Summit in Paris, and the Summit, at the end of the year, in New York, on post-2015 targets, take place just during the presidency. As the European Parliament's permanent rapporteur for humanitarian aid, I would like to stress the need to include humanitarian aid, the prospect of humanitarian aid, as far as the year is concerned ... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE). -
text: I am pleased to see a successful and ambitious Latvia at work, for the first time in a leading European role. My sincere congratulations and best wishes. Latvia qualified for this role as an example of a country that has overcome a deep crisis through decisive reforms. I would like to say this to a colleague who spoke disrespectfully about Latvia's success: if our former colleague Dombrovskis had not taken responsibility for the rule with his team a few years ago, Latvia would remain a patient with a significantly higher depopulation.  I welcome the ambition, the comprehensive concept and priorities of the Latvian Presidency. I also welcome the programme coordination with the Commission. I very much like the announcement of the 2020 strategy review. I expect the strategy of beautiful objectives to be upgraded with new integrated cross-sectoral development concepts. I see a marked need to come up with such a concept in the threesome energy, agriculture and the environment. I want a particular added value to Latvia on the future of the Eastern Neighbourhood.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D). -
text: Prime Minister, energy is a key pillar of the 'Juncker investment package', as it has been called. At the same time, energy and the Energy Union are a strategic objective for the whole of Europe. You have mentioned that due to the geographical location of your country, you will naturally turn to the East. However, in the Eastern Mediterranean, on the south side of Europe, we have important developments. One of our Member States, the Republic of Cyprus, of which one third of its European territory is occupied by Turkey, is trying to mine and use natural gas and energy for the strategic interests of the European Union itself. In a very strong resolution, here, we recognised its sovereign rights and at the same time condemned Turkey's actions. But we also have new illegal actions. I ask you to tell us what you will do about it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR). -
text: Dear Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would also like to thank and congratulate you for this sparing and robust speech. I am very pleased that a nation that has been able to liberate itself from the Soviet representation can lead the European Union today, and I am also pleased that you have upheld Eastern European politics so clearly, frankly and courageously, that European security and European solidarity are threatened by the danger of Russian imperialism. This is not, as one of my foreno spokes, calling war, it is simply a real, solidarity-based response to the threat not only to Eastern Europe, but also to the whole of the Old Continent. Thank you for these words. It was actually a solid and frugal speech. First of all, I would also like to congratulate this passage, which concerned cost-effective legislation, clear, cost-effective legislation.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE). -
text: Madam Prime Minister, welcome. We are hearing today the main priority areas for the Latvian Presidency, one of which is a more competitive European Union to support growth, greater well-being for citizens and more future development. We cannot agree more on these objectives.  However, I would like to refer to a legislative proposal which I am rapporteur and which touches on these points: the Directive on the transparency of measures regulating the prices of medicinal products for human use to which you make no reference. I reason my colleague Sophia in 't Veld says that there are many legislative proposals blocked in the Council. It is, Madam President-in-Office, with this Directive to provide patients with faster access to innovative medicines by improving their well-being. It is about accelerating the market entry of generic medicines, which means lower costs for national health systems. It is also about reducing the bureaucratic burden on companies in an industrial sector that is strategic for European competitiveness. I would remind you, Madam Prime Minister, that the European Parliament has already taken up its position at first reading and that in this parliamentary term, I and my colleagues... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, today in the European Union, especially in the peoples of the South - Galicia among them - many people suffer from poverty, hunger, and social exclusion. The Latvian Presidency should direct work to establish universal basic income. Health and access to medicines. Nowadays there are people with hepatitis C who do not receive medication because of speculation and the Troika. Don't you think one of the objectives of the Presidency should be to restore public services and ensure access to health for all people? Of the unemployment that affects young people, nothing has been said either. Milk quotas end on March 31. There is a great deal of concern in the sector. The reduction in prices at the origin is already a reality. Do you not think that it should be an objective of the Presidency to propose that public policies for production control continue? Let us join the southern wind, which will arrive from Greece with Syriza, to drive the changes that the European Union so badly needs.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to address those who are beginning this adventure of the European Semester today. Beyond all the big words that are made, even as mayor, I see people every day asking me for help, asking for answers both to my city, to my nation, Italy, but also to Europe.  We have seen in recent years how much poorer people have become, European policies have made them poorer. So I say to you: let us do something very concrete. Do you know that in Europe in recent months and years the possibility of eating meat has decreased while the purchase of eggs has increased because they are much cheaper? Maybe no one in here understands what meat is? These are two slices of meat, the people of Europe, millions of people, can no longer eat this because it has become a mirage, because there is no money. On the other hand, they only eat eggs! Then make the policy for the little ones, help the families, help the people who do not have the opportunity to buy even the slices of meat anymore and let us make sure that the eggs are well consumed but ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Marek Plura (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Dear Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am pleased that the Latvian Presidency has included the issue of human rights and social inclusion in its priorities and that it plans to address the situation of people with disabilities. I believe that the presidency's actions will contribute to significant progress on the introduction of the European Disability Charter. With the Charter, people with disabilities could make full use of the facilities offered in each country, which will contribute to greater mobility and fuller access to work and study abroad for this group of European citizens. I also hope that the draft introduction of the Charter will be on the agenda of the high-level meeting on disability in May.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, my congratulations to Latvia for taking over the first Presidency of the EU. Prime Minister, I welcome your programme and in particular the importance you have placed on the financial services sector and the need to get the framework right. However, as a rapporteur for the money market funds, I am disappointed not to see this more clearly in your programme. This is important legislation that has been on the table since September 2013, and the main concerns and possible solutions are well established. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of this House will vote on this in March this year. Therefore I would like your commitment that your Presidency will work with us to conclude on this issue. A quick second point: you place great emphasis on developing relations with Central Asia. I would ask you to expand this to the whole of Asia, especially India and China, and I hope you will set the framework for re-establishing EU-India summits.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE). -
text: In the next six months, the Union will try to return to the path of economic growth. The Juncker Plan is ambitious and the expectations for its implementation are considerable. The Presidency faces the important but difficult task of carrying out work smoothly on the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The Commission is due to present a legislative proposal on this in January. The second, equally important issue is the security and political stability of our continent. Our community will not be safe if there is still armed conflict across the eastern border. I therefore agree with the Prime Minister that Europe must be more involved internationally. The European Neighbourhood Policy needs to be strengthened and perhaps reformulating, and the Eastern Partnership Summit planned for May will be crucial in this context. Latvia has presented a sensible programme and has chosen good priorities. Any action by the Union in order to be effective must be carried out in cooperation with the Commission, Parliament and the Council.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D) -
text: My country, the Slovak Republic, will also preside over the European Union for the first time in 2016. You come at a time when the situation in Europe is very dramatic in terms of foreign policy, but also in terms of economic and social affairs. We have a difficult situation here in Greece, we have a difficult situation in Ukraine. All this will be part of your agenda and you will have to deal with all this perhaps faster than the very noble idea of the digital agenda you put on your agenda. So I would like to wish you well. Because we must show the citizens of the Member States of the European Union that we are doing something for them; that everything we are discussing here not only has a bureaucratic and administrative dimension, but has a direct impact on their lives. You also come from a country where the situation of the employed and their wages are not as good as somewhere in Western Europe, so I hope that this situation will also improve. We in Slovakia would appreciate it.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, I note with great satisfaction that there is a lot of expectation in Parliament for the Latvian Presidency, and you do not have such a level of expectation without an equal level of trust in the ability of the Latvian Presidency to perform that duty. The Commission fully shares the trust in the Latvian Presidency. We know from experience that there is only one way Europe moves forward, and that is if the three institutions responsible for moving Europe forward work together, hand in hand, with a joint programme and with joint ideas about the future. I want to come back to an issue which was raised by one of the honourable Members about the ability of Latvia to play its part, in the context of its history and its difficult paths in the last couple of years. Exactly 24 years ago I was in Riga when the oppressor, the Soviet Union, tried to prevent Latvia from fulfilling its destiny of being a free country again, and violence was used on the streets of Riga. I was there, I witnessed it, and it is a moment of great pride and joy for me to be standing here today, 24 years later, seeing in this institution the Latvian Presidency with its ambitions, its talent and its ability to take the European Union ahead with our ambitions and with everything we need to do in the next six months. If you had told me in that cold January in 1991 that this was going to happen in January 2015, I would have probably called medical services to have you committed – but here is what has been achieved, thanks to the ambitions of the Latvian people to be free. They did not choose to become members of the European Union because they wanted somebody in the European Commission, because they wanted somebody in the European Parliament or because they wanted to be part of institutions. They wanted to be members of the European Union because they shared the values upon which the European Union is based. That was the European family they wanted to belong to, and they have made these ambitions come true. Today those values are being challenged from the outside as well as from the inside of the Union, and the ambition of the Latvian Presidency, mirrored by the ambition I hear today in Parliament and by the ambition of the Commission, is to face the challenges and give an answer to them: to make sure that more people get jobs in Europe, that our rule of law is strengthened in Europe, that we are stronger in order to face outside threats, and that we use the potential of the energy union, of the digital single market and of all the things that will create a stronger European economy. I want to conclude by saying that the Commission has full trust in the excellence of the Latvian Presidency and its ability actually to deliver what all of us here today want for the European Union.

name: Laimdota Straujuma
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Dear Members, Panelists! First of all, I would like to thank you very much for your interest, opinions and questions. And I would like to thank Mr Frans Timmermans for reminding him of what happened on the exactly days of January in Riga. Because it's a certain emotional moment. I will try to answer your questions, but first of all I would like to say that it is very important that the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council work together. And only together will we be able to achieve what some Members of Parliament have said, namely that we will work for our people, the people of Europe. I will group my answers to the comments and questions of the political groups and Members in three parts: first, security, then, involving or in a global Europe and, thirdly, growth. For safety. It is the responsibility of all of us to respond to security challenges, and in this respect I believe that the Schengen system and the free movement of persons are an undeniable fundamental principle of the European Union. I cannot agree with the Members who are calling for the suspension of Schengen. By stopping Schengen, we will demonstrate our weakness and show those who are attacking our values that they can prevail and achieve their own. I can only repeat what Mr Gianni Pitella said about Schengen by name. With regard to the details of the much mentioned passenger register, I call for a look at these issues once again. We understand that issues are politically sensitive elements; we can discuss modalities, but we need to act. For a Europe involved. I absolutely agree that we must pay equal attention to our neighbours, both in the south and in the east. I would like to emphasise once again what I have already mentioned in my speech, namely that Russia's aggression in Ukraine is not only a bilateral issue between Russia and Ukraine, but also a question of European and global security. The best way to deal with this crisis on the part of the European Union is to maintain the unity of the European Union on this issue. For Europe, the European Union must continue to defend its principles, both in words and in deeds. We believe that we need to work in three directions. First of all, practical and political support should be given to Ukraine and other Eastern Partnership countries. Of course, we also expect the reforms that are taking place in these countries. Secondly, relations with Russia must be addressed by continuing diplomatic dialogue and pressure, in compliance with international law and the Minsk Agreement. Thirdly, it is necessary to strengthen our internal and external security. During the Presidency, we will strive to shape the political process and achieve, seek a peaceful and sustainable solution to the conflict in Ukraine, respecting the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of the states. It is important for all of us – and I believe that russia also has an important role – a strong and stable Ukraine. Therefore ( and here I thank the Commission, which has already done so this year) support the Ukrainian economy. Next, in response to a question from Dimitrios Papadimoulis, Member for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), we believe that TTIP should be a win-win agreement. We must have equal partners on both sides: the European Union and the United States. In view of the growing public interest in TTIP, we will actively cooperate so that the negotiations to be conducted by the Commission are also linked and reflected in the public. It is very important to inform the public and ensure much greater transparency in these negotiations. If we are talking about growth, then, as some of my colleagues have said – and this is supported by the Commission – the European Union's growth in the coming years must be based on structural reforms, fiscal responsibility and investment. And investment and the social dimension are interlinked. If there is no growth, it is difficult for every government to be social. I therefore believe that we need to be able to think about both dimensions. We have talked for a long time about investment in theory, and today I would like to congratulate the Commission and Mr Jean-Claude Juncker that the Commission has proposed investment for the European Union, and that is the mission of the Latvian Presidency, the Commission, and I have also asked Parliament to consider it as its mission, so that the solutions for this investment programme are available to our entrepreneurs as early as next semester. I have heard many words about overcoming the Latvian crisis. Thank you for the assessment, and I also accept the criticism, but it is clear that Latvia has overcome the crisis and latvia's growth continues, and we are proud of it. For every country in crisis, I cannot say that Latvia will be an example to all countries of how to act. Each country is unique, and each country chooses its own path to deal with the crisis. We have chosen our own path and it has been successful. And I would like to say that not only was austerity at the heart of the latvian crisis management path. It was also investment, it was a successful use of cohesion funds, it was structural reforms, it was a whole set of measures. And here, Mr Manfred Weber left, but, as I said, I would also like to agree with what Mr Weber and several other colleagues have said that growth is only possible if we find this right balance between fiscal discipline, structural reforms and investment in the economy. This is not only a challenge for Latvia, but for all of us. Next, Dimitrios Papadimoulis, MEP for cohesion. As I said earlier, cohesion is very important to us. We understand this, we use it, and we see very well in Latvia how both cohesion and the Structural Funds contribute to the growth of our economy. About 315 billion investment plans. I would like to reiterate that the Latvian Presidency will work on the basis of what was decided by the December European Council to facilitate a timely agreement. At the same time, I would like to agree with Robert Zīle and Matt Carthy that we need to look for ways to encourage investment in every Member State of the European Union. And, of course, I also agree with Mr Jean Arthuis on the organisation of the investment environment. And it is clear that, in order for us to implement this investment plan, we need, I will mention again, we will need triparty cooperation. And not just a tripartial Council. This means all 28 countries. Several Members touched on the issue of Greece. I would like to say that we are closely following developments in Greece. We must take into account and respect the choices made by the Greek people on 25 January. We assume that, after the elections, Greece will implement what the agreement provides and will continue the reform programme agreed with international leaders or heads of state. Changes to the program can be made, but only with the consent of all parties. After the Greek elections, it will be necessary to find a mutually acceptable solution for Greece and the European Union. I believe that we are all interested in Greece remaining in the euro zone and continuing the promises it has made as it moves towards economic recovery. Next, a number of colleagues addressed us with questions about the Energy Union. I would like to thank everyone who supported this priority, which is one of the conditions for competitiveness, and the Latvian Presidency will continue to work on the creation of an energy union. We are pleased that its creation will begin as part of the Riga process. In the new Energy Union, solidarity between Member States, a functioning, well-connected internal energy market, strong energy diplomacy, competitive energy and energy independence must be the most important elements, and, as some have already said, governance issues. In response to the question by Ms Sophia in 't Veld and Pilar del Castillo Vera on the single market for telecommunications, the Presidency will continue to work on the proposal and will work towards a compromise in the Council. I understand that this is not easy, but the work to be further focused on those elements of the proposal that will bring added value, namely roaming and net neutrality. We want a high-quality solution that will bring benefits. We must avoid the increase in mobile costs within the Member States. In response to the question of data protection by Ms Sophia in 't Veld, the priority of our Presidency is to work actively on the data regulation with a view to achieving universal access to the Council of Justice and Home Affairs Ministers. We believe that, in the digital age, a single data protection framework will strengthen data protection in Europe. At the same time, Latvia is fully aware of the complexity of the discussions on the remaining issues and the overall implementation of this project. MeP Pavel Telička spoke about better legislation. I fully support the work of First Vice-President Frans Timmermans, so that we really get to better legislation, that we have always considered the most appropriate solution and that the policies that we adopt are the most effective. I would also like to take this opportunity to call on the European Parliament to renew its work on the European Passenger Name Record. I call and trust that the European Parliament will be a close cooperation partner for the Council and the Commission.  Dear Members, Dear Commission, I would like to say thank you once again to everyone for your interest, for the questions asked. This will inspire the Latvian Presidency to work further. We, each of us, are ready to work with you to build a better Europe that is good for every citizen of the European Union. Thank you all!

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. - As shadow rapporteur on regulation on In vitro medical devices and the transparency directive on drug pricing measures, I hope that the Latvian Presidency of the European Council will adopt the legislative progress that the European Parliament and European patients have been waiting too long for. I call on my council colleagues to tackle the growing problem of excessive enjoyment of alcohol in Europe, especially among young people. Alcoholism costs Europe's economies around 150 billion euros a year, while social damage is utestuleable. I hope that latvian colleagues will show some political courage and propose new solutions to this problem. I welcome the announcements that one of the priorities will be the regulation and development of eHealth and mHealth technologies. These are tools that can help national health systems in situations where costs are increasing and budgetary resources are decreasing.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – I would like to wish the Latvian Presidency well, but I fear that the programme it has tabled does not mean anything like this. The new Presidency starts with u-local assumptions when it assures us that the Six-Pack and Two-Pack economic governance accords of 2011 and 2013 supposedly helped to better address the excessive public debt of the Member States of the Union. In fact, the total public debt of the 18 euro area Member States has increased sharply in the years of the crisis, from 83% of their GDP in 2010 to 95% in 2014, far from the Maastricht Treaty target of public debt below 60% of GDP. On the other hand, the policies pursued by harsh austerity are inflating unemployment and driving an increasing proportion of the population to or below the poverty line. What we need to make monetary union sustainable is a generalised restructuring of public debt under the responsibility and initiative of the European institutions. Unless there is substantial relief in this way of public debt, especially in the Mediterranean Member States, it is impossible in the long term for the euro area to survive.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – The terrorist attacks on Paris have led to the latvian presidency being transformed into a horizontal priority, something that must always be at the heart of the Union's action: the defence of European values. The Presidency has also prioritised the resolution of the PNR dossier, which I find most debatable. It should be recalled that, over the past few years, the EU has been adopting various instruments to combat terrorism. In particular since 2001, we have paid particular attention to this phenomenon. In particular with the strengthening of Europol, cooperation mechanisms between police officers or the development of the new Schengen Information System. In addition to the various proposals already under discussion, the Latvian Presidency has prioritised the review of the European internal security strategy, which will identify the challenges, principles and guidelines within the European Union. I hope that the Presidency will maintain a balanced approach and not question, in the name of security, the value it seeks to protect: Freedom. If, in the name of the fight against terrorism, we agree to limit our freedoms, we will be granting terrorists the victory they dream of: destroying our societies and the values that define us.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the Latvian Presidency programme and appreciate the attention paid to the field of food safety. We are sure that the European Union needs a review of food safety regulations. We need clear rules to prevent unpleasant situations where certain producers are falsely accused of violating European rules in the field. The conclusive example is that of Romania. In January 2013, producers in my country were unfairly involved in the scandal of mislabelling horsemeat products. It is unfair for honest producers to suffer from the mistakes or ill-will sins of rogue commercial agents. Regulations and procedures should be designed in such a way that the perpetrators are identified as quickly as possible, without any collateral damage. With regard to increasing the competitiveness of European agriculture and creating new jobs in this area, I believe that greater attention should be paid to small farms, family farms, up to 10 hectares, which constitute a good part of the agricultural area cultivated mainly in Eastern Europe.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Mr President, first of all congratulations to Latvia, one of the smallest EU Member States, which has been entrusted – for the first time – with the great honour and responsibility to lead the Union for the next six months. I am pleased to see that the Presidency is pursuing a significant agenda in the field of employment and social affairs. As a priority, Latvia should set as a goal to call on the Member States struggling with high unemployment to implement, as a matter of urgency, structural reforms in their labour markets to improve the situation, with a specific focus on young people. Another aim should be to further facilitate labour mobility in the EU. Latvia should aim to conclude an agreement with the European Parliament on EURES regulation (the EU job search portal) as part of this wider objective. This should be accompanied by a Presidency-led communication campaign to inform the European citizens about their rights as well as job opportunities in the other Member States. Paldies!

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – I am in the 'fortunate' position that, as Hungary representative of the Baltic State, I do not have to explain the problem of energy dependency, the importance of alternative purchasing opportunities and infrastructure building. Although energy security is not directly included in the three official objectives of the Latvian Presidency, one of the key to creating a competitive European Union is the development of competitive energy sources and a single integrated energy market. I am concerned about how cumbersome and slow our energy targets are: the target date for achieving the single energy market was 2014 – we now see clearly that this has not been fully achieved. The implementation of the third energy package as soon as possible is essential for the full integration of markets. The other difficult area is the one-voiced voice to external partners. Addressing the situation in Ukraine is a challenge for the European Union, which is why it is of the utmost importance to build appropriate coordination protocols and practices. I see that swift action is needed, both for competitiveness aspects and for security of supply considerations. That is why I look forward to discussing the Energy Union dossier in the coming months.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the acknowledgement by the Latvian Prime Minister of the need for greater transparency in the TTIP negotiation, in recognition of the growing public interest in this proposed EU/US trade deal. In my view it is crucial that TTIP does not limit the ability of the Scottish Parliament to organise public services in the way that best fits the needs of the people of Scotland. This applies most of all to health services. TTIP must not be allowed to impede the Scottish Government’s freedom to manage healthcare in Scotland. In a broader sense TTIP must not curtail the ability of the Scottish Parliament to bring public services back into the public domain if that is the democratic will of the Scottish people, and to manage them in the way the Scottish people see fit. If these criteria are not met then the treaty would clearly be undemocratic. This will be of particular importance within areas such as procurement which could be too easily overlooked, particularly the promotion of local economic activity and local supply of food to public institutions like schools. I would not support TTIP if public services and local democracy were to be undermined.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The priorities of the Latvian Presidency touch from a strategic point of view on the most important areas of development of the European Union. Focusing on ensuring the competitiveness of our economy and the stability of the internal market is definitely the right decision. In the face of the terrible turbulence resulting from the Russian embargo on agricultural products originating in the Member States, it is the internal market of the Community that is facing the biggest challenges. I very warmly hope that the Latvian Presidency will give agricultural matters the highest priority. The efficient use of natural resources and simplification in the implementation of the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy are also important issues to which Latvia intends to devote a great deal of attention to the meetings of the Agriculture and Fisheries Council. There is no doubt that ensuring the Union's food and energy security is the basis for further action. It also welcomes the development of the Neighbourhood Policy and the strengthening of the Eastern Partnership, as well as the promises to restore the counter-terrorism directive to the calendar. The Latvian Presidency of the Council of the EU is quite special, due to the change in the position of President of the European Council, the new composition of the Commission, as well as the current developments in Europe and its immediate neighbourhood. I hope that cooperation with the eu's most important institutions will be effective and that Latvia's priorities on key issues will guide the Council's work in such a way that the next six months will bring a great deal of good to Europe and its people.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to thank the Presidency for taking into account the aspects of people with disabilities in the field of disability, and in particular in dealing with disasters and natural disasters– and I would just like to refer here to the High and Professional Presidency event at the beginning of the year, where elements of the DRR (Disaster Risk Reduction) were discussed from a disability point of view. This issue is important not only because the European Parliament has already been active in relation to the 112 number, but also because the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) prioritises this issue. In Europe, heat and floods are the main cause of catastrophic conditions in the face of Asia (earthquakes and tsunamis), but our Asian partners are ahead in strategic planning and thinking and it is worth learning from them. That is why I welcome the fact that it is planning a high-level meeting on disability at the end of the work of the current Presidency, and I hope that progress can already be made on this issue.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that the Latvian Presidency intends to strengthen the important role of education and training in promoting economic growth, investment and citizens' well-being. These are very important declarations in the context of the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and the implementation of the Juncker Investment Plan. The programme also lists an overview of the implementation of the Bologna Process as part of the meeting of higher education ministers in Eritrea. The involvement of the Presidency in the proper preparation of this meeting is crucial for the further development of the Bologna Process and for the creation of a knowledge-based Europe. It should be noted that although the changes resulting from this process are mainly taking place in universities, this initiative is largely political in nature. It is an attempt to develop a common response to problems in most countries, including m.in. youth unemployment, inadequate adaptation of education systems to the labour market or barriers to mobility.  For these reasons, among other things, the Bologna Process and the European Higher Education Area have a key role to play in creating a Knowledge and Innovation-based Union economy, stimulating investment, strengthening employment and building a European identity. There is an urgent need to continue and consolidate the Bologna Process, identify new challenges and lines of action, increase its funding, emphasise the social dimension and focus on preparing graduates for the labour market.

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: Writing. Relations between the European Parliament and the United States Congress are long-standing and intense. That is why two interparliamentary meetings are held each year between representatives of The Congress and members of the Delegation for Relations with the United States of the European Parliament, of which I am chairman. In December, we agreed with the American side to put the strengthening of security and defence cooperation at the heart of discussions within the next interparliamentary meeting. The American co-presidency of the Transatlantic Legislative Dialogue is very interested in this meeting taking place in Riga. There are two reasons for this: on the one hand, transatlantic relations consist not only of economic and trade policy but also of a common defence and security policy. In the light of the very current challenges, a meeting in Riga is therefore a good place to be. The second important topic of the meeting will be energy security. Since the Latvian Presidency has set itself the priority of the 'establishment of an Energy Union', this is also a good fit in terms of content. The symbolic value of a joint meeting between MEPs from Washington and Strasbourg and the EU Presidency will be important in the European and global context. I would ask the Latvian Presidency to contribute to the success of the interparliamentary meeting and to participate in the political discussions.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. – The new Latvian Presidency of the Council aims to focus its activity on the major proposals to be presented by the European Commission in the first half of 2015, especially with regard to the new Investment Plan, the Digital Single Market or the creation of the Energy Union. I believe that it is time to move towards full integration of the digital market, which will allow us to achieve important efficiency gains. Around €260 billion a year and a GDP increase of 4% by 2020 is at stake. I would also like to point out that particular attention should be paid to the Iberian Peninsula in the context of the creation of the Energy Union, as Portugal has the capacity to produce renewable energy that it can export to the whole of Europe if the necessary interconnections are established.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. – The recent tragic events in Paris draw our attention to a significant and still-neglected segment of European integration: the co-existence of majority and minority nations. Minorities contribute to the diversity of the European Union. National minorities make up 8%, immigrant minorities up to 6% of the EU population. These numbers are not insignificant. We generally understand the diversity of the EU as being between Member States, but the cultural and national identity of the Member States would not be the same without the co-existence with minorities. An effective and well-balanced minority protection system serves as a tool of integration rather than disintegration. Traditional and new minorities, however, have different needs and need different protection systems. The EU citizens who belong to national minorities need attention at EU level. They should get the feeling that their existence is not neglected by Brussels. Therefore I expect steps in this direction from the EU during the Latvian Presidency. It is high time to accept European minimum standards for the protection of traditional national minorities. It is also high time to rethink the effectiveness of our policies with regard to immigrant communities.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Latvia, as President-in-Office of the European Union, has the opportunity to take a long step forward in the further development of the EU's Eastern Partnership. For the EU Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga in May, all EU Member States should ratify the association agreements with Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia so that they can enter into full force. The EU Eastern Partnership summit must also move forward with the introduction of visa liberalisation for Ukraine and Georgia, as was the case with Moldova last year. The Latvian Presidency also needs to find concrete ways of deepening relations with azerbaijan, Armenia and Belarus, the three other Eastern Partnership countries. Relations with central Asian countries, where Latvia has been active so far, also need to be closer. So it's good to move on from this surface. The Latvian Presidency of the EU will be successful in this area and in other areas. Latvia has done a lot of its own in recent years , coming out of economic difficulties, meeting the criteria for joining the euro and become a candidate country for the OECD.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writting. –  A competitive Europe also means Europe with secure and reliable energy supplies.
