The main objective is the competitiveness of the Community economy. The instrument for this purpose is foreign trade. A polite request that we also have this in the spectrum of these main principles and directions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR). -
text: Mr. President, there are several crisis hot spots in the world today where the European Union wants to engage more strongly as a mediator and insurer of stability and peace. But active conflict resolution, while noble and necessary, also poses a security threat, as those dissatisfied with the solution increasingly come after European citizens to punish them for what they see as the omission or bad intention of European politics.  Therefore, I believe that in parallel with a more active role in world crises, a better security policy must go on our soil. I believe, first of all, that cooperation between competent national authorities and security forces should be raised to the highest possible level in order to detect and address the potential threat more quickly and efficiently.  It will be crucial to maximise the system for information sharing between Member States and with third countries, which are genuinely fighting terrorism. Performing together against this global sleuth simply has no alternative. (Speaker agreed to answer the question "blue card" (Article 149(8) of the E.S. regulation)).

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – It is very important to increase intelligence cooperation and it is very important to prepare for further terrorist attacks, but the most important thing is to prepare for the causes of terrorism. One excuse, at least for many of those who have carried out terrorism, is the Conflict in the Middle East, which you intervened in. Do you think that it is precisely the Palestinian question that should be resolved in order to lay the foundations for terrorism?

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Sometimes large countries, for personal interests, play with the lives of other small countries. I think what is happening now in Syria is precisely the result of playing great states through the fate of small nations. I believe that Israel and Palestine must sit down on their own and try to solve problems. We can't solve someone's problems if they don't want to solve them themselves.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the High Representative made a very good introduction, calling for the recovery of European identity. I very much hope, Ms Mogherini, that this new spirit of change which has emerged from the Paris demonstrations might be transferred into practical actions, so we look forward to your determined leadership on security and defence matters. I would like you to focus among other things on cyber-defence capabilities. I expect the Commission to urge Member States to develop their respective cyber-defence strategies and to coordinate them in doing so, using the European Defence Agency to create joint EU cyber-defence potential. However, the fundamental issue for any practical progress on security and defence methods is the economic basis. The first victims of the economic crisis were defence budgets, and while Russia has been modernising its army and has increased military expenditure to 4.5% of GDP – and the same is true for China – the figure in most EU Member States has plummeted far below 2%. There is no way to avoid or postpone systematic recovery of the EU’s defence capability. One problem that the European Council in June this year needs to address is the practical application of Treaty Article 42(7) – the mutual defence clause – especially in the new security situation. Could it be used also in case of cyber-attacks against vital strategic infrastructures? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: "blue card" question. "Sir, you have just said that the European Union must regain its identity. I can understand that view, even if it seems a bit abstract. But to illustrate this opinion, you quoted the demonstrations of January 11 in Paris and here I do not understand you. I do not see how you can link these Demonstrations in Paris to a problem of European identity since, very officially, the 4 million French people who marched all over France wanted to do a republican march. They therefore invoked the French Republic and they also invoked national unity.  I ask you if you do not think that this event has nothing to do with the European Union and that, on the contrary, it may be showing a distrust of the Union?

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – We are speaking about European identity – it is not EU identity only. It is based upon a common European cultural heritage, our tradition, our culture and first of all, spirit of solidarity. I think the Paris demonstrations took place in the spirit of solidarity, not regarding anyone or anybody.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, allow me to begin by thanking the High Representative for her work and the efforts that she is making and for the report that she has given here to this House. Europe faces many security challenges - a frozen conflict in our eastern neighbourhood, crises in the Middle East and North Africa, and the global threat of terrorism as recently seen in France, Pakistan and Syria. An effective European security and defence policy is therefore crucial for our citizens’ welfare. The tragic terrorist attack in Paris has affected us all. Our response should not lead to losing our core values. This will hand victory to extremists. Instead, we need to push for a coordinated and comprehensive global response in dealing with terrorism. We need to deal with some of the long-standing disputes in the world, such as Palestine and Kashmir, with better security cooperation internally and externally, education – as extremists thrive on ignorance – and the need to show responsible leadership to counter the narrative of extremism.

name: David McAllister (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to underline to Mrs Mogherini three aspects which, in my opinion, have not been addressed yet and are important to ensure a successful common foreign and security policy. Firstly, the European Union, as we all know, is especially powerful in its immediate neighbourhood. Therefore it is necessary to strengthen the EU’s set of external instruments. The European Neighbourhood Policy should combine a long-term structural engagement with better instruments for a short-term impact. Secondly, the European Union should have a key role in terms of strengthening the Eastern Partnership, on the one hand, and maintaining the dialogue with Russia on the other. With regard to the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga, which will take place in May, I welcome the fact that the Latvian Presidency has announced a more individual approach towards the countries in the EU’s Eastern Neighbourhood, since we all know that one size does not fit all. Thirdly, and finally, I believe that accession countries need to align their foreign and security policy with the EU acquis. We should be very clear on this and call for implementation in all areas. This includes decisions introducing restrictive measures against Russia as long as they are necessary.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, a strong focus on our neighbourhood and the Middle East is undoubtedly important, but objectives can be compromised by being absent in other regions. I am concerned that, regarding Asia – home to half the world’s population – it is left to the US and Russia to set the agenda. We saw an illustration of this just this week in India. High-ranking global players from across the world were there at the Gujarat Summit. Meanwhile the EU was not. President Obama is visiting India once again, for the second time. So would you agree, High Representative, that it is an urgent issue that we resurrect the EU-India Summit? Otherwise we will disappear from Delhi’s radar. Our absence in India, China and Asian states is short-changing our businesses and citizens. Failing to increase engagement with these countries would equal failing to deliver growth, high social standards, stability and progress on tackling climate change. I hope that in 2015 we will finally connect the dots and adopt a proactive Asia strategy in which these countries are approached as real and equal partners.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Dear High Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The intention of today's debate is, above all, for MEPs to express their views on the implementation of the common foreign, security and defence policy. For this reason, I will only point to a few points. Firstly, I do not share those views in which the rivalry between civil rights, European security or economic matters is being built. In my opinion, we have a tercet of values in which conformity and equality matter of fundamental value. This is why I am of the opinion that there is a need to build a single system covering the whole of Europe for the control of the movement of air passengers. Let us remember that by extending the guarantees of citizens' security, we strengthen and make their citizens' rights real. Secondly, my assessment of the NATO Summit in Wales is ambivalent. On the one hand, it seemed that the preparations would end in poor results, on the other hand, as a result of the Ukrainian crisis there was a mobilization, and there was undoubtedly no disaster. Today, however, the most important thing is that political arrangements are translated efficiently into purely military language and decisions. I have the impression that political will, determination and full consent are simply lacking in this matter. I regard the personal chairmanship of the High Representative of the Defence Committee as a good sign of these possible successes. Thirdly, I am a great opponent of duplication of decision-making centres in security structures, the establishment of new institutions, the building of alternative steering centres or the resolution of redefined security problems by successive ad hoc agendas. The EU Treaty is sufficient to benefit from it.

name: Boris Zala (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the security challenges we face are probability greater than at any point in the EU’s history. The gravest is the threat of radical Islamic terrorism. After the tragedy in Paris, we are hearing proposals to weaken the Schengen regime. In my view, that would be a huge step backwards. Instead of reinstating border checks and undermining one of the EU’s fundamental freedoms, we need closer coordination among our security and law enforcement agencies. Instead of gathering ever greater amounts of data and undermining civil liberties, we need more effective, intelligence sharing to connect the dots from the information we already collect. We also need stronger institutional structures at EU level. I believe that Europe needs its own common intelligence service, as proposed last year by our esteemed colleague, former Commissioner Reding.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Firstly, I welcome your holistic, fundamental approach. Secondly, I support your self-image of being the foreign minister of a superpower for peace, dialogue, respect and diplomatic solutions. Thirdly, however, I believe that success depends on whether the European Union becomes a political union that can unite the states of Europe into a common foreign, security and defence union. Fourthly, success also depends on whether we provide sufficient financial resources for EU missions, whether we are finally changing the public procurement system for EU missions and whether the European Procurement Agency can coordinate all changes in national defence policies and ensure that they are adequately equipped. Fifthly, I share your view that foreign, security and defence policy starts at home. None of us are neutral. Each of us is jointly responsible. On the one hand, however, this means that anyone who violates European law, internally, weakens us in foreign policy, and everyone who opposes a common foreign, security and defence policy undermines your self-image of representing a superpower of peace. You have Parliament and my delegation at your side.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 'A common defence policy designed to support a common foreign policy presupposes that the Member States identify common interests: there can be no common foreign policy without a common analysis instrument; but a common foreign policy cannot even exist without a common will", these are the words of a great European, Leo Tindemans, who unfortunately left us last month, taken from his report of 30 April 1998 on the progressive establishment of a common defence policy of the European Union. Even today, this phrase retains its value intact, and the countless situations and crises that would require an urgent redefinition of European political priorities and its methods of action in the field of the common foreign and security policy have already been mentioned in this House. However, the knot of common will remains to be resolved, a subject that has been taken up several times in his speeches by our resigning President of the Italian Republic, Giorgio Napolitano, a will that still seems insufficient in our capitals. The aim is to achieve this will, we are taking advantage of the leadership capacity shown in recent months by the High Representative. In conclusion, I would like to point out that the Programme of the Latvian Presidency has stressed the need to make progress on the European battle groups. That is why we need a new legal basis from Article 42.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I am very pleased that the European Union has become an economic superpower. The fact that we are all together an economic superpower is, in my opinion, proof of collective success and collective perspective. And within this set the opportunities are more for smaller countries, which would otherwise go unnoticed or could be sidelined. For example, if we were not an economic superpower, countries such as Ireland, Portugal, Greece, Cyprus would have trouble meeting their financing needs to avoid bankruptcy after 2008. Also the fact that we are economically strong affects our relations with Russia. There is this difference of opinion on the Ukraine issue, but I think that Russia, after the fall in the international oil price, which has caused, among other things, the fall in its national currency, the ruble, and the passage of its economy into recession, will at some point want to stop funding a policy that puts it at odds with us. But I think we need to work better to get strategic depth in our policy. In other words, why not fund the control and restriction of illegal immigration? The French media broadcast that, after the dramatic events of Paris, consumption is falling, the psychology of the world is changing. In other words, there are malfunctions and economic costs. Therefore, it is better to cover an account together, to find common policies together to prevent problems in each country individually.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, Vice-President, thank you, High Representative Mogerini for fully presenting your priorities, and I would like to thank my colleague Pierre Vimont for contributing the past five years to the work of the European External Action Service and the foreign policy of the European Union.  It seems to me that after Paris, the issue of internal security becomes as important as the global positioning of the European Union in line with the priorities defined in the work programme of the new Commission and in line with the mission entrusted to you by Commission President Juncker. It seems to me that it is crucial that we strengthen foreign policy credibility over the next five years. As one of the European Union's foreign policy portfolios of sorts from the point of view of the European Parliament and head of the Delegation for Ukraine, I will endeavour to ensure that our joint activity is coordinated and coherent and that we deliver results that will lead to peace and stability for the country that is in our greatest focus.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! Mrs Mogherini, I very much liked your explanation of why we need a common foreign and security policy. It is the defence of fundamental values and our identity. I would encourage you to repeat this term, the superpower for peace and freedom, again and again. This must be remembered in the minds, even if the opponents of Europe do not like to hear it. I believe that you also receive a great deal of public support for the defence of freedom and peace, including in the United Kingdom. Well, you said that the challenges are complex and we need a whole package of measures. We are not a military power, we are a civilian power. We have instruments that we can use. In the fight against terrorism, citizens expect security. There is also the question: are we well equipped, do we have enough instruments to protect ourselves from terrorism, as far as the intelligence services are concerned, including european persecution by the European Public Prosecutor's Office? These issues, I believe, should be on your agenda.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, there are undoubtedly many challenges facing the European Commission and the European Parliament in the common foreign and security policy. One of the biggest of these, of course, is the full-scale war being waged against the European Union by various jihadist Islamist groups, which are located in the Countries of the Middle East, in the Horn of Africa, in the very heart of Europe. This foreign policy must be based on exchanges and intelligence sharing. The common security policy must be strengthened, because with these groups, with this way of asymmetric warfare, we can fight where it is born - not on the streets of Paris, but where it departs. She left Nigeria with Boko Haram, she left Somalia with al-Shabab, she left Islamic State, she left Hamas in Palestine.  Let's not forget the role of countries that support terrorism, and here an important issue that no one has put in the chamber is Turkey's role in supporting Islamic State, in the transfer of illegal immigrants and refugees to the territory of the European Union.  This needs to be done and this should be our common foreign policy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, the Paris tragedy has rocked Europe. The Paris tragedy has also in some way united Europe. We were all in solidarity with the French people, we all showed unity and it is good that european leaders were together and held hands in Paris because this is also a proof of European solidarity and European togetherness.  What I want to highlight as one dimension that has not been talked about here is that many leaders of Islam, many Muslims stood in solidarity with us in Europe and share our European values. I think that dimension is very important. Mufti Zagreb condemned this crime, but also offered something else - he offered a way of functioning Islam and Catholicism as it is in Croatia, in a country that is a well-known Catholic country to a large extent but Islam and Catholicism in Croatia function well.  Maybe we have good models in Europe.

name: Milan Zver (PPE). -
text: The European Union needs a new European security strategy. We need a proactive and not a reactional foreign and security policy. Free movement within the European Union remains a priority, but on the other hand we must do everything in our power to prevent terrorist attacks like the one in Paris. In order to ensure greater security for the citizens of the European Union, we need to tighten controls on external borders, improve the exchange of information between intelligence agencies and other organisations on fighters abroad, terrorist networks and air transport passengers. We also need closer cooperation with internet providers in order to quickly remove records of incitement to hatred and terrorism as quickly as possible. I am in favour of a European investigation order, which should solve problems in cases of obtaining information and evidence in cross-border cases.  I am also in favour of member states increasing their defence capacity, investing more in it, but also in ingothing in positions when it comes to Eastern politics.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, Rule 162 on the catch-the-eye procedure: for the second time today we have had speakers from groups; no EFDD speaker has been allowed. I asked an hour and a half ago for a ‘catch the eye’. I would just like some justification as to why we are not being allowed to speak.

name: President. -
text: You are the only speaker from your group. You had a blue card before, and there are so many speakers – I see that Ana Gomes wants to speak as well, and she did not even have a blue card before, so I have to make a choice. I have way too many speakers under the catch-the-eye procedure. I apologise if you do not get to speak this time round; there are a number of debates that will follow. I hope you will have a chance.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. - Mr President, this is quite a strange exercise for me. Among many positive and very nice things said, which I appreciate as the encouragement is always useful, I have heard some of you saying that there is little clarity in our foreign security and defence policy and that we should learn from some of criticism of the past. I understand that this is a debate also on the report on choices that have been made since the last Parliamentary debate on this, which was actually before this formation of Parliament and, if I am not wrong, that debate was in April last year. It is clear that I cannot – and indeed it would not be fair for me to – make an assessment or evaluation on a report on choices that were taken before I became High Representative/Vice-President of the Commission. (Here again I would invite the European Parliament to refer to me using the term that is mentioned in the Treaties. I am sorry if I mention this from time to time, but I think we have to respect the Treaties in these little things). This does not mean that I do not have an opinion on previous choices or previous policies: the ones that were done and the ones that were not done or not taken. This only means that I am in the first two months of my mandate and concentrating on the things that need to be done for the future, obviously starting from an assessment of what were our weak points or what needs to be completed. In this respect your opinion counts; your opinion, the opinion of Ministers on the Council side and the opinion of the Commission on the other. But from my side it would not be fair to pretend that in two months I can make an assessment of things that were done in the previous months or years or plan for the next five years in a complete and exhaustive way. But what I can do here is say what I intend to do over the coming months and make sure that we check that regularly with common discussions like this one, and also identify some of the basic lines – as I am trying to do. Starting from one basic point: Mr Brok, the Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, mentioned the fact that dealing with the foreign security and defence policy is not only a matter of security but also a matter of values and of economic interest and interests at large. I would start from there. I think that anyone who is dealing with national foreign policy knows that you start from the analysis of the national interest, and I think we need to take this European interest as our starting point for developing our strategy. However, the exercise of developing a fully-fledged strategy is not something we can do in a couple of hours in this Parliament, even if this Parliament has a lot of knowledge about that. We need to take our time. I will reach out to the external community and also involve not only the European Parliament but also national parliaments and national foreign and security dimensions. That is why, to those of you that asked me: ‘what is the role of the European Parliament going to be in defining what I intend to launch as a foreign security policy strategy?’ I can say that I intend to launch a wide, deep and open process – not writing a document or drafting documents together but having a common reflection together. If we have to define our European interest as the basis of our common strategy, we need to have a broad and comprehensive debate. Therefore, be sure that we will be coming back to this issue so often in the months and probably years to come that we might even be bored of it. But I personally will never be. A point was raised by a Member of Parliament – who is not here anymore – mentioning the picture which is going round the social media these days of the leaders, not only of Europe but also leaders of the world, in Paris, which does not show the people behind them. I have seen that picture as well. I would never stand here saying that the European Union or European Union institutions or leaderships are perfect; neither is this Parliament. But our job is to fill the gap between the thousands of people that were in the streets and that picture. That was the big strength of not only Europe, but Europe and the European capacity to reach out to alliances in the world. The power of that picture was not the number of people behind the first row; it was the complexity, the mix of the people in the front row. There were Europeans, big countries, small countries, different countries, people that are used to fighting each other on different issues in different fights, African leaders, Arab leaders, international organisations, regional organisations: the mix. The power of that picture was the sense of an alliance of civilisations, and that was what I think the people in Paris, the European people were applauding: the capacity of the European Union and of France to take an approach which was an alliance and not a clash of civilisations. I think that this is giving us the responsibility to build on this promise of going in that direction. As regards a point that was mentioned by many of you: others’ stability, security, democracy and respect of human rights is also our stability, security, democracy and respect of human rights. We are so much interlinked; we discussed that on Libya yesterday. Some were saying that we should just stay out. No way; we are interlinked so much. There is no other way of assuring our own security, stability and prosperity if we do not work also on the security, stability and prosperity of our common region and also of people that are far away from us. But I will return to that. I would start, for sure, with the neighbourhood. Engage and work together, whether in the south or Tunisia – but also in Iraq. I take the point raised that there is no structured EU presence in Erbil, and let me tell this Chamber that I am going to propose that we do have an organised permanent presence as the European Union in Erbil. I think we have to be present; it is not a matter of flags – although it sometimes can be a matter of flags – but it is a matter of being able to do the job in the most effective way. We have to be in all parts of the neighbourhood where our work and our investment is needed – not only in the interest of our neighbours, but also in our own interest. That is true as regards the south; it is also very true as regards the east. Like some of you, I was also a bit surprised by the fact that the conflict in the east of Ukraine was not as high on the agenda of the discussion that we had today as I would have expected it to be. I think it is probably because we have another point later in the afternoon specifically on that. I would refer to that more in depth during that discussion, but let me say here as regards the conflict in Ukraine and the support that we have to build for Ukraine and for Ukrainian internal reforms and success, that I believe it is going to be a crucial part of the success or failure of our foreign and security policy, and that the Riga Summit – that some of you asked about – is going to be one of the crucial elements next month for redefining our relations with the Eastern partners on a tailor-made approach. We are going through a revision of our European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), and you can be sure that we will have an exchange with the European Parliament, together with Commissioner Hahn, on the ways in which we are reviewing the policy as such. Let me also mention, while we are talking about the neighbourhood, that yes, I completely share what some of you said about the Western Balkans. This is one of the areas where the added value of the European Union cannot be substituted by any other actor in the world. Therefore, Bosnia and Herzegovina and also other countries of the Western Balkans are going to be one of the key priorities, I would say the starting point. My generation grew up thinking that it would be impossible to have peace in the Western Balkans. Now we almost forget to mention the Weston Balkans because it is so quiet – everything is relative. But this is also a positive encouraging sign; if we work, day by day and consistently, with all our means on a mediation and stabilisation process and on the prospect of European integration, we will be successful in stabilising societies and institutions. Some invited me to choose – the Member is not here any more, sorry about that – between continuing to work on visibility everywhere, maybe in competition with Member States or other organisations, and selecting only a few priorities where we do really bring added value. Obviously we have a number one task, which is to do our job in our part of the world because, like the Western Balkans, this is the place where we are not replaceable. But on the other hand, I think it would be a strategic mistake if we thought that this is an alternative compared to being also present in other parts of the world. Latin America was mentioned; I would mention Africa. India and Asia in general were mentioned; China, I think, also was mentioned. We cannot choose, because on the one hand we have to pay maximum attention to the places where we bring added value – and that is to me clearly our neighbourhood. At the same time, we also have to be present and invest in our relations with the rest of the world, whether Latin America, the African Union – I am going to be there in a couple of weeks – or Africa in general and some key places in Africa. This also relates very much to our security. Now we look at the Arab World, but do not forget that a lot of our security is linked to the security in the Horn of Africa and in the sub-Sahel region. And if we consider that the economy is also part of our foreign policy strategy, how could we forget Asia? Human rights are also a basic part of our foreign policy strategy, so how could we forget some big countries in Asia or elsewhere in the world? I think we do not have the luxury of choosing. We have to do all. Someone said – and he is still here in the room, thank you – that we are surrounded by a set of crises and the clear thing today, hopefully to everybody, is that none of them can possibly be solved by one Member State alone, or by a group of Member States. I fully subscribe to this, and I think that now the awareness is there. The point is, also from my side, to develop a capacity of not looking at the two things as contradictory. I completely agree with one of you in this Chamber who said that the European Union’s beauty is its diversity. I fully agree, but we should never fall into the trap of thinking that diversity contradicts unity, because our strength is being united in our diversity. There are ways of coordinating our common foreign and security policy without overlapping with national interests, because so much of the national interest today coincides with the European interest. This is what I think we need to understand. I have been a national government minister myself, and I know that national priorities in most cases can only be reached through European coordination and European means. This is true on both foreign policy and defence. I thank those who raised it. The French in particular will excuse me if I say so, but I think we understand each other in this room. We somehow have to take the opportunity presented to us by the shock of what happened in Paris last week to understand that we have to move and to wake up as regards sharing and increasing our common work in two areas: intelligence and defence. If we do not do it now, it means that we do not understand what is happening in the world. Sharing intelligence is something on which I will ask this Parliament to support me in asking Member States to do more generously; not because it is in the interests of the European Union, but because it is in the interests of their own citizens to share intelligence and to invest and share on defence. Many questions were asked regarding the June European Council. We have started to work with the European Defence Agency. I agree with those who mentioned that we need to have concrete deliverables on many issues, starting from industrial ones and the four major projects that were decided to be followed-up on at the June European Council – the air-to-air refuelling, drones, cyber security and satellite communication – but also in general on innovation, dual-use research and fiscal and financial incentives for defence cooperation. This is something about which the European Defence Agency has already started to put concrete proposals on the table for the Ministers. There are also other important things like ‘train and equip’ projects to support partners’ capacity in crisis management. We need to have some extremely concrete and precise deliverables in the June European Council. That is important not only for our security but also for our economy and for our industries. We also have other things to do at the level of defence. You asked about the defence budget. This is a sensible debate, which in the European Union as such has not taken place. We had that debate in NATO and different organisations, with which I am starting to coordinate very closely, because I believe that we are different; we have a different mission, we have a different identity and a different membership. But we need to work together on security in a complementary way: we have our differences, but still we have to work very closely together. But this issue of national defence budgets has not been an issue in itself for a European agenda, and I believe that it should be an issue for the June European Council debate. The target set at the NATO Summit was 2%. I would say that an additional reflection on the defence budget is not only the amount of money, it is also – and mainly, I would say – the way in which the money is spent, and in this regard European common defence projects can be very helpful, because the output in defence counts more than the input, because what we really are looking for is projects that work. But I think that we will have to look at that also at the European Council in June. When I mentioned a superpower, I did not expect such a reaction to it. First of all it is not a dream. Somebody said: ‘instead of dreaming of being a superpower’. You know we already are one. Do not necessarily link superpower only to the military; I believe that we can also be a hard-power superpower. But take soft power or take other fields of foreign policy: we are the first donor in the world. In development we are already a superpower. In many other things; in climate change we are leading. We are a superpower. On diplomacy, we Europeans have the largest network of diplomatic presence in the world. On many other things – on presence on the ground – in many places, if you put together the European Union and the Member States, we are certainly the superpower in the world. But a giant that is not aware of being a giant is not a giant but a dwarf. This is the exercise that we have to do – to realise what instruments and power we have and to use them, because having a superpower and not using it is a waste. In this world really we cannot waste any of the opportunities that we have. I think I will finish here by mentioning one element: the white paper on defence. I am concentrating more on defence, because I realise that was an aspect on which I talked less in the beginning, so I am trying to catch up. I think the main point today is to develop the security and foreign policy strategy. It has taken more than ten years, and someone said either we were very successful or we were late. I guess we are late. Not only has the region changed, but Europe has changed. After 11 years we have instruments, and we are ourselves completely different from 2003. I think we need to do this exercise first, also because first you define the scenario, the work, your objectives and your European interest, and then you go to the instruments. But this could also lead to a white paper on defence – why not? It could be. But I think that now we have to engage first in an exercise of defining. I said that by June I would present the assessment of the global security challenges that are facing us, and then I think together – together with the European Parliament but also with national parliaments and with the foreign and security community in the European Union at large, including the Member States – we will need to define our foreign policy and security strategy. But I do not exclude that this could also lead to working on a white paper on defence at a later stage. I thank you very much and I am looking forward to the next debate.

name: President. -
text: This has been a very useful debate, giving life to Article 36 of the Treaty. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Enrique Calvet Chambon (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The current situation shows that the fight against terrorist fanaticism requires a new strengthened position from Europe as a global defence agent. As Europeanists we must admit the need to speed up the march in order to achieve a common defence.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. – The terror attacks in Paris exposed failure in countering terrorism, which has much to do with the lack of Europe: lack of cooperation in ‘human intelligence’, lack of integrated policies to prevent radicalisation of young people, not to mention the austerity policies which fuel unemployment, social marginalisation and alienation – fields where terrorist organisations recruit. Some Member States bear more responsibility than others for blocking EU cooperation under CFSP and CSDP – including for double standards and grave mistakes in external action which feed the narrative of terrorists – just think of Gaza! In Iraqi Kurdistan where four of us, Members of this Parliament, were last week, many people expressed their grief over the Paris terror, which they saw as linked to the suffering Iraqis are daily enduring at the hands of ISIS. And they did not fail to note that those we call ‘foreign fighters’ are indeed European young people: over 3 000 of them in ISIS ranks, massacring non-Sunni Muslims and Yazidi, Christian, Shabbak, Kurdish and other minorities in Iraq and Syria! We have a collective responsibility and must work together and act strategically and coherently in fighting terrorism. That is why we desperately need CFSP and CSDP.

name: Eduard-Raul Hellvig (PPE)
text: in writing. – We are in the midst of an asymmetric war, in which the safety of European citizens is threatened by human bombs prepared by terrorist groups. The common danger requires a common response. The EU urgently needs a coordinated anti-terrorist strategy between Member States. The Paris attacks are a blow against European security and the edifice of values that are the foundation of democracy. In the face of this serious threat, it is necessary to tighten and appropriate anti-terrorist legislation to the challenges of the new Jihad, caused by citizens of European states, indoctrinated and trained on Islamist fronts for attacks on EU soil. It is inadmissible that Islamist propaganda and the free movement of terrorism suspects, to and from bases in the Middle East, continue to endanger the life and freedom of European citizens. Drastic measures are needed against those who opt to join the ranks of terrorist organizations. Terrorist status is incompatible with that of a European citizen. I also believe that a common strategy is needed, at European level, to stop the spread of fanaticism and terrorist messages, in particular through the Internet and places of worship.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The attacks on French soil must not go unanswered. Clearly, the tools of our security and defence policy have not enabled us to take the measure, nor to face the dangers to which we Europeans are now exposed outside and now, within our own borders. To do this, we urgently need to identify our strategic and capacity weaknesses if we are to implement a truly effective security and defence policy. It is no longer a choice but a duty. If we are to protect our borders, our values and our fellow citizens, we must have an operational common military apparatus, put an end to the senseless cuts in our defence budgets, revise the common financing mechanism for our military operations and finally come to speak with one voice to the rest of the world. Enhanced police and intelligence cooperation and the establishment of a European NRL will also be essential to ensure the effectiveness and coherence of our joint action. Only then will we rise to the security challenges that lie ahead. Let's not wait for another drama to react!

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We all agree there can be no peace without justice and diplomacy, and this also applies to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, where decades of armed struggle and on-off peace talks have simply failed. Signing the Rome Statute opens up Palestinian territory to future International Criminal Court  (ICC) investigations. This is a situation that Israel and its allies, including the UK, fought a long and intense behind-the-scenes battle to avoid – forgetting that the decision not only sets the stage for filing a war crimes case against Israel for its actions in Gaza but also exposes Palestinians to prosecution. The Palestinians will themselves be judged by this court.  Surely, if the EU is committed to actively promoting the widest participation in the ICC, we should be backing the right of the Palestinian people to seek justice through accession to treaties and international organisations, and not discouraging them from doing so. If we, the union of European nations, continue to fail to act and to support Palestinians’ campaign to join international organisations, then the Arab-Israeli conflict will remain a thorn in the side of the Middle East, causing suffering and destruction that will continue throughout the remainder of this parliamentary term and many more to come.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. - The terrorist attack in France on the editorial board of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo last week is a dark stain on security policy within the EU. The question is how to ensure a higher level of security. In the days after the attack, initiatives for decisive action in the fight against terrorism are being 2016. At the same time, a thorough consideration is needed. We have democracy, values and principles that take care of the well-being of all Europeans. Security is one of the key conditions for development, education, economic growth, jobs and investment. And that is precisely why it is necessary to review whether security, defence and foreign policy are appropriate or whether they need to be amended and elaborated to ensure a higher level of security. However, this needs to be done in a thoughtful and coordinated manner, with the definition of a strategy for the future. However, care must be taken not to fall into the trap. This trap means that, in the name of greater security, we would increase the power of control over the movement and travel of citizens. We cannot provide for greater security by restricting human rights and freedoms. It is precisely excessive control and unbridled and uncontrolled data collection that can lead to counter-effects and increase the risk of terrorism. I therefore call for common sense in the measures that will follow to raise the sense of security among Europeans.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is discussing a new security policy today, given the absolutely abominable terrorist attack that took place in Paris. In the European context, it is the duty of the European institutions to move to the stage of concrete action, in the light of the new terrorist threats coming from the territory of the Member States themselves. We are now talking about an internal threat that requires extremely close, coherent and effective cooperation between all 28 states. With Romania having the largest external border of the EU in Eastern Europe, Schengen membership, postponed for political and in no way technical reasons, becomes crucial. Security measures need to be increased at the EU's external borders and movements within these borders of persons belonging to terrorist organisations need to be further monitored. Romania's accession to Schengen can only add expertise in preventing and combating terrorist activities in the EU. Romania's accession to Schengen becomes, in these circumstances, beneficial not only to Romanian citizens and Romanian companies, but to the entire European Union. With an active conflict on the EU's eastern border, Romania's, the safety of all Europeans would increase if this border became the Schengen border.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the recent atrocities in northern Nigeria (2015/2520 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, the violence by Boko Haram in the north-east of Nigeria is becoming daily more extreme and more threatening to the region. I would like to thank you for having this debate today: I think it is crucial that, as well as discussing our own security threats, we do not lose sight of what is happening in relation to major terrorist threats in other parts of the world. This is also very much part of our counter-terrorist communication strategy. In the last few months alone, hundreds of innocent civilians have been killed, more kidnapped and thousands displaced. The attack on the border town of Baga last week is only the latest in a long series of attacks and bombings, and increasingly frequent attacks into Cameroon demonstrate that the threat is regional and is becoming even more so. The objective is increasingly to spread terror and gain territorial control, with the indiscriminate targeting of everybody – Christians, Muslims, traditional and religious leaders, teachers, students, farmers, market traders, villagers, women and children. But I would highlight in particular the attack on Christians and the attack on girls, especially girls studying, who are a strong symbol of change in their own societies. The numbers are frightening: around 13 000 killed since 2009 – more than half of this number in the course of 2014. There are 1.5 million internally-displaced people in Nigeria, 155 000 refugees in Niger, 37 000 in Cameroon and 11 000 in Chad, putting stress on local communities and potentially creating further conflicts. The breakdown of administration and law and order in wide areas of north-east Nigeria will also make the holding of elections in these three states increasingly difficult. The EU is committed – and will probably need to be even more committed – to supporting these countries in the struggle against Boko Haram. The question is: what can we effectively do in the short term and in the long term? Whatever we do, we need to do it in close cooperation with the countries affected. In the short term there must be an effective military and humanitarian response to the crisis. The countries of the region have undertaken to create a Multinational Joint Task Force, which has not yet been mobilised. The EU is willing to help support the coordination of this force and is already providing EUR 10 million in counter-terrorism assistance to the Office of the Nigerian National Security Advisor. The EU Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection department (ECHO) is also providing what humanitarian help it can to the refugees and displaced. In the medium term, it is crucial that the people of these states also have the prospect of development and jobs and a government that can protect them and respond to their needs. To win this war, the ‘hearts and minds’ of the populations affected have to be won, otherwise our efforts, including at security level, will not achieve their target. And rules of engagement have to be respected by the security forces. This is the message we conveyed at the last Ministerial Dialogue with Nigeria in November, when we invited Nigeria to speed up the implementation of the planned actions and to reinforce respect for human rights so that the European Union and its Member States can join forces with local initiatives in a more concrete and effective way.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Mr. President, High Representative, while the attention of our European and world public focused primarily on the barbaric attack in Paris, in Nigeria Boko Haram literally razed the place baga. That is why I would like to repeat the words of Nigerian Catholic Archbishop Ignatius Kaiga here and quote: "I see a very positive response from the French Government after the killing of French citizens. It is necessary for such a spirit to spread further, not only when it comes to attacks in Europe, but when it happens in Nigeria, Niger, Cameroon or other poorer countries. We need to mobilise international resources to stand up to those who have caused so much pain to so many families." Colleagues, it is normal for us to react more strongly when something is happening in our continent. We can and must be proud of the solidarity of the people and citizens of all Europe with the victims in Paris. But our values are universal and therefore we must show active solidarity towards the victims of Islamic radicalism in Nigeria. Two thousand people were massacred by Boko Haram in the town of Baga. It's time to say Je suis Baga aussi. Because the attack on Baga is also an attack on our values, Boko Haram establishes a caliphate in the north of Nigeria and becomes a global threat such as jihadists in Syria, Iraq or Libya.  Finally, one of my observations as a member of the Development Committee: we must adapt our development cooperation to the new priorities of counterterrorism and radicalism, because let's not kid ourselves, Boko Haram is making so much progress among other things because on the other hand the weak institutions of the Nigerian state and endemic corruption. Therefore, building effective institutions and fighting corruption are a key goal that we must achieve through European development aid policy.

name: Norbert Neuser
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has The victims of the attacks in France have rightly received our attention and sympathy in recent days. We said this with "Je suis Charlie". I missed a slogan: "Nous sommes nigériens" . That would have been a good thing if it had expressed Europe-wide and global sympathy. The people there deserve it. Are we powerless to face all the terrorist activities throughout sub-Saharan Africa – from Mauritania to Mali, Niger, Chad, Nigeria, Kenya, Somalia? It is essential that we demand the political elites in these countries, and especially in Nigeria. Member States have helped to train security forces in Nigeria, but to no avail. On the contrary! The security forces operate partly without democratic legitimacy, without control, without pressure for justification. This, too, is part of the truth when we look at the causes of the emergence of Boko Haram and other terrorist groups. We need to see how we fight corruption in Nigeria in particular. In the last ten years alone, EUR 80 million has disappeared in the gas and oil industry – money that this country desperately needs to establish fair conditions. We have a political leadership elite that enriches itself – just like the military, as well as businessmen – while at the same time absolute, extreme poverty. What we can do, in particular, is to give greater support to the non-governmental organisations that exist in Nigeria, which are good, in civil society, in the judiciary and in the media.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – At the beginning of this week, the Archbishop of Jos, Ignatius Kaigama, complained about the 'ignorance, ignorance of the West about the real danger posed by Boko Haram'. And the Archbishop wondered where the West's solidarity with Nigeria, which is so bloody, is suffering from persistent Islamist terror waves? And you also talked about it, High Representative. On Monday, the same day, nigeria's defense minister announced that his army is losing the war against Boko Haram. Only an international coalition, he says, can offer a military solution. That's what you talked about, about the immediate surroundings. And that while Nigeria's immediate neighbours – Niger, Chad and Cameroon– are also not a party on the ground, militarily, or want to be for Boko Haram.  You spoke, High Representative, about humanitarian and military response. I hold my heart when you look at the dangerous destabilization of this region around Nigeria. I hope that there will be a really strong European response, because it looks very sad. And we are also talking about the connections that there are between the Nigerian army and Boko Haram.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, High Representative, colleagues, the horrific violence of jihadist terrorism came awfully close to home last week, when Charlie Hebdo journalists were slaughtered and when people who were doing something as innocent as buying groceries were targeted because of their Jewish identity. Open diverse societies threaten the misguided dogma of violent Islamism. Therefore, we must be even more resilient in defending that openness. Not only do these extremists select symbols of freedom of expression – a universal human right – but in Nigeria, girls’ education or any education at all is the prime target of Boco Haram, which literally means ‘forbidden book’ or ‘Western education is forbidden’. Forcing people to adhere to one’s ideology with such extreme violence is the clearest sign of weakness imaginable. Back in 2011, when I was an observer to the presidential elections in Nigeria, volunteers of the Youth Service Corps were killed in terrorist attacks. The Youth Service Corps actively volunteered to help run the elections, and as such the attack marked an attack on all sons and daughters of Nigeria. This week, by using a child as a suicide bomber, new levels of barbarism and a lack of humanity have been shown. We condemn these attacks in the strongest possible terms and send our condolences to the families of the victims. It is important in Europe that we are fully aware of the global nature of the jihadist terror, in which perpetrators and victims come from all corners of the world. It is also important to recognise that in Nigeria the impact of terrorism has become the rule rather than the exception. We must play an active role to end the brutalities and eliminate IS, Al-Qaeda, Boco Haram and their affiliated networks.

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it has been a devastating week in Nigeria, with fatalities on an absolutely horrific scale, and our thoughts are obviously with those who are bereaved and who are caught up in the violence. The atrocities that were committed by Boko Haram in Baga are utterly deplorable and, in fact, border on the unimaginable. More than 2 000 people were murdered over the course of a number of days, and the government and state security forces were simply unfit to intervene to save them. It has to be noted – as has already been said – that the Nigerian state is not exempt from responsibility for the recent escalations through a series of deplorable human rights abuses. Amnesty International, for example, believes that at least 950 suspected members of Boko Haram died as a result of overcrowding, starvation, brutality and extrajudicial executions while in state custody in Nigeria in the first half of 2013 alone. Having said that, nothing could possible excuse the actions of Boko Haram. To strap a bomb to a child and detonate it is a vile, indefensible act that has shocked probably even the most seasoned of conflict observers. So there is now a moral responsibility on us all to show the same outrage and invest the same resources in addressing the causes and consequences of these atrocities as we would if they were happening anywhere else in the world. In a week when this House rightly defended media freedom of speech, we must also state that international media organisations have a moral duty to bring the situation in Nigeria to prominent public attention in Europe and across the world, because only then will we force governments to contribute positively and in a measured manner to the quest for stability and justice in the region. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Colleague Carty, ...... (The President interrupts the speaker for technical reasons) Colleague Carty, don't you think that the inability of the authorities in Nigeria to deal with Boko Haram Islamists is the main reason for the development of Islamic terrorism there? Don't you think it is also the responsibility of these companies, which receive profits from the extraction and exploitation of natural resources in Nigeria, which is an extremely rich country? And don't you think that only a military force can crush Boko Haram terrorists, and that the world and we, the European Union, owe efforts in this direction, as we also show solidarity to the victims of terror in Europe?

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – There is a comment that you have made that I would disagree with: perhaps to say that only a military solution would address the scourge of Boco Haram. I would question that. Certainly there does need to be a security response, and yes, I believe that international companies have a responsibility. Primary responsibility lies with the Nigerian government. I believe that right across the world we need to show the same outcry – and that includes this House and the European Institutions as well as the governments of Member States – to ensure that these atrocities that we witnessed in the last week simply cannot happen and cannot go unnoticed. The reality is that there are citizens in our Member States who do not even realise that these happened only a week ago.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the least we can do this week, while we are mourning the victims of the cruel attack by terrorists against the French satirical paper, is to discuss this issue in our plenary, and I join those who deplore the lack of international attention that has been given to the case of the razing to the ground of the whole town of Baga in northern Nigeria. The minimum here is to do our best to have an independent international investigation of what actually happened because, even if the figures vary quite a lot, we can fear that up to 2 000 people have lost their lives in this indiscriminate attack. Let me point out that the Nigerian army fled when this attack happened. Nigeria is a rich country but, of course, we need to support their fight against terrorism. One means of doing that is by supporting the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), the cooperation organisation of West African countries which has reiterated its commitment to work with the government of Nigeria, the ECOWAS Member States and all stakeholders so that terrorist attacks of this kind come to an end. Let me also, at the end, point out that we still do not know what has happened to the kidnapped Chibok girls so, just as we are saying ‘Je suis Charlie’, we could say that ‘We are the Chibok girls’. And we need to get them back.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. –  Mr President, whilst much media attention has been given to the brutal massacre by extremists in Paris and Islamic states in the Middle East, another brutal, anti-Western and extreme organisation, Boko Haram, which means ‘Western education is forbidden’, has grown in power in northern Nigeria. Reliable information can be difficult to obtain out of Nigeria at the moment, but the latest suggestions are that up to 2 000 people have been killed in the latest campaign of terror, during which over 1.5 million people have had to flee the fighting. Then, of course, there is the fact that these same extremist Islamists kidnapped 276 schoolgirls in April last year, and most are still missing. It has been reported that a number have been sold on as slaves and have been forced to convert to Islam. In October, it was reported that two girls escaped captivity and made it back to their families. They said they had been held in a camp in Cameroon and raped every day. It is barbaric! Resolving this crisis will be difficult, and there are no easy answers or quick-fix solutions. What I think we can be sure of is that the European Union or the West is unlikely to be any more successful in Nigeria than we have been elsewhere in the Middle East and North Africa. What Member State governments must encourage is greater regional cooperation and a truly global response, and this can be achieved not only through the United Nations, but also through the Commonwealth. I would suggest that this free association of friendly nations with a shared language, history and culture is far better suited to exerting positive influence in this part of the world than the European Union, which has far too many of its own problems to deal with first.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Europe cannot remain ungodly in the face of the situation of terror created by Boko Haram in Nigeria. These actions outperse on the scale of terror to any other because, in many cases, their victims are helpless young people and because they use girls to commit them. The Nigerian Government, in coalition with neighbouring countries, does not have sufficient strength to deal with Boko Haram and therefore needs the support of the international community under the protection of a United Nations mandate. The ups and downs of Boko Haram's actions and other violent actions across the country are partly due to the closeness of the elections of 14 and 28 February. Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank you for appointing me head of the European Union's Election Observation Mission for this election. The team that will follow the electoral process is already in Nigeria and I will join it shortly. This mission will have different characteristics than usual, given the impossibility of being able to deploy the mission throughout the territory, for obvious security reasons. The presence of this mission demonstrates the European Union's commitment to holding inclusive, transparent and credible elections in Nigeria. We're going to conduct an analysis of the entire electoral process and not just election day. And we will be attentive to any disputes that may arise during the process and once the elections are held. And above all, forgive me for a moment, I want to call for avoid tying up violence in Nigeria.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the same day that France was hit by Islamist extremism, Nigeria was living the nightmare of thousands of victims at the hands of Boko Haram. Those who die in Africa, who die as a victim of the same war and the same ideology of death that struck europe, therefore deserve the same reaction. There are no second-class deaths! Madam President, the Europe that was in Paris on Sunday must be consistent, it must show a strong will to meet this great challenge, starting with Nigeria, precisely, before it is too late. We cannot watch the massacre of thousands of people helpily! Europe must promote and lead an international task force, with the involvement of the United Nations and existing regional bodies, capable of putting in place long-term, structural responses.  Combating terrorism, Madam President, also means eradicating the root causes that led to its birth; it means combating illiteracy, inequality, underdevelopment, corruption and the misappropriation of the proceeds from the exploitation of natural resources; it means offering hope to a people by protecting democratic institutions and stimulating political participation. I would remind you that we are only a few weeks away from the presidential elections in Nigeria. It means giving children a future as vile instruments of war! Finally, an appeal to the leaders of the African democratic states: have the courage to make your countries the centre of the world, as happened in Paris. Some of the leaders – as Mr Mogherini also mentioned – were present in Paris on 11 January. Open the door to peaceful and democratic protest against all forms of violence against human rights! We will be there to say: I am Africa, I am Baga! (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI)
text: Blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to ask Mrs Kyenge, she makes all this important speech about Nigeria, but I want to show her a photograph: in your opinion, this gentleman – who is the iman of London – who says that those who speak of Muhammad must die. What do you think, you should not be arrested immediately, if Europe existed, and as far as I am concerned, someone like this, who also looks like a goat, should be destroyed, must not be an iman, nor in London, what do you think?

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this question is inappropriate, we must not confuse the sick Islamist ideology with our democratic values, and I believe that we must not be misled by this question in order to put ourselves on the same level. We are not afraid of anyone and we are able to decide, according to freedom of expression, according to our values, what is good for our society and what must be removed as cancer from a sick body.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, the problem is practical, not theoretical. We can talk about structural reforms in Nigeria that will take years. But right now, between Baga and the Tumu Pass on the Libyan-Nigerine border there is a day and a half on the way. The great drug, terrorist and weapons corridor is a day and a half on the way.  Nigeria's armies are ineffective because they are corrupt. Niger's is ineffective because he's small. Cameroon's almost non-existent in practice. The only valid one is Chad's. And the only chance of s stoping crime is with democratic violence, with the need to stop crime on the ground. And that is only possible with European forces that are able to form, assist and seal borders. Are we going to do more than rhetorical statements to reassure ourselves, or are we going to implement a practical, military, field policy in collaboration, of course, with the countries concerned?

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, we are talking here about Africa’s largest economy; it is a country that is major provider of peace-keeping forces within Africa. As people have been saying, we know it is grossly unequal; we know about the corruption; we know that a lot of the money does not reach the grass roots; we know that there is still a high level of poverty, inequality, children who do not get educated. I think that makes the attacks on the schools – the misogynistic attacks on girls – even more distressing. There has also been a lot of criticism in Nigeria about the current President’s response: he has sent condolences to Paris but he has said nothing on Baga. We know that it is difficult to get information; we know that Boko Haram have taken out communications systems, but nevertheless we would also hope that the government of Nigeria also steps up and really takes this seriously and openly. There are many people who will not be able to vote in the elections on 14 February – I was an observer last time – because they are displaced, they are refugees. We really need international support and action to change this. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Do you share my concerns over the lack of compliance with convention as regards the Nigerian Constitution, which previously saw the Presidency rotating between the north and the south, and of course this has gone out of the window with the election of President Jonathan? Would you like to see, and would you support me in seeking, a return to that revolving Presidency again?

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think the issue about the revolving presidency is one for the Nigerians themselves to sort out. You will be aware that Goodluck Jonathan himself will say that he was only elected once into that role and has the right to stand. What I would like to see is a much more democratic process in terms of the election – I am pleased we have an observation mission there – so that people can actually cast their votes and be sure that their votes mean what they put in the ballot box. But whoever is the president afterwards – whether it is Mr Buhari, whether it is Goodluck Jonathan again, whoever else – we hope that they really do get to grips with this problem rather than trying to pretend that it does not exist.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D). -
text: Madam President, a girl under the age of ten blew up a bomb in her body at a market in Nigeria's Borno state. He destroyed many lives, and so was his. We couldn't talk about Paris and not talk about Nigeria. But what is it in Nigeria? What does Nigeria need to fight this murderous madness of Boko Haram? What are our chances of actually and urgently helping Nigeria? They're killing girls and women, they're using markets as space for violence. It is a symbol of what this murderous thought—if we can call it thought—is intended to do with the civilian population. We need political intelligence, Mrs. Mogherini. Fast, urgent, materialized in measures. And may the European Union be present in the search for a possible life in that country, the largest in Africa, the most populous and the richest.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D). -
text: Sur President, Sinjura Vi大i President, Massakru minsi - hedge iddeskrivietu l-midja, il-qtil ta' elfejn tal-Boko Haram f'Baga. Dan hu attakk viljakk ieħor tal-Boko Haram. Min jista' jinsa t-tfajliet li nħatfu minn skola, u li sal-lum ħadd i jaf x'sar minnhom? Massakru ta' 2,000 ruħ; tfal, nisa u xjuħ, li i setgħux jiġru biżżejjed biex jaħarbu l-mewt. Dan m'huwiex biss theddid għan-Niġerja, imma wkoll għall-Afrika u l-Ewropa. Attività terroristika m'hemmx biss fl-Afrika. Fil-Pakistan, it-Taliban qed ukoll jagħmlu ħerba mit-tfal tal-iskola, filwaqt li t-traġedja ta' Charlie Hebdo ġabet it-terroriżmu f'qalb l-Ewropa. U hawn tqum il-mistoqsija: Għaliex l-Ewropa injorat għal dan iż-żmien kollu l-organizzazzjonijiet terroristi大i bħall-Boko Haram? Kemm hemm bżonn imutu nies biex nirrealizzaw li t-terroriżmu sar pjaga u theddida kbira għas-sigurtà u l-pa大i internazzjonali? L-attakki riiera ħamra għall-futur. Fl-aħħar nett, trid tkun l-Ewropa li tirreaġixxi u tiġġieled b'mod sod u effettiv, biex tiddefendi l-valuri Ewropej tal-pa大i u tad-demokrazija kontra estremist u contra t-terrorist.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: The Government of Nigeria has not been able or has not wanted to halt the escalation of atrocities committed by Boko Haram that massacreentire villages, kidnap children and now, horribly, use them as human bombs. The fight against Boko Haram, as its name bears, cannot be isolated from what we have to fight against other groups of the terrorist hydra that attacked last week in Paris. And against the networks of organized crime that support terrorists.  We need to activate the Common Security and Defence Policy to assume our collective responsibilities to help the people of Nigeria, the ACP partner country, eradicate Boko Haram.  We need the CFSP to make Europe heard in the Security Council and to determine that the responsibility to protect must be urgently exercised in Nigeria, with the support of the African Union and the neighbours also affected.  Boko Haram is a threat to Africa's peace and security and global peace and security. (The speaker agrees to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – You are speaking very passionately about dealing with this evil organisation, and I share your feelings on it. The one thing that concerns me is that we have heard a lot about these discussions, and I wonder whether you would agree with me that, if we are talking about projecting the EU into this scenario, there is a danger that there will be some comeback. Surely stronger border controls with sensible, fair rules would stop there being more comeback on our streets?

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Do you know that many of the people who are stranded in Libya trying to reach Europe’s shores have come all the way from Nigeria to escape this kind of phenomenon? I share Ms Mogherini’s view that this is all linked. And if we think that we can conceal ourselves and protect ourselves in Fortress Europe, instead of trying to go and help those who are our partners and who are fighting the same terrorist hydra that creates a lot of problems inside Europe but also for our partners, we will be doomed.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2009 Boko Haram announced the founding of the Islamic caliphate in Nigeria, today 70% of Borno is in its hands and elections will take place next month, but we all know that over one and a half million displaced people will not be able to vote and that the cards have not yet been delivered. The Nigerian Government is inefficient and the national army is powerless and is asking the international community for help, but it is silent.  Last year, ten thousand people were killed and on 3 January Amnesty denounced the massacre of two thousand people, and on the very day of the Demonstration in Paris, girls stuffed with explosives were detonated precisely as weapons of war and used for this unkn knowingly. What are we still witnessing? What are we waiting for? Baga is only the beginning, now Boko Haram could aim for total control of Africa's most populous state and a thriving economy and then extend, why not, to the borders of Chad or Cameroon. Europe does not leave Nigeria alone, it is not enough just to write Je suis Charlie!

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would first like to express my absolute condemnation of any attack, any terrorist action and, of course, my solidarity with the victims and the countries concerned. Today we are dealing with the subject of Boko Haram. Yesterday the attacks in Paris. On too many occasions, in too many places, we regret the use of violence to defend different causes.  Kapucinski wrote that in the world they were going to threaten three plagues. The first is the plague of nationalism; the second, the plague of racism; and the third, the plague of religious fundamentalism. All three have the same trait, a common denominator: irrationality. An aggressive, almighty and total irrationality. And Boko Haram is one of those irrational fundamentalist groups. An ignorant irrationality that is surprised by concepts such as freedom, democracy or human rights. We have not been able to prevent the emergence of Boko Haram, but we can prevent new adherents. We can prevent new terrorist organizations. There has been talk here about short-term strategies, how to fight, but there is an inevitable long-term strategy that is education. Only with education will we wipe out the violent. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You talk about ‘we’. Would it not be better to have a regional solution to this tragedy that is happening in West Africa? Would it not be better to leave this to the Commonwealth and to the African Union, rather than let our opponents use this opportunity to talk about further Western intervention?

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Madam President, I believe that we can help. Clearly, one of the values of the European Union is to defend democracy wherever it is needed and to help our friendly regions move that democracy forward. I do not believe that, as a European Union, we can look the other way and I do not think we can let Nigeria be worthwhile on its own and try to fight terrorism. Honestly, I think the European Union has to be where it's needed.

name: József Nagy (PPE). -
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I took part in the big protest in Paris last week, I'm Charlie too! I am, Charlie, condemning all forms of violence. Europe must come together against insanity! But I'm not just Charlie, I'm Baga! The Baga, which was leveled with the ground by terrorists in Nigeria on 8 January, leaving behind thousands of casualties. Boko Haram in Nigeria already controls 70% of Nigeria, and they fanatically persecute anything they think is in com-match with the teachings of Islam. We can't keep quiet! Because he is complicit with sinners who are silent! Boko Haram's atrocity will not be solved on its own, the people of Nigeria need us! Europe can return the Nobel Prize for Peace by sitting back and watching the violence taking place. Let's find, please, the means to stop the carnage.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Madam President, we condemn the atrocities and recent massacres in Baga, northern Nigeria. Religious fanaticism leads the Islamist group Boko Haram to extremes every day.
