This expands the jihadists' territory in Africa and creates a new Muslim caliphate this time in Africa, from the city of Guzau to the Cameroonian border. At the same time, conflicts in northern Nigeria are increasing migration flows to southern European countries and Greece, where thousands of refugees and migrants are coming through Turkey. Mrs Mogherini, Turkey has become the main route through which thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants cross into Greece and the rest of Europe. Instead of restricting migration flows through its territory, it eventually facilitates them. At the same time, Turkey does not implement the agreement to re-enter illegal immigrants on its territory. Finally, Turkey has shown no decisive stance against the Muslim caliphate in Syria. Is it random? I don't think so.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for Nigeria, 2015 should have been a year of political debates, projects and hopes to be fulfilled in the run-up to the legislative and presidential elections in February. Instead, there are those who campaign with bullets and machetes. In the city of Baga this year, thousands of people will not vote and not for abstention, but because they no longer have a life to do so and now lie in a mass grave or on the street like a lot of rubbish.  Why is this happening? Because there is also a copious illegal trafficking in weapons from libya's warehouses to Chad and Niger, because Boko Haram certainly does not manufacture them in the forests! A few days ago, we saw millions of people, in Paris and around the world, marching, that march should also have been for the dead in Nigeria, for those in the Mediterranean and for so many other forgotten cemeteries! And not just for those at Charlie Hebdo! My condolences go out to all those families.  Je suis Charlie, je suis Ahmed, je suis Nigérian et beaucoup d'autres. Je ne suis pas hypocrite.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Madam High Representative, i would like to thank you for your excellent work The situation in Nigeria is increasingly dramatic. More than 2 000 people have been killed by Boko Haram in recent days and the European Union must respond as soon as possible. Presidential and parliamentary elections will be held this year to further reveal the weakness of government institutions. The people of this country should be prepared for the increase in Boko Haram activity. Boko Haram attacks villages, small towns. Terrorists kill everyone. This was the case in the city of Bago, which was attacked by Islamists last week. After the city there were only ruins. We can already talk about the civil war in Nigeria today. As one bago resident wrote on Twitter, "how do I feel safe when our authorities condemn the Paris attacks and do nothing, they don't even give real details about the number of casualties in my city. Maybe my life means nothing to them." That is why the European Union must react decisively, because the people of Nigeria are deprived of a strong government, medical care and a strong army and administration that can defend them from terrorists.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR). -
text: I thank Mrs Mogherini for mentioning Christians when she mentioned this tragedy in Baga. I would like to thank you all the more because, two days ago in this House, Its President Martin Schulz mentioned that he also sympathizes with the two thousand victims in Baga, but when he enumerated the types of intolerance and ideology of discrimination that threaten us today, he refused to mention anti-Christian hatred. However, silence about anti-Christian hatred is in itself an act of anti-Christian contempt, and I therefore appeal to the President: do not remain silent! At least let you speak! Courage!

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. - Madam President, I completely agree. Thank you very much for this chance because on Sunday, while we were marching in Paris, I was also thinking, exactly as many of you here, that it was not only hypocritical but also counterproductive not to say or do anything about what was happening – apparently many kilometres from Paris but really very close to Paris – because, as almost all of you said, these two things and many other things are so closely interlinked that we cannot be under any illusion that we can solve one problem without also tackling the others. That is why I know we do not solve the problems of the world with statements. I have to say that I have a certain negative reaction whenever I am asked to make a statement on everything. But in some cases a statement is symbolic; and I decided that a statement on that day had to be my statement, and not a spokesperson’s statement, because we have to speak and act with the same strength and with the same coherence, whether in Paris or in Nigeria. At the same time I agree very much with what many of you have said about the fact that we need to act on different levels. It is not only, obviously, the first reaction, the point about the security of the people in Nigeria and the rights of the people, starting with girls in Nigeria. It is also a matter of creating an environment which makes it less probable or possible for this phenomenon to arise, so that the people of Nigeria and the surrounding countries have a proper future and a proper present in their countries and in their lives. I believe that this is something that, for sure, we have to do. I said at the beginning what we are already doing, whether on the security side or on the humanitarian side or on the development side. I welcome your invitation to do more. You can be certain that I will come with something more, probably more with the foreign ministers than in other formats, especially when it comes to the security aspect. But let me underline what many of you said about the need to do this in a framework which is not an EU framework only. We need to work very much with the region, with the African Union, with the UN framework. We need to work in a coordinated way. I would like to thank very much Mr Fisas Ayxelà for his important role in leading the electoral mission in the coming days and weeks. Let me also take this opportunity to say how much I value not only parliamentary diplomacy, but also the work we do through our observer mission for elections. I think this is a crucial part of our diplomatic and foreign policy job, and this is thanks to the dedication and professionalism of many of you who dedicate so much energy, time and effort to this exercise. Let me thank you for this, as I will be thanking, hopefully personally, all of you for similar exercises – not similar, because this is a crucial one – and I am looking forward to your report on that.

name: La Présidente. -
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place in February. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 3 January 2015 the bloodiest attack in the history of the Boko Haram terrorist group took place, killing 2,000 people in Nigeria, most of them women, children or elderly people who could not escape, in an attack against Baga, near the border with Chad. It is known that Boko Haram is an extremist Islamist group that believes education and books should be banned, killing more than 10,000 people last year alone. Nigeria's president, Goodluck Jonathan, who expressed his opinion on the Paris attacks, did not comment on the atrocities in his own country. Even if Nigeria prepares for next month's presidential and parliamentary elections, I think it is unimaginable to want to maintain your image, to the detriment of peace and security, and the fight against terrorism becomes virtually impossible. I believe it necessary for European states with economic interests in the area to have a constructive and effective dialogue with the Nigerian authorities in order to fight terrorism and to respect the fundamental rights of citizens. It is also important that the Western media has access to sources of information precisely so that these atrocities are brought to the attention of the international world in order to be condemned and to provide the necessary support to be combated.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today more than ever the European Union must act in the face of the jihadist threat, in any form, and find ways to eradicate this terrible scourge, but we must not only look this way, within our borders, but also where jihadism has been acting, interning and expanding for years. Nigeria is one of these cases. Boko Haram's attacks are indiscriminate, abominable and repulsive, resulting in the killing of more than 10,000 people during 2014. I welcome the address of this issue at the next Regional Security Conference in Niamey on 20 January. The Union must engage firmly with Nigeria in the fight against Boko Haram, supporting the strengthening of the State and its institutions, including the military, and developing an effective development cooperation policy that reduces the country's fragility. This week more than ever "we are all Charlie" but please, I ask you not to forget to ask strongly for "bring back our girls".

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. – It is a sad reality that we live in a world marked by escalating levels of violence by religious extremists. With the recent massacre of over 150 people by Boko Haram in the town of Baga last week, there is no worse example of this scourge on the global landscape than Nigeria. And this is not new – my colleague Bastian Belder and I have already raised awareness of these atrocities. However, if the dastardly attacks in Paris tell us anything, it is that we in Europe should not ignore this intolerance, or simply hope that, in times ahead, it remains in some foreign land. The EU has a duty to act. It has a duty to act to stop the radicalisation of children as young as 10 for use as suicide bombers. It has a duty to act to protect those most vulnerable to persecution: women, young people and religious minorities, including Christians. Most importantly, it has a duty to act to protect the belief that fundamental freedoms of religion, expression and speech are stronger than any terrorist bomb or bullet.

name: La Présidente. -
text: The agenda calls for debate on the statement of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Ukraine (2014/2965 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. - I am grateful for the invitation to discuss the situation in Ukraine at a moment that is particularly important. I was wondering whether there were any moments that were not particularly important in relation to the situation in Ukraine in the last 11, 12 or 13 months, and there were probably not. But this gives me the chance to report to you in plenary about the work that is going on at my level and also about my recent visit to Ukraine. I visited Kiev on 16 and 17 December 2014, almost one month ago. My messages there, which I also had the chance to share with the European Council on my way back, were about the European Union’s full support for the full and swift implementation of the Minsk Protocol and Memorandum, the need for a credible process of reforms to deliver on public expectations for an improved way of governance, and the EU’s readiness to support and assist this process. A year back, you would probably not have expected that Ukraine would now have a new president, a new parliament and a new government. This is to say that we have to give credit for the positive developments that the Ukrainians have managed in these difficult months. I will come back, obviously, to the situation in the east of the country, but let me concentrate first – as the Ukrainian leadership that I met in December did – on the internal situation of Ukraine. We now have a relatively new leadership in place: a new government, parliament and president fully committed not only to a process to resolve the situation in the east but also to the core, necessary reforms in the country. The Ukrainian reforms are crucial, first of all, in terms of responding to the high expectations and aspirations of the Ukrainian people, who expressed those aspirations very clearly in the last two elections. Meeting especially with civil society organisations and NGOs and activists in Kiev, I found it interesting to listen to how their focus was very much on delivering internal changes. There are systemic issues that need to be addressed, including corruption, constitutional reform and decentralisation. Here, apart from the work that the European Union can do, there is a lot that the Council of Europe and the Venice Commission can do to assist in judicial reform, energy sector reform, electoral reform and reform of the business climate. Again, meeting with our 28 Member States’ Ambassadors to Ukraine, I was impressed by the common indication from all 28 Ambassadors in Kiev that, on the one hand, they supported financial assistance but, on the other, that they recognised the need to create a business environment that enables private investment to continue, or to return to Ukraine, in an effective way. The list of reforms is long and obviously very difficult, but Ukraine will find – and is already finding – support for these reforms on our side. Last week the Commission proposed a third macro-financial assistance programme for EUR 1.8 billion. This is an additional sign of the EU’s solidarity with Ukraine and also part of a bigger international effort based, of course, on conditionality principles. In the light of the very difficult financial situation that Ukraine is facing – and I remind you that this programme is not a blank check and will be strictly conditioned – I count on the European Parliament’s support to finalise this assistance. However, it is very difficult to reform while facing a conflict on your own territory, and I think that here we have two main responsibilities. The first, as I have said, is to support the internal, difficult, challenging but needed reform process inside Ukraine. The second is to work on the dramatic humanitarian impact of the conflict. This is an issue that I know is crucial for some of you, and I think that the international community, starting with the European Union, needs to do more. Support for those who have left and those who have stayed is crucial. We have been discussing this with the Ukrainian authorities because the support has to come not only from the international community but also from the authorities in Kiev, and they are willing to give it. The problem of access for humanitarian aid has to be solved. Access needs to be ensured. So far, the Union has committed EUR 32 million in humanitarian and recovery aid, and it will continue helping if our support is increased. But then there is the security situation on the ground and the political process for talks and a solution to the conflict. Let me state here again our committed and united position on the conflict, and let me also quote the Latvian Prime Minister, who said, when presenting the priorities for the Presidency this morning, that our strength is unity. It has been unity and it has to continue to be unity. I will keep this in mind not only during the debate today but also in relation to the work that we have to carry out in the coming months. Our common, agreed and shared position in the European Union is precious, and that is the need to work for a solution to the conflict in the east of the country – a sustainable solution that respects sovereignty and the territorial integrity of Ukraine. We are doing all that we can to make this process work. On 9 December 2014, President Poroshenko declared a ‘Day of Silence’, and since then, until yesterday, I have to say – and the Ukrainian authorities confirm – that the situation had been improving significantly. Yesterday, again, there were 12 victims. Let me use this opportunity to say that this must not become a trend. What happened was a dramatic, terrible event, and I hope that we can go back to the previous situation which, from the Day of Silence on 9 December until some of the breaches of the ceasefire, was relatively calmer than it had been. Commitment to the ceasefire is a necessary prerequisite for any resolution of the crisis. In recent weeks, as you know, there has been a re-intensification of the talks in different formats. On the one hand, in the Normandy format, this has created some elements of hope, but the conditions were not created for a meeting in Astana to be convened at this time. At the same time, efforts were undertaken by the Latvian Presidency. We discussed this with the Latvian Foreign Minister last week in Riga, and he paid a visit to Kiev and then to Moscow on Monday. I know that many of you will ask what the European Union’s role is here – some of you had the chance to ask me that question already in a different meeting – so let me reassure you from the beginning that what we are trying to do is to make sure that, with the Presidency format and the Normandy format, this is taking place in a framework of European Union efforts. This means that the channels of communication are not only for information but also for coordination, so that the steps which need to be taken are taken together at different levels. The Latvian Foreign Minister and the French and German Foreign Ministers are going to report back to the Foreign Affairs Council on Monday. Obviously we have been in more than close contact over these weeks – not days, but weeks. At the same time, as I said in my hearing before the European Parliament before taking office, it is time for the Union to reflect on a less reactive, and a more proactive, approach in our relations with Russia. This is why the Foreign Affairs Council on Monday will start a strategic discussion on EU-Russia relations. The question is not about going back to ‘business as usual’. It is very clear to all of us – and here again there is unity – that there is no going back to anything. On the other hand, however, we need first of all to share positions and considerations and not leave matters of political or technical dialogue to individual national considerations. We need to work in a coordinated way, and not only in relation to the instruments we have for engaging Russia on implementation of the Minsk Agreement. We have used the OSCE, we can use the Normandy format and we can use the Latvian Presidency, in a common European Union framework, and we have been engaged in discussions here, always in coordination with President Tusk and President Juncker. At the same time, we need to assess together – all 28 Member States and the Commission – all the instruments that we have for engaging Russia with positive leverage. That does not mean that we are offering something: it means that we have to be aware of all the different channels that were open, were closed, were frozen or suspended. We need to be aware of what stage we are at, on different tracks, for example with regard to foreign policy – because we do discuss with Russia issues such as the Iranian talks, Syria and the Middle East process, processes that are within the UN Security Council framework. The Americans do this, as do individual Member States, and we need a common framework for doing that in a more transparent and coherent way. When it comes to other forms of dialogue, for example at technical level – think of the efforts the European Union has made on facilitating an energy agreement between the Russian Federation and Ukraine – or in relation to other elements, we need to review where we are, at what stage we are on different aspects, and what can be used in positive or negative terms to try to influence, in the best possible way, a change in Russian behaviour on Ukraine. I will stop here, listen to your comments and then reply at the end of the debate.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, most of what we want to say is in our resolution, so I will not repeat that. I will just highlight some issues which are the most difficult, and I will speak about the part of the glass which is empty rather than the part which is full – which you described so eloquently. Firstly, why are the European Union and you, as Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, absent from the Ukrainian talks? Why is your chair empty? Why do we not have the Geneva rather than the Normandy format? The Latvian Presidency is not a substitute. It should be you there, as our Foreign Minister. Secondly, why is nothing being done with and for Ukraine under the common security and defence policy (CSDP)? We are doing for Ukraine, with our CSDP instruments, less than we are doing – with all due respect – for Somalia, military training being an example. Thirdly, why is there no major and visible EU-branded humanitarian aid to Ukraine? The sum of EUR 32 million is ridiculously small, and it is not ‘EU’ aid – it comes through intermediaries. Fourthly, why is there no information campaign to counter the Russian information war? To recall your words in the previous debate, we are not a superpower in relation to Ukraine. We are a dwarf. We are a payer, not a player. We are punching below our weight, we are having less impact than we could, and your policy on that is too timid. The EU does a lot but not enough. Often we do too little too late and in too shy a way. We are hiding behind the OSCE, UN, Red Cross and some Member States. We do not call things which happen by name. War is war, and terror is terror.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are rightly very concerned about the humanitarian situation in Ukraine. Everyday life in conflict zones is becoming unbearable for more and more people. This also applies to 600 000 refugees in their own country and another 600 000 refugees in neighbouring countries, most of them ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: La Présidente. -
text: (Addressing some members of the EPP group who are talking loudly) Gentlemen, please respect the speaker.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, let the PPE-DE discuss a little bit, they need it bitterly, and then they will also come into line. And more than 600 000 people who also need help as refugees in neighbouring countries. There is an urgent need for more humanitarian aid than has been the current need. Solidarity is demonstrated not by our speeches here in Parliament, but by action. The International Red Cross would be a quick solution, and aid must be quick, because they need it now, not in the summer. In order to really improve the situation, we are repeating today that the withdrawal of russian soldiers and mercenaries must now take place, not at some point. We call on all parties to implement the Minsk Protocol agreements without delay. I know it is not an easy time for the government in Ukraine and it has already done a lot. The elections are a positive example. And yet it is now important to advance and implement reforms independently of the conflict: among other things, to consolidate the functioning rule of law, to obtain independent justice, to carry out constitutional reform, including the necessary decentralisation, and, above all, to fight corruption.  Then the people of Ukraine will feel the difference – the difference for which they once moved to the Majdan. Our support for this is, they are safe.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the European Parliament has prepared a resolution on Ukraine. It is a very good document. I can say I subscribe to every word there is in it. But let me make three general points. First, Ukraine faces two major challenges: it has to reform itself, and it has to defend itself at the same time. It does not require a genius to know that it is extremely difficult, and without outside help it cannot succeed. Second, Russia’s behaviour is largely predictable. Whatever the effect of sanctions and oil prices, it will be following the same course in the foreseeable future. History teaches us that change in Russian politics has always resulted from the internal reshuffling of power. Third, Europe’s policy towards Russia. The problem is that we simply do not know who is running the show. Is it Mrs Merkel? Is it you, Ms Mogherini? Is it Mr Hollande, Mr Steinmeier, the Prime Minister of Latvia? Will the real negotiator stand up please? And the final point relating to the previous item on the agenda: I was shocked that you did not address the issue of the atrocities committed against Christians in Nigeria. I find it disgraceful that the EU is silent on this issue.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, one has to be objective. What has happened since Minsk? Did Russia really try to show good will? Did Russia really try to help broker peace in East Ukraine? Did Russia really try to monitor its border and prevent irregular troops and others from entering eastern Ukraine? No, that has not happened. Has there been any positive sign from Putin concerning the Crimea? None. Nothing has led to a positive outcome up till now. There will be no Astana Conference because Minsk did not produce anything substantial. I think that the sanctions should do the work, and the sanctions are working – together with the low oil prices – so the Russian economy is in trouble. I am not happy because of that, but I hope that it will hurt Putin enough to be sensible and indeed go to the negotiating table, wherever that table is, whether it is in public or in private, and produce results. Only if there are results on the ground – and that means the recognition that Ukraine is an independent nation with internationally-recognised borders – can we go further. That is what we should do now. We can try to help the people in the Donbass, and for that we can try to help Ukraine to reform. That is essential, because otherwise there will be a kind of Ukraine fatigue where people say ‘Ukraine again?’ So we should help them. It should come from Kiev itself, but the sanctions should stand and should work further, together with the economy. Putin will not listen to reason. He will probably listen to the economy.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has Since yesterday, it has been clear that the planned Astana meeting will not take place. This once again gave us the chance to talk to each other. In view of the innocent ten deaths, I find the reference to principle, to the lack of preconditions for a meeting, cynical. Ladies and gentlemen, if we are not only to speak out verbally for an immediate peace in Ukraine and its territorial integrity, we must finally put ritualised rhetoric behind us and assess processes in real terms. There will be no military solution in eastern Ukraine, and at the latest both sides, the political and military leaders in Kiev and Donbass, will have to make their contribution to peace. Whether they do that and, if not, why not, would be discussed in concrete terms. It would be a matter of debate whether Mr Yatsenyuk is really the EU's natural ally, despite his electoral legitimacy. His political credo, which he presented in Berlin these days, is: there is always only the other guilt, politically uncomfortable and his own actions are talked about beautifully in the mainstream lexic. What his government has done to date is massively frozen social benefits, mass redundancies, drastic price increases, it is a privatization program that is completely unregulated even after ukrainian media, which once again only makes oligarchs like Firtash richer and more influential. These are drastically increased military expenditures, of which 30 percent have disappeared in corrupt channels. The 2015 budget does not provide for a hryvnia for the supposedly central fight against corruption. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, have you noticed that Prime Minister Jaceniuk is the head of a democratic government who received a mandate from his people because he won the elections? He has a clear democratic mandate, he is the head of government who wants to work with us and works with us, who has worked with us. Isn't it really important to talk more respectfully about our friends and not put them on one set with the aggressor?

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I said that Mr Yatsenyuk has democratic legitimacy through the elections. The question, however, is: is he also the only point of contact for the European Union with his policy when we address the real situation in Ukraine? What happens socially? I was there, and I was told that if something changes very quickly in the social, economic fabric, in the implementation of real political reforms, we will see the next Majdan. People are hoping for change in this country. We, as the European Union, must support this.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am not saying 'dear Mr Scholz' because I think you are discussing below level. There would be no reason at all to discuss a humanitarian emergency in eastern Ukraine if Russian strategists – I do not know exactly when – had decided that they were not prepared to accept Ukraine's territorial integrity. It may not suit you, but the problem has started with the annexation of Crimea, and it has continued with the systematic destabilisation, supported by Russia, in eastern Ukraine. Unfortunately, the causes of the war in eastern Ukraine must now be sought in the Russian Government. No one, especially no German, would dare to claim today that Belgium had started shooting.  All I really ask is that you stick to the causes of the problem in the analysis of this conflict.  (Applause) Minsk, Minsk is an agreement that has been reached because the Europeans have put pressure on the Ukrainian government and on the Russian government to negotiate. The Minsk agreement is a compromise, very much in favour of those responsible for terror in eastern Ukraine. If we want to push through this compromise, which is so far the only way to pacify, which is the only way to stop the humanitarian disaster in the occupied territories, then we must stick to the concept of economic sanctions.  I am glad that you have said once again that there is unanimity in this concept of continuing to pursue policy, of relying on economic sanctions, not on a military solution. But russia needs to respond differently. That is the key to talks in Astana or no talks in Astana. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs Harms, can you tell me which strategists and when they decided to break up Iraq, break up Libya and break up Syria?

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. This is a different debate. My group – everyone will remember this – and my party has also taken to the streets against the Iraq war. The Iraq war cannot in any way be used as a legitimation for a war in eastern Ukraine. Those who have opposed the Iraq war must not be afraid to criticise and take action against the war in eastern Ukraine. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to answer another question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: Blue card question. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I fully understand Mrs Harms' objections and I certainly agree with Russia's responsibilities and the need for territorial integrity. I would just like to ask you to remember that fascist and even neo-Nazi paramilitary forces have acted and are acting in the East and the Donbass region and that the Azov battalion in particular is directly dependent on the Kiev Ministry of the Interior.

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. We have expressly pointed out in our resolution that there are indeed terrorists who have been sent to this war. There has been discussion for some time about people who are known from Chechnya. The name Girkin is now known all over the world, and the problems we have in the pacification have to do with the fact that it is very difficult to have a sensible dialogue in a region where a system of separatists, led by properly elected politicians, has not established itself, but in which a system of warlords, of Mafiosi, has been established. , established by criminals, and who are used by Russian soldiers ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer another question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Ms Harms, would you agree with me, following Ms Spinelli’s ridiculous comments, that the true fascists are the Russian aggressors? The Jewish community of the Crimea has been completely eliminated and the synagogue that has been there for 50 years has been closed down, with swastikas daubed on it by the so-called liberators from Moscow, and the Tatar community have also been put into exile. Fascism is coming from Moscow, not from Kiev, I am afraid to say. Would you agree with my statement?

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not want to deny that there are also nationalists in Ukraine. However, as far as I can see, there is not a movement in Ukraine that is committed to winning campaigns in neighbouring countries. In any case, you would have to show me that first. Ukrainian new nationalism is very much the result of the attack by Russia. I want to see a nation – Italy is famous for not being nationalist, you have right-wing movements – in Europe, which is under attack without such nationalist reactions. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Franz Obermayr (NI). -
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the President-in-A Without criticising your management and chairing, there are a few usages in this House. First of all, time should be taken into account. It's nice when you knock, but if you leave the speaker 40 seconds further the time ... The second is a nice usance: if time is already short, only to grant a "blue card" and not to allow so-called questions with "blue cards". That would be my request – with all due respect to your management.

name: La Présidente. -
text: Thank you for your advice, Mr Obermayr.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Dear colleagues, I will not be a prophet if I say that the events in Ukraine are gaining more and more dangerous momentum. A quick, wise, just, diplomatic solution is needed, which is firmly respected by all sides. Further exacerbation of the situation is a major economic problem, not only for Russia and Ukraine, but also for all other states and regions. The European Union and the international community must make every effort to achieve a peaceful solution based on the Minsk Protocol and the Memorandum. Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty must be defended, we must never recognise the illegal annexation of Crimea, but at the same time we must not promote a new Cold War and we cannot give up on provocations. The European Union's support for the newly formed Government of Ukraine and its reforms is of particular importance. There is a need to establish a specific economic assistance plan for Ukraine and to provide all financial, technical and military assistance and advice if necessary. Only a common and strong position of all the States of the European Union and of the international community can deliver positive results in defending the provisions of principle and finding wise diplomatic solutions. In defence of Ukraine, we defend Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and all other countries of the European Union. In defending Ukraine, its sovereignty, we defend Europe, we defend our homes. Could anything be more important? So let us be firm, wise and united.

name: Udo Voigt (NI). -
text: Madam President! The conflict as described here is always intensified when unilaterally sanctions are carried out instead of talking to each other. I am shocked at how much the rhetoric of the Cold War has returned here in this House. Have you not noticed that the current situation of the euro has brought the euro to its lowest level since its inception? The ruble is falling into the bottomless. Inflation in Russia was 11.5% in December, while inflation in Ukraine was 25% in December – 50 times higher than in January 2014. The sanctions adopted weaken the euro and destroy thousands of jobs in EU agriculture. But the sanctions also affect the countries of the Eurasian Economic Union: Kazakhstan, Belarus ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Elmar Brok (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her I am astonished at how congruent the arguments of the left and the NPD from Germany are when I hear Mr Scholz and Mr Voigt here. Everyone seems to be to blame for the crisis, but Russia is not. It is the case that Russia invaded and annexed a foreign country, and that the Minsk agreement is an attempt to ensure that this is managed. And since we – the European Union and NATO – do not want to go to war over Ukraine, sanctions are the instrument for telling the aggressor that aggression is expensive. This works not only because of this, but also because of the oil, etc. We are ready to talk to Russia, as the resolution clearly says. All channels should be kept open. Any format, whether Astana, Geneva or whatever, must be sought for any possibility of dialogue. However, I also think it is right that the meeting in Astana should not take place, because Russia has not made it possible for this to lead to far-reaching agreements. Such conversations of the top spires must bring results! Moreover, the Commission and the High Representative are doing a good job there, and we must state that we should continue to do so accordingly with our position, and that is why we do not want to end the sanctions unless, step by step, there is also the fulfilment and implementation of the demands of the Minsk agreement. Ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to say that we have a terrible situation in Ukraine, but also because exactly two years ago Russia began to impose trade restrictions against Ukraine in order to bring the country to its knees and to move away from free choices. The country is in difficult situations because a foreign country has invaded with its own troops. Turning a rope out of it now, that Mr Yatsenyuk has not yet made this a thriving country – Mr Scholz, you should be ashamed of yourself with such an argument! We want peace, and we want the freedom of all European peoples, and no great neighbouring peoples should have the right to impose their will on smaller peoples! This is the Europe of the future! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Brok, if we want to be constructive, do you not think that we should distinguish the fate of eastern Ukraine, for which we must negotiate and try to convince Russia, and perhaps that of Crimea, for which we have a simple problem of free determination of the right of peoples to have themselves? For finally, there was a referendum in Crimea and international law gives other precedents of countries that have achieved independence such as Kosovo.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Firstly, genocide should be avoided in Kosovo against a dictator. That is the difference. In Crimea, there were also very far-reaching autonomy rights for the Russian people, which are not available anywhere in Russia for minorities. The third point is that there have been no free elections. There was military occupied, there was not even an alternative. That is why this was not a fair referendum, but even one, as we know it, with a very low turnout. In this respect, I would ask that we do not go down this road with Crimea. I know that your party has been watching elections there and has received money from Mr Putin for its election campaign in France. This is not the basis for a serious conversation.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I should like to thank the Vice-President/High Representative for her focus on the humanitarian situation in Ukraine. As winter sets in, humanitarian access to eastern Ukraine is indeed urgent to prevent starvation and medical emergency. The evidence of it being blocked is, of course, itself a violation of international law. I ask Ms Mogherini in her reply to comment on ECHO’s role in this respect. Second, our resolution puts a proper focus on reforming Ukraine itself and endorses the reform priorities under the Association Agreement outlined in the letter from Ms Mogherini to Mr Brok. Ukraine now has responsibilities under that agreement, and it is proper for us to exercise pressure in this respect. Finally: on Russia, my group endorses the aim of a more proactive approach. As our amendment shows, de-escalation of the sanctions can follow de-escalation of the crisis because, as I had the chance to say to the Vice-President/High Representative earlier, any change in EU restrictive measures must reflect a real change in observance of or prospects for peace, not a weakening of Europe’s resolve to achieve it. I trust that the message will be understood by the foreign ministers on Monday.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR). -
text: Madam President, I have great regard for the Ukrainian people. I collect Ukrainian art, I visited Kiev in the Crimea and I am certainly no excuser of Putin’s Russia. Nevertheless, I am deeply concerned at the mess the EU has made of its intervention in Ukraine to date. Whilst I support a Ukrainian trade deal, the EU Association Agreement is nakedly political. It talks of convergence in foreign and security policy and of military cooperation. An EEAS official has even said there is a clash of geopolitical rivalries of two competing empires. The EU must exhibit its strength, and now Ukraine wants to join NATO. All this just pokes the Russian bear. This year, acclaimed US film director Oliver Stone is releasing a documentary alleging that the CIA was involved in the Maidan demonstrations. He says that so-called shooters, who killed protestors, were third-party agitators with CIA fingerprints. And this ‘Regime Change 101’, as he calls it: is it fiction or fact? I would like to know whether the EU is aware of these claims and if the EU is at all complicit.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, many colleagues have already touched upon our concerns over the humanitarian situation in Ukraine, from these terrible killings of civilians in a bus to the prospect of a frozen conflict in eastern Ukraine, so I would like to point out a different topic. It is important for Ukraine, especially in this difficult situation, to move forward with reforms. Restoring democratic legitimacy and economic growth, the adoption of anti-corruption laws and the creation of the anti-corruption bureau are steps in the right direction. But more needs to be done to restore citizens’ trust in the legal system, public authorities and democracy. Given the challenges ahead, the EU Support Group for Ukraine has a crucial role to play in identifying the areas where technical assistance is needed for the implementation of a reform programme. So I would like to ask the High Representative: is the allocation of staff and resources enough for the Support Group to fulfil its mission in Ukraine? Finally, I would like to stress that the EU should express clear opposition to lifting sanctions against Russia before clear conditions are met.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, the policy of threats, blackmail and cooperation, cooperation with far-right elements, imposed by specific European and American interests, is responsible for turning Ukraine into a social and humanitarian bomb. Today the European Parliament, Europe's supreme democratic institution, values of solidarity, freedom, democracy, equality and human rights, produces another resolution of fear. And I wonder: what policy do we produce in here? What is the positive vision and hope we give the peoples of Europe for the European acquis? The cultivation of fear, uncertainty, insecurity, Cold War politics and rhetoric? Ladies and gentlemen, in ten days' time we have elections in Greece and its people, who have been impoverished and impoverished in recent years, are threatened for their choice in the most vulgar way by the political and economic directories of the European Union itself. We here have a duty to fight to change that direction. A united Europe is a Europe of peoples and not of interests and markets.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Ukrainian crisis, yet another paradoxical episode. In this Parliament it seems that we can only be pro Poroshenko or pro Putin, black or white. Personally, we in the 5 Star Movement do not want to join the club either of them, but we would like to apply instead for that of objectivity. On the board, I see above all a clash between the superpower struggling not to lose world hegemony and an ancient superpower that has now lapsed but inflamed by the ambition to regain a global role. In middle stat Ukraine: a deeply fractured country along the South-West-North-East axis.  Russia is playing to freeze the conflict because what it could easily take by force would cost it too much in terms of geopolitical isolation and therefore aims to wear out its adversary. The US-EU axis is prey to the feverish race to the Far East, whatever the cost! For the Ukrainians, who risk economic suicide, and for us, who have never developed a real alternative energy policy. The budget seems very clear to me: we almost all lose, we Europeans, the Russians and the Ukrainians certainly lose; only the Chinese, increasingly lered by the advantage of a strategic alliance with Russia, unnaturally induced by us, and the United States that leads us towards shale gas and increased military spending, earn. That does not seem to me to be our interest, but perhaps here some people, ladies and gentlemen, think that they are not in the European Parliament but in the Third Chamber in Washington!

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI). -
text: Madam President, the situation is very complicated. I am afraid Ms Mogherini does not understand that the situations in Donetsk and in Lugansk are very different. The independence of Ukraine is a keystone of Polish politics. No responsible voice in Poland would agree on the partitioning of Ukraine – if there were such a plan – between Poland, Russia, Romania, Hungary and Belarus, because one can love Russia or hate it, but we like Russia to be as far from Polish borders as possible. Still, if Ukrainians hate Russians, from the Polish point of view that is a very good situation, because the typical stance of Ukrainians is to hate Poles, so if their sentiments are directed against Russia, that is a better situation from our point of view. The only point that annoys us is the German-Ukrainian sentiment. We do not like to be between a pro-German Ukraine and a very strong Germany. That is all.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE). -
text: Madame la Présidente, it is always difficult to intervene après M. Korwin-Mikke. I'm going to go to Romania. Mr President, on 16 September 2014, we ratified the Association Agreement with Ukraine here and I was saying that it is a historic day for this country - several colleagues shared this idea. Four months later, today, I firmly believe that Ukraine needs new such days, historical moments. And I believe that, more than ever, it is necessary to find a solution to bring peace back inside Ukraine and to stabilise the borders of this country. In these days when confrontations in the east of this country have intensified, such an agreement could prevent the situation from worsening and the increasing destabilisation of Ukraine and, by implication, Europe. That is why I believe that we have a duty to contribute to the pacification of our continent, encouraging and taking part in any dialogue that may lead to an agreement. I think any format is good to go in that direction. Beyond the thorny territorial and security issue facing Ukraine, I would also like to express my hope that the leaders in Kiev will be determined to continue the fight against corruption. President Poroshenko said last autumn that "what paralyzes Ukraine is corruption" and I hope that this is not forgotten, even though we all know that the situation ukraine is in is very difficult, but I believe that the fight against corruption, the construction of institutions that produce tangible results is a priority axis of action. That is why I encourage Ukraine to be implacable in the fight against corruption; it is an experience that we also know from other former communist states and I do not think that things can be formulated differently here.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D). -
text: Madam President, as the hacker group Cyber Berkut attacks its targets in cyberspace and their classically armed comrades threaten the country's territorial integrity, ukraine's real space needs to respond urgently to a deepening recession in the 2nd year of the war.  The economy will shrink by 6%. Last year the decline was a high of 7.5 %. The national currency of wrestling had the worst indicators in the world with a loss in value of 38%. The government in Kiev is seeking another $15 billion in aid, and some connoisseurs argue that only $50 billion would be enough for a sustainable reconstruction programme.  But Ukraine could only get these funds if it meets the well-known goals of international creditors: broadening the tax base, deregulating industry, improving the business climate and selling off state assets. In doing so, it should be prevented that extreme austerity measures do not endanger more of the population that is left without social benefits than the war itself. Because one million people have left their homes, 1,500,000 live in harsh conditions in the conflict area, and 1,700,000 children have been affected by a crisis whose end is not looming.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for This is a very important resolution of the European Parliament. It is the result of a compromise between all political groups and is important, and perhaps even historic, because it very clearly sets out the conditions that must be met in order to undo or even reduce sanctions against Russia. And this, it seems, is the dream of some politicians in Europe who think what to do to undo sanctions against Russia. Let them think about our European interest, and it is in our European interest that Ukraine be more and more a country with which we are in great relations, including economic ones. Moreover, this resolution also speaks of the economic situation in Ukraine. We are calling for reforms there, but above all we are stressing, and it is very important, that we do not recognise the self-proclaimed elections in Donetsk and Luhansk, but perhaps the most important thing is that we explicitly encourage the Member States of the European Union to ... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, a week ago the civilised world was deeply shocked by a deadly terrorist attack against journalists in Paris. Yesterday, 12 innocent civilians, including children, were killed because of a bus-shelling near Volnovakha, Donetsk Oblast. Terror attacks, from Paris to Volnovakha, are just another grim reminder of today’s reality. Terrorists have many faces, from jihadists to Talibanis, to Islamists in Northern Nigeria, and the Russian-backed and -funded bandits in eastern Ukraine. But all of them have one thing in common: hatred of Western liberties and democratic societies. We must give proper and evident recognition to an existing nest of modern terrorism in Europe: the so-called Donetsk and Lugansk People’s Republics. These are the places where terrorism and instability are breeding.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL). -
text: The official version of the European Parliament on the history of the situation in Ukraine is not right with reality.  The most distracted may seem not to it, but those who have opposed the coup in Ukraine today are being victims of violence, restriction of freedoms and rights, imposed by fascist forces that are now linked to the Ukrainian authorities and police and security forces - the officials and mercenaries. Has we not heard here of the May 2 slaughter in Odessa or the arson attacks on the opposition party's seeds, the bill that ukraine's Parliament is currently discussing to outlaw only ideologies with which it does not agree?  Has we not heard here of the murder and torture of those who opposed the authorities exiting the coup d'état?  Don't you remember the phone call from Baroness Ashton and the Estonian minister in which he warned her that the snipers would be connected to the evil maidan movement and not to Yanukovych and that she ignored it?  All this was not necessary just because they wanted to sign the Free Trade Agreement.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul It is never acceptable to change the borders of countries by means of violence. It is a fundamental principle of international law that I and my party fully support. Moreover, we are equally firmly convinced that it is always wrong to use force to unseat a legitimate and democratically elected government. We want to be clear that we are opposed to any kind of enlargement of this European project, which in all respects has its own life and is now extending its tentacles to the countries of the east. This applies regardless of whether enlargement is reflected in actual membership or some form of association agreement. With regard to the situation in Ukraine, there are many different aspects to take into account, not least from a security policy perspective. The main consideration of the Sweden Democrats is that the EU should under no circumstances be extended. This consideration is equally relevant whether the subject of enlargement is Moldova, Turkey or, as in this case, Ukraine. We are not, as some have claimed, an admirer of Putin's authoritarian Russia. On the other hand, we believe that Ukraine and its people should have the same right to self-determination as we demand that the people of Sweden should have. My question to you, Madam Vice-President, is: what do you consider to be the decisive cause of humanitarian suffering in Ukraine?

name: Nicolas Bay (NI). -
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, the Commission has made us accustomed to falling from Charybde to Scylla. Yet when you're listened to, you really don't regret Mrs. Ashton. Indeed, pragmatic, you seem to defend positions much less Atlanticist than the one that preceded you in this post.  Last Thursday, in Riga, while Europe was looking to Paris, you considered the possibility of lifting the sanctions taken by the European Union against Russia, you said, because of positive signs from Moscow. Alas, it was reported on Sunday that Canada had just delivered another forty-two containers of military equipment to Ukraine, on the eve of the Berlin meeting. According to many observers, the Ukrainian authorities are in fact only trying to buy time to better prepare a new punitive expedition in the Donbass, rather than a diplomatic solution, respectful of the people of Ukraine, which Russia is calling for. Let us therefore stop listening to the American wars and try to resolve together, between neighbours of the Old Continent, this fratricidal conflict that has lasted too long and which harms the interests of our peoples.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Mogherini, for her excellent work. Ukraine must do the impossible today: reforms must be implemented in times of war. And we need to be aware here that, by supporting Ukraine, we also support the security of the European Union. A stable and united Ukraine is a security pledge for the European Union. I am pleased with the European Commission's proposal to allocate EUR 1.8 billion to Ukraine, but the real stabilisation of Ukraine requires more help. The European People's Party therefore calls for work on the European Marshall Plan for Ukraine. Of course, this must be closely linked to targeted reforms, and I hope that this is also understood by the elected Ukrainian leaders. We must help strengthen not only Ukraine's defence capabilities, but we must help Ukraine to confront Russian propaganda. This propaganda is also directed against Europe and against our values. I expect the European Commission to propose a communication strategy that will protect European values against disinformation from hostile countries. Thank you!

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D). -
text: Consistency and unity are the key to the EU's successful engagement in Ukraine, and at this point I would like to thank Mrs Mogherini. For this reason, in the framework of the dialogue with the Kiev leadership on the country's European perspectives, on the development of the rule of law according to European standards... (The representative cancels his/her post due to a technical problem.) So we must also talk about the danger of rising nationalism. Representatives of the Ukrainian government have stated in recent weeks that they plan to introduce a series of law enforcement procedures and penalties against some of their citizens in order to enforce the law excluding dual citizenship as strictly as possible. In addition to the Russian minority, the threat or harassment is directed against members of a number of other national minorities, including many EU citizens, who need increased political protection. Although technically legal, this harsh act by the authorities is nothing more than a concession to increasing nationalist pressure. The law can only serve to increase tensions and escalate with this timing in the current domestic political situation in Ukraine. I therefore call for these aspects to be taken into account in the current discussions between the European Union and the High Representative and our friends in Kiev, in addition to the ways in which political and economic support is strengthened.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR). -
text: Last week we witnessed the terrible terror in Paris and yesterday 12 Ukrainian citizens died in Volnovakha when their bus was shot at by a Grad missile. All indications are that it was fired by pro-Russian militias. Should we not consider placing the leadership of the so-called Donetsk and Lugansk People's Republics on the list of terrorist organisations? Je suis Charlie, je suis Volnovakha. The Minsk agreement is four months old, but there is no question of peace in Ukraine. On the contrary, Russia does not seem interested in demining the conflict and continues to destabilise and provoke. For example, the way in which Russia detained the Ukrainian MEP Nadia Savchenka goes against the basic principles of international relations. And in Kaliningrad, Russia large-scale unannounced military exercises. I would like to be optimistic about the peace talks, but I am quite frankly difficult. And yet the implementation of the Minsk agreements is the only way out.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, first of all I owe the Vice-President an apology, because we are behind schedule and I have a meeting that I have to rush to. Very briefly a few remarks. Madam Vice-President, you said we need unity, and I could not agree more. The unity is to be provided primarily under your leadership. The moment we have a fragmentation of messaging, I think we will have no unity, and we will also have some Czech politicians that will be moving away from the common line. Secondly, aid: we are doing a lot and we can do more, and I think the Member States can contribute. Financial assistance is important, but it is not the alpha and omega of everything. I think that we are dealing with an administration that needs some significant support. I think we should be looking at opportunities for deploying experts, as was done in the past with acceding countries. Thirdly and lastly, you have spoken about positive leverage in the context of Russia. Donald Tusk mentioned an adequate, consistent and united strategy towards Russia. We need it, but let us not fool ourselves. We need it, but the key lies in Russia, and at the moment I see a principle of conditionality. Any move has to be conditioned by moves on the Russian side.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, let me start by thanking The High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, for her introductory speech. In my relatively short active political life, I am forced to take a position on the second war in Europe. After the first one, there was a feeling of pain and injustice in many people in the Balkans. Plus an artificial state – Kosovo – with two centers: the Pristina administration and the geopolitical one at the US military base Camp Bondsteel. What will remain in Ukraine after the Second European War of my life? How much unnecessarily spilled blood and how much resentment and what new military bases? We need a solution to the situation in Ukraine, which will start the path to the coexistence of peoples of different nations, languages and confessions. Not in the form of today's apparent victory, which will set up future conflicts. The spirit of Minsk, the cessation of hostilities, the exchange of prisoners and, last but not least, constitutional reform, is a policy that we must promote. This should also be proof that the European Union really deserves the Nobel Peace Prize.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: I would like to ask Mrs Mogherini and Parliament for a resolution on two issues. Neither is a political issue, but both are human rights issues. 1. The Russian Parliament has called on the European Parliament and other parliaments around the world to cooperate in an independent international fact-finding investigation into a series of crimes against civilians in south-eastern Ukraine. Is there anything wrong with that? The other is that in Ukraine, among other national communities, nearly 200,000 Hungarians live as indigenous national communities. There are a number of UN, Council of Europe and EU standards on the human rights of indigenous national communities. They're in my hand, I'm going to give them to you. Can they convince their Ukrainian friends that they must comply with these standards as an associated country of the EU?

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE). -
text: Madam Vice-President, thank you for your views on the main determinants of your engagement with Ukraine and I appreciate that at the beginning of your mandate you have already visited Kiev and got an immediate impression after the elections held for the new Supreme Labour, 26 October, where I had the pleasure of conducting an observation mission with other colleagues in the European Parliament and noting that these elections were conducted in accordance with high international standards.  As chairman of the parliamentary association committee between Ukraine and the European Union, I offer my condolences to the Ukrainian people and the Ukrainian authorities for the terrorist attack that took place yesterday in Volnovakha where 12 civilians, Ukrainian nationals, died. This is further proof that Ukraine is a victim of aggression and undisclosed hybrid war by Russia, so we as a European Union must firmly insist on preserving ukraine's territorial integrity, when it comes to parts of Dombas, but also, against the international law of annexed Crimea and our policy of restrictive measures towards Russia must be constant.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D). -
text: Mr President, what was really interesting about Mr Mogherini's speech was his position on Russia, which clearly outlines a new opening. I thought of willy brandt and Egon Bahr's new policy on the East, because we need something new here now. It is clear that last October the elections in Ukraine were democratic. It is possible to build a society of freedom and justice with human rights on the basis of these democratic elections. I believe that the European Union and all of us will be ready to support Ukraine when the Ukrainian Government presents a timetable for a concrete reform programme, and so on. It is possible to build a whole new policy on this. I am convinced that, under the leadership of Mr Mogherini, russia can be influenced in such a way that there too there a desire for consensus arises.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. It is Russia, a country that wants to subjugate neighbouring countries, said President Lech Kaczynski in Tbilisi Polish 2008. Less than two years later, he died in an unexplained manner in the Smolensk disaster. The free world has moved on to the agenda both over aggression in Georgia and over the Smolensk disaster, and in the opinion of me and many experts, this is when the verdict was made on Ukraine – because Russia does not retreat if it does not feel resistance, if there are no appropriate measures taken: not words, not resolutions, but decisions, real decisions. Sanctions were the right direction, but you need action, High Representative, your personal action. Not the empty chair that Mr Saryusz-Wolski spoke about, but your participation, your commitment and the commitment of the whole Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE). -
text: Ukraine's concern number one is clearly a security situation. Within 24 hours yesterday, so-called separatists in eastern Ukraine violated the truce 84 times. A tour bus was shot and more than 12 people were shot. Military activity is clearly growing again. Without the end of the conflict, the whole development of Ukraine will remain disturbed. Ending the conflict in eastern Ukraine, as well as ending the annexation of Crimea, is clearly in Russia's hands.  However, Ukraine can now and immediately begin a thorough fight against corruption and also fundamental reforms. The European Union can help here. Thus, all Eu Member States should ratify the Association Agreement as soon as possible, no later than the Riga Summit. There is also a need to move towards visa liberalisation. It is very important for the European Union to keep Ukraine open to the European perspective, knowing that the conditions for convergence with the European Union can be met by Ukraine itself.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE). -
text: Madam President, when a year ago on Maidan Square people gathered in a cold Ukrainian winter and asked that Ukraine stick to its path towards Europe, nobody in Kiev, in Brussels, in Washington or in any other European capital had any idea that a hundred people would perish in the following weeks. Nor could anybody have guessed how the coming year would look: that the situation would be that part of Ukraine is in effect occupied by Russia, and another part of Ukraine is under Russia-backed terrorist control. We were taken by surprise – twice. All of us want peace, and as soon as possible, but core principles have to be maintained. When talking about the peace process in Ukraine, Europe has to keep stressing the importance of returning Crimea to Ukraine. Europe has seen its share of frozen conflicts and difficult territorial disputes. Forty years ago, the Helsinki accords were signed by European countries for precisely that reason: to guarantee the inviolability of European borders. There can be no justification for the annexation of parts of Ukrainian territory. Europe has to be very careful about what we consider real progress in the peace process in Ukraine. The Minsk Agreement was a good step in the right direction – too bad that it is not leading to Russia withdrawing its troops. Nor is Russia ceasing its support of groups in Donetsk and Luhansk, which show every sign of being terrorist organisations. Just a few days ago, a bus full of civilian passengers was blown to bits in the Donetsk region. Twelve people were killed, 16 injured. Is there anyone who could call this progress?

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the topic of Ukraine rightly provokes strong reactions and emotion because it is leading and key to the future of both Europe and the European Union. I want to raise an issue that no one in the house today has touched on, but it is also key to the situation in Ukraine. This is the issue of the civil and political rights of national minorities within the territory of the state and the attitude of the new power towards these minorities and their rights.  It is known that on the territory of Ukraine there are German-speaking, Hungarian-speaking, Tatars and others. Among them is the Bulgarian national minority, which according to various sources number between 250 and 500 thousand people. There are reports that there have been cases of violence and human rights violations of representatives of these minorities - forced mobilization and forced participation in combat. There are civilian casualties among them. Separately, it is unacceptable that the stated intention of the new authority to abolish the use of the native languages and names of the minority population is unacceptable. The right to native language, to self-determination is a key, basic human right, and the new authorities in Kiev must unconditionally comply with it. My question to you, Commissioner, is this question being raised before the new authorities in Kiev and what is the Commission doing to protect the fundamental rights and civil liberties of national minorities, including the Bulgarian one?

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, the sovereignty, independence and indeed the democracy of a great European nation are under attack – but it is more than that. The core principles upon which peace and security in Europe are based are being grossly violated. Helping Ukraine must be an imperative for the European Union. A lot has been done, but we must pursue our policies over time. The ambitions of the Kremlin will foster division in our ranks and exploit every weakness. Russian failure to live up to the Minsk agreement shows that we must stand united and neither give into threats nor be carried by propaganda. We must stick together on sanctions. It is up to the people of Ukraine to decide on their path. They did it in an impressive way in the elections in 2014, where I had the honour to be an observer, but our task is to help them confront the aggressor, rebuild their economy and strengthen their democracy. We must help Ukraine implement the Association Agreement and support their efforts to tackle corruption. By cutting tariffs we have already been helping Ukrainian exports substantially. The humanitarian crisis in the East needs instant action. Millions are in desperate need of food, medical care and heating. UNICEF reports are staggering: 1.7 million children live in a conflict zone. Children should be given special attention.

name: Kati Piri (S&D). -
text: The new Ukrainian government is setting itself up for an ambitious reform package. It is necessary to make the implementation of this concrete as soon as possible. Moreover, it must be a reform according to the principle of inclusiveness. A pluralistic society that does justice to the European values that the Maidan uprising was about. These reforms are complicated by the ongoing conflict in the east. The failure to implement the Minsk agreements by Russia and the separatists is alarming. This once again indicates that the sanctions imposed by the EU are still relevant and that we must stick to them. Finally, it should be clear that the Netherlands will not rest until objective evidence has been provided for the cause of the crash of flight MH17 and those responsible have been brought to justice. I therefore urge full cooperation and access to the international research team and for the bottom stone to be brought up. I would like to hear from the High Representative how she sees her role in this.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. When I listened to Commissioner Mogherini, I hoped that we would hear at least one strong statement about Crimea, because it is not enough to declare that we do not recognise this annexation. I also do not expect you to come up with a plan here on how Ukrainian sovereignty is to return to Crimea, but that we will learn how to react in order to restore the balance, the brutally shaken annexation of Crimea in the region. After all, we know that there are already consequences, e.g. russia's strengthened military presence in Abkhazia.  And the second thing That I wanted to ask on this occasion. How is the European Commission's official attitude to the Normandy format actually? Because I have serious doubts about whether the best mandate for talks with Russia is doing business with Russia. I am referring to things quite fresh as the sale of submarines, the monopolistic position on the use of the Opal gas pipeline completely circumventing EU rules. So maybe let's think more about Central Europe, then we will have a bigger title to talk about solidarity in Europe.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE) -
text: The situation in Ukraine is, in many respects, one of the greatest foreign policy challenges we face. It is therefore necessary to clearly define and fulfil the vision of our relations with Ukraine. The truth is that we were not prepared for this crisis. It is all the more important to respond to it in the spirit of our European values. There are two strategic issues on which we need to have agreement before the Riga Summit. The first touches on the trilateral talks between the EU, Ukraine and Russia on the Association Treaty and the DCFTA. We have accepted unprecedented third-party interference in the bilateral political and trade agreement. The Member States, together with the Commission, must therefore set clear limits for which we can no longer retreat. After all, it is inconceivable to reach a deal with Russia at the expense of the sovereignty of another country! The second issue concerns the territorial integrity of Ukraine and sanctions against Russia. These should continue until we find a lasting agreement on the Domba region and Crimea. It would be a strategic mistake to waive sanctions against Russia until these issues have been resolved with the consent of the Ukrainian side.

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the illegal annexation of Crimea last March represents the most disturbing aspect of the entire Ukrainian crisis. For the first time since World War II, borders in Europe have been modified through force. Moreover, by doing this, Russia got closer to NATO by hundreds of kilometres, being able to strike deeply into NATO territory using long-range weapon systems deployed in the peninsula. If Ukrainian territorial integrity and sovereignty can be restored in the eastern part of the country, provided the Russian forces withdraw, Crimea remains the biggest challenge, both legally and militarily. Of course, refusing international recognition of the annexation and imposing sanctions on business coming from and going to the peninsula will continue for long as it will take, but the challenge remains. It will have to be addressed politically too.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR) -
text: Mrs Mogherini, congratulations on your position as High Representative and I am pleased that you have replaced the Baroness, who has steadfastly ignored this Parliament. I chair a party that supports sanctions against Russia and I consider the annexation of Crimea to be a violation of international law. But I would like to remind you that the EU's role is not to save or solve the economic problems of all the countries around it. The European Union has a huge number of its own problems – huge debts, unemployment, stagnation. People who want to send money to Ukraine do it from a foreigner, not their own. Ukrainians can take their own account of their economic problems, because for 20 years they have voted for governments that have not reformed but stolen. If Ukraine needs to be economically helped today, we have the International Monetary Fund, of which all EU countries are members. If, in this way, the European Union continues to engage as before, it will experience its second Greece.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Russia's development in an authoritarian direction and the annexation of Ukrainian territories exacerbate the unrest in Europe. The fact that President Putin shows no signs of changing his criminal behaviour is serious, but historically not surprising. The Finnish history of Unrest in Ukraine depicts how the government in Kiev in 1919 demanded the withdrawal of the Russian troops that were then on Ukrainian territory. The response from Moscow then was the same as it is today: No Russian troops are in Ukraine. History teaches us about the Russian attitude towards Ukraine, but history also teaches us what the price of leniency is against a Russia whose tool is the lie and violence. In order to succeed in being heard with a non-democratic Russian state leadership, joint and strong action on the part of the EU is required. Today we know that sanctions are having an effect, the currency is plummeting, investors are fleeing and growth is falling. Against this background, it is regrettable that the French President is now talking about easing sanctions policy. It's sending the wrong signals. Therefore, in the face of the Union's evaluation of sanctions policy, the call to the Social Democrats of Europe is to say no to the lifting of sanctions, do not betray the fight for freedom in Ukraine.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D). -
text: It's hard to say anything else.
