In recent months, we have seen – while modestly – progress in developments in Ukraine, as the Minsk peace talks have brought prisoner exchange, but then the negotiators have found themselves in an impasse again due to differences over how to achieve a lasting ceasefire and mutual withdrawal of forces. That's the reality, and that's the challenge. The humanitarian situation is worrying. Efforts to resolve the long-lasting Ukrainian crisis must be intensified. This year I expect a change in the rhetoric between the Union and Russia, which has begun to gain the overtones of the Cold War. Russia must abide by the agreements.  Only then will it be possible to move forward even for rapid urgent reforms in Ukraine to make it a full-lunger. In the world, we are seeing a worrying trend of declining levels of peace. Europe is no longer safe, too, but it is Ukraine that is an example of the struggle for pro-European values, and let us keep this in mind and start taking more decisive and quicker action.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR). -
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today, a great deal of violations of international law, particularly on the Russian side, have been denounced. This is certainly quite rightly happening, because it is the breach esto, violations of international law, particularly through the annexation of Crimea. However, in the same resolution, ladies and gentlemen, you now also want to think about Ukraine's membership of the EU. I wonder whether we have not yet had enough problems among ourselves in the present form of the European Union that we now have to think about enlarging this European Union. And then, ladies and gentlemen, think seriously about whether Ukraine could not also be a nato member in the future! I really wonder: do you actually take note of realities? Do you really take note of what your task is, ladies and gentlemen of the majority groups? Finally, tomorrow we want to adopt a Resolution on Russia which bluntly supports interference in Russia's internal affairs with substantial financial resources! This is mendacity, as it can no longer be worse!

name: President. -
text: Before I give the floor to Mr Wałęsa for one-and-a-half minutes, can I just repeat the announcement to the Chamber that we are not taking blue cards because of the time constraints on our debate. I do apologise for that, but that is the ruling of the previous chair and I am maintaining that.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. It is difficult not to refer to the words of my pre-thud, which were simply outrageous. It seems that what he expressed in his speech should be condemned very bluntly.  But moving on, it is easy to see that the crisis caused by Russia will continue for so long that we need to think about how to increase solidarity among the Member States. The best way out of this situation will be to adopt or set clear goals that will unite us. Compliance with the Minsk provisions has proved problematic for the Russian side from the outset. The ceasefire, the unconditional withdrawal of Russian troops from Ukraine, the halting of the armaments of armed groups or mercenaries, the exchange of all – I repeat all – prisoners and the restoration of Ukrainian control of the territory of the whole country seem to be obvious conditions here. It is important to emphasise here the restoration of control over the territory of the whole country, because I have the impression that we are already forgetting Crimea, and yet it all began.  The warming of Moscow's image, even if it is visible, is only illusory. The European Union must not loosen its firm stance and, on the contrary, must be ready for further restrictive measures that will stop Russia's destabilisation of Ukraine. I believe in this success, but diplomatic channels must remain open.

name: Boris Zala (S&D). -
text: Madam President, solving the conflict in Ukraine is the most urgent task. On the one hand I applaud the leadership of Germany and France in their pursuit of a negotiated solution within the Normandy format. I understand the demands of crisis management, but my fear is that, as a result, the institutions of our common foreign policy as provided for by the Lisbon Treaty are becoming marginalised. I would like to see the High Representative, despite her comprehensive explanations, and the Commission take on an even more prominent role. I would like to see the EU – as an autonomous strategic actor representing the interests of all its Member States and its citizens – engaging with Russia and Ukraine. It will carry much more weight and legitimacy, which is what counts in geopolitics.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE). -
text: Madam President, we miscalculated the beginning of the conflict and war in Ukraine, so let us not mismanage the end of the conflict. We sometimes speak about a strong Russia; but Russia is not as strong as we are weak, because we are divided and we are afraid – partly because of our misunderstanding of the situation and also partly because of the assistance of our far right and far left, which are united in order to weaken the European Union. We also do not need to leave the back door open for a retreat, and to go back to business as usual with Russia, just because we can find excuses to do this. We have to first stop the aggressor, and only afterwards can we can start to go back to business as usual. The key to success is a firm stance against the Russian aggression, and at the same time also firm support for Ukraine. Ukraine should be supported first of all with funding and advice. This is what many analysts and experts, such as Alex Motyl and Anders Åslund, are saying. Even George Soros is saying this. But to do this, we also need to be firm with the Ukrainians and tell them that they need to implement their reforms. I am not sure they understand this very clearly in the limited time they have. We also should understand that we have to speak a clear language and have a clear head with all of this. So let us not live in an illusion, and let us be realistic, because Ukraine is our strategic interest.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, let me begin by thanking all the colleagues with whom I was able to participate in the preparation of the resolution. However, I see one major threat in our assistance to Ukraine's reformers at the moment. If we really want to help Ukraine in political and economic reforms, i think we need to change our approach. In the past, we have seen poor coordination or perhaps even rivalry between the various representatives of the European Union. A clear evidence of this is a kind of misunderstanding between High Representative Ashton and Commissioner Fül in the early days of the Ukrainian crisis. Now the situation is happening again, and in many cases we do not speak with one voice. I would like to ask whether you will initiate a debate on a long-term, unified and coordinated EU policy and on a united voice towards the Ukrainian leaders?

name: Michael Gahler (PPE). -
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for her work I believe that we can make our aid to Ukraine even more targeted, and I believe that the people sent there by the Commission are far from sufficient. I think we should remember what we actually did in the pre-accession process for many candidate countries. For example, we have made government twinnings, twinning from experienced authorities in the old Member States, in the reform of the authorities in particular. We also have partly – And I know this from my Member State – institutions that do nothing but translate laws en bloc, for example, if they have proved their worth – that is, to shorten the time a little so that Ukraine also quickly implements and implements what is necessary.  I believe that we can act much more specifically in order to save time, and I believe that we also have many allies in political groups. I am thinking of at least four of the governing coalitions where people have been elected directly from the Majdan to the various parties, including parliament. These are also the drivers of real reforms against the old structures. Otherwise, it must remain clear that, of course, sanctions will only be lifted if Russia fulfils the things provided for in the Minsk agreement. And otherwise I am still surprised that a kind of spiritual Hitler-Stalin pact is apparently under way here from the far left and the far right. This is also a scandal, which we should address here again and again.

name: Goffredo Maria Bettini (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, yesterday's attack on the bus carrying civilians, where 13 people lost their lives, is yet another violation of the Minsk Protocol, the highest price of which the civilian population unfortunately pays the highest price. The resulting setback in the peace process is very dramatic.  I would like to highlight two points which are essential for the imminent management of the conflict: the European Union must strengthen its efforts to ensure that humanitarian aid to eastern Ukraine is carried out in full compliance with international humanitarian law, in neutrality and in close coordination with the Ukrainian Government, the UN and the Central Committee of the Red Cross; Russia's respect for these same principles would remove doubts about the cargoes of humanitarian convoys, as an alibi for illegal trafficking in military equipment. In addition, Ukraine urgently needs to focus its efforts on political, economic and social reforms. Now is not the time to push Ukraine towards NATO.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE). -
text: Madam High Representative, thank you for your report and also for your call for a unified approach. We are returning to negotiations on Ukraine five months after the adoption of the association agreement, and we have no choice but to condemn once again the annexation of Crimea and the military unrest that is supported by the Russian Federation. Unfortunately, the situation has not changed much. We appreciate that there is a new government in Ukraine after democratic elections. She has the will to reform, but she has problems because her country is devastated. Ukraine needs our help, not only moral, political, but especially material, which is why I also welcome the financial support so far and the current increase in the loan. However, support for Ukraine in terms of expertise and expertise in a number of areas that must undergo reform is equally important. I would like to be more specific, because I was in Ukraine in mid-November and I have repeatedly dealt with Members and school representatives and I am still in contact with them. I know that it is in the field of education that they are preparing a fundamental reform and they expect our help. As post-communist countries once did, Ukraine can now benefit greatly from OECD expertise in pursuing these reforms. Here I also see an opportunity for effective assistance from the European Union, and I am addressing the High Representative with this call for technical capacity assistance, which is not expensive but effective. Thank you for your understanding.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Madam High Representative, i would like to thank you for your excellent work We started this discussion by talking about the challenges facing Ukraine, the difficult reforms that lead to the development of the democratic economy, but to continue this conversation, this debate requires that we take the context appropriately. And the context is that in the east of Ukraine there is a regular war, a war with tanks, with daily shelling of people, with the death of soldiers and civilians. And from the perspective of Brussels or Strasbourg, it seems that Donetsk, Luhansk is somewhere far away, but from warsaw's perspective it is very close and not coincidentally today the Polish delegation is very in agreement and in assessing the situation, and in proposing solutions. There is no doubt that the resolution of the case in the East, the resolution of the Ukrainian case, is a question of the security of the European Union, the security of all of us, one of the most urgent, most important issues to be resolved.  And here the role of Russia is crucial, because it is the Russian troops that support the separatists, the Russian media are engaged in anti-European and anti-democratic propaganda on a huge scale. The European Union cannot be divided in the face of these events, it cannot be hesitant. We must be consistent and consistent in showing disagreement with the integrity of borders established in international agreements. Consistent in the application of economic sanctions, which are effective, in continuing and developing dialogue and cooperation with Eastern Partnership countries and, finally, in assisting Ukraine, which is the key to stabilising the situation in the East.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE). -
text: Madam President, since the start of the aggression of the Russian Federation in eastern Ukraine more than 4,000 people have been killed and more than 9,000 people have been injured. Since the 2014 Minsk ceasefire agreement was signed alone, more than 1,000 people have been injured. The same UN report notes that 600,000 people have moved out of Ukraine and another 600,000 have been forced to leave the country as refugees. Today, every day, more than 1,200 people flee Ukraine. Basically, those who remain are fighting for medicine and food; separatists have occupied hospitals and the sick can no longer be cared for and so on.  I ask and we all ask the troops of the Russian Federation to stop all aggression, to withdraw from the border with Ukraine to make room for OSCE troops along the border. Let us be united, firm and strong, speak in the same voice and show the Russian Federation that democracy has defeated and communism has lost!

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE). -
text: Dear Madam President, Fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. Ukraine is in a serious domestic political crisis for European orientation, a difficult economic situation and, foreign policy, a protracted Russian-Ukrainian military conflict that has killed thousands of people. The war in eastern Ukraine costs the country EUR 5 million per day, which is a huge burden on the Ukrainian economy, with runaway inflation and impoverishment for the civilian population. However, humanitarian catastrophe and insecurity are not only having an impact in Crimea and war areas. The re-emergement from the domestic political crisis is the assistance of the new Ukrainian Government and the European Union. As there is no unified and painless solution to the problems, radical changes are needed: the elimination of corruption and double standards, the capitalisation of the economy, decentralisation and full respect for human and civil rights for the majority and the minority. I think the most important thing is that Ukraine must become a European democratic state, and in order to do so, the EU must give all its assistance from a financial, expert and moral point of view, but also supervise it... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE). -
text: Madam President, unfortunately, yes, we have seen repeated violations of ceasefires of late and a very unstable security situation in Ukraine. Nonetheless I note the comments you have made that, since 9 December, there has been relative peace and the situation has become more calm. However, it is fragile and uncertain. Like my colleagues, I want to see implementation of the Minsk Agreements. We need to stress that sanctions will be upheld if Russia does not change its course of action. A commitment to ceasefire is necessary, and Russian sanctions must only be eased or lifted after real progress in implementing the Minsk ceasefire is made by the Russians. I was very happy to see the result of the free and fair parliamentary elections, but now we must insist on swift implementation of necessary reforms in Ukraine also. As leaders we have a duty to engage in an overall peace settlement. Ramifications for the world from anything other than a lasting peace agreement are unthinkable. A dangerous distrust has built up between Russia and the West. Nevertheless I do note your comments that we need a less reactive and more proactive approach to Russia – a more strategic discussion in EU-Russian relations, but no easing of sanctions until we see change.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, it is certainly known to the Commission that my country, the Czech Republic, recently sent 250 tonnes of machine gun ammunition to Kurdish fighters in Iraq. It has thus made a significant contribution in the fight against Islamist terrorists.  We know very well, Madam Vice-President, that the fight for the next world is being fought in Syria and Iraq, and there is a front in the fight against terrorism across these countries. We know it's not the only line. The other is taking place across eastern Ukraine. Our European Parliament has repeatedly called Russian aggression in Ukraine by its real name and supported the application of sanctions against the Russian Federation. Sanctions began to work, but they could not stop the war in eastern Ukraine. That is why it is so important to continue sanctions. And not only that, Ukraine needs to defend itself against aggression. Its soldiers urgently need material assistance in the form of weapons and ammunition. Like Kurdish fighters in Iraq, Ukraine is defending Europe.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE). -
text: Madam President, given that we are happy to see that Ukraine took a very clear road to European Union values and principles and that those free and fair legislative elections validated a pro-European orientation of Ukraine, the situation is still far from being stable and predictable. There are still strong tensions in the regions controlled by the separatist forces, and the security of all Ukrainian citizens is far from being guaranteed. The European Union has to continue to support Ukrainian integrity and sovereignty. The Commission’s Ukraine Support Group should provide more substantial technical assistance and EU institutions should work harder in order to strengthen a genuine civil society, one that is independent and courageous. Energy security is a major issue. It is important that, with the assistance from European institutions, the situation has somehow been solved until spring, but we need to consolidate long-term solutions which would also be beneficial for the EU strategic objective for a secure and diversified supply.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the current situation in Ukraine is again alarming, dangerous and needs further humanitarian – and I insist, humanitarian – and diplomatic steps and stronger multilateral dialogue between the parties involved, and the EU has to play a very important role in this. Today it is of vital importance that the Minsk Protocol is fully implemented, including Russia as well. All threats to the lives of Ukrainian citizens are to be condemned. Obstacles to the work by the special monetary mission must be removed and Ukraine needs to carry out the political, economic and social reforms that the nation needs. I firmly believe that Ukraine needs a strong, committed Europe at her side in order to maintain her independence and integrity of territory and to fulfil the Ukrainian people’s desire to live in a democratic, civilised state that also respects the rights of the national ethnic minorities.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI). -
text: Madam President! We have a very worrying situation in Ukraine. It is indeed nice that the Union is calling for the peace plan to be implemented. However, it would have been wiser to call for a trialogue right away and to start the talks with Russia. As we all know, two are part of the dispute. Russia has, of course, made many mistakes and has taken on a great deal of blame, but Europe should not be caught in front of the American carts either and should be a transatlantic vicarious agent. After all, the damage remains in Europe: 3 000 dead, one million displaced, billions in costs for Europe and, ultimately, a divided and still corrupt Ukraine. And Russia: a dangerous, fire-hazardous situation economically and financially. I therefore propose that we return to normality quickly, activate the trialogue and stop the sanctions and communicate very dampeningly and sensibly with both sides.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, the European Union must continue to support cooperation between ukraine's democratically elected president, parliament and government in order to bold reforms and overcome the current severe crisis, as well as guaranteeing the rights of all Ukrainian citizens, regardless of their ethnic origin.  Ukraine's government needs a single political will and solid financial support from the international community for its programme to succeed. It is part of the European perspective of Ukraine and a unified way for the long-term development of the country and its citizens. Russia's aggressive behaviour is the main cause of the crisis and poses a threat to European security and a gross violation of international law. The lifting of sanctions depends solely on the Kremlin's conduct.  I also call for the release of the separatist-kidnapped Ukrainian serviceman Nadia Savchenko, who is currently in Russia. I believe that we need a donor conference to restore Dombas, modernize Ukraine's strategic and energy structure. Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity cannot be questioned.

name: Julie Ward (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I am very pleased to hear the High Representative’s report on the high level of activity observed amongst NGOs during this difficult time. In preparation for this debate, I have been in communication with cultural actors from Ukraine, Russia and EU Member States, who agree that more consideration must be given to the power of civil society to pursue peace-building initiatives through the arts, with the EU as a key player: able to share, support and develop best practice, particularly in respect of young people who are, after all, the future.

name: József Nagy (PPE). -
text: Dear Vice-President, Allow me to return to the influence of the Vice-President's office. As we heard at the beginning of the speeches, I would also like to join in the view that your office is symbolically set aside on the most important foreign policy and security policy issue in the European Union. You were talking about great power, global influence, which is a very good attitude. But once we have reached the key issue, we can see that the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy will not even receive the chair in the negotiations. I believe that it is in the interest not only of the European Parliament, but also of the majority of the citizens of the European Union, and that you would like to see a stronger position in your office. I think that if we are to point out this political expectation more emphatically... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE). -
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Unfortunately, it is clear that the ceasefire agreement is still being violated. Moscow must strictly respect Ukraine's independence and stop destabilising the situation in the eastern regions. I think it is extremely important that the European Union speaks with one voice on this matter. We need a strong, common front for talks with Russia, supporting the Ukrainian government. At the same time, it is equally important that the internal political situation in Kiev is stabilised. The Ukrainian Government must regain its capacity to carry out the necessary reforms, which is why I am so pleased that parliamentary elections have been held. The choice made by Ukrainian society is decidedly pro-European. Research indicates that Ukrainians are ready for change and even for short-term rending if they are to bring long-term benefits. The new government faces many challenges. I hope that it will quickly proceed with the implementation of the much-needed and expected changes.

name: László Tőkés (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. A quarter of a century after the break-up of the Russian-Soviet Empire and the beginning of the reunification of Europe, we must show our full solidarity and unequal support for Ukraine joining the Union. According to the European People's Party and Hungary, in the financial, economic and humanitarian areas, we must give all assistance to our eastern partner in a state of war without declaring war, and we must also maintain sanctions on Russia pending the full implementation of the Minsk Agreement. In the long term, however, economic and military means cannot in themselves lead to results. A political solution is needed in the geopolitical force field of the emerging new Eurasian World Power Centre and the Euro-Atlantic Alliance, the Russian-Ukrainian-European confrontation and the crisis situation in Ukraine.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, let me reassure those who have insisted on this point of my personal full commitment to working with the European Parliament. Perhaps I can make a suggestion for organising our calendar in a wiser way, because I think it is a pity that we face such an important discussion at this late hour in the evening. We still have three debates to go, and I think it is a pity that so many Members of Parliament have left. So this is just an invitation to the Presidency to think, perhaps, of a better way of organising our work. Let me restate what many of you said tonight: that unity is our strength. We need to keep this unity; we need to keep this strength. I know very well what my responsibility is: it is to work on the unity of the European Union, be it in the Council, be it in the Commission – and be assured that the unity of our efforts and our objectives is there, on the Commission side and on the Council side – or be it at the European Council, where we had a strategic discussion on this question in December with the Heads of State and Government, or at the level of the Council of Foreign Ministers, which will meet again on Monday for the second time in two-and-a-half months. I have been in office now for two-and-a-half months, and the majority of my time has been dedicated to this unity on the message and on the proposals, be it on the support for Ukraine internally, or be it on the strategy that we need towards Russia. Let me quote Mr Brok and others in saying that our role, and my role, is to support any form and any format of dialogue that can make us, and can make the Ukrainians, first of all, together with the Russians, move towards positive results on our common objective, which is a resolution to the conflict based on respect for, and the restoration of, Ukrainian sovereignty and Ukrainian integrity and on respect for international principles and basic laws – which means no change of borders by force. Maybe I did not underline that point well enough at the beginning. I took it for granted: we have been saying it for such a long time that I expected the Chamber to share this position, which is natural to me. I understand from the debate that this is not the case, and I would invite you, too, to exercise your personal, individual, political and institutional responsibility to work on signs of unity coming from this Chamber, because this is also the European Union voice. And let me say that I am quite worried by the level of the debate tonight. Let me also say something that I did not mention before, on a question which was asked during the debate. I am going to underline it clearly: it has not only been stated by me several times but it is also in all our official positions. There is not going to be any change in our policy on the non-recognition of the annexation of Crimea. That is clear; that is to be taken for granted; that is not going to be changed. You do not change borders by force: not in this continent, not in this century, not in this millennium. You do not do it, and we will never accept anything like that. Not only will we never accept something like that, but we will always keep our non-recognition policy. Now, when it comes to my role, my job, you are right: I lead the European Union’s foreign policy and security policy. But my role is more complicated than worrying about what and where my chair is, or perhaps what table I should be at, because my real point is to have a table that works: one that yields results. I am sorry to say that very bluntly, but my main preoccupation day and night is not where I am sitting. My main preoccupation is to create the conditions for negotiations to be successful. If we manage to move forward on resolving the conflict in the east of Ukraine that will be my result. It will not be to get a picture at a negotiation table. Whatever I can do to facilitate that – whatever I can do with other European ministers, or the prime ministers or presidents, or the Members of the European Parliament or of other regional organisations – I will do. My objective is to contribute to resolving the crisis: playing in full the European Union role but also, if possible, being smart and intelligent in playing that role. And we have to understand what is the best that we can do, at what times and in what format. As many of you have said, we have to support, in a cooperative and intelligent way, anything that we see can work, starting with the full implementation of the Minsk Agreement. Now, what are we united on? There were some basic elements in the debate tonight, and, while this is not my role, let me personally invite you to explore the possibilities of having a joint, united message and a joint resolution. I think we are united on the support for Ukraine at different levels. On the political level, first of all, on 15 December 2014 we had the first European Union / Ukraine Association Council meeting following the Association Agreement, and there we defined, together with the Ukrainian Government, the ways in which the Union will support the reform programme in Ukraine, including through technical assistance. Secondly, on security – and if this went unnoticed by some of you, we will definitely need to improve our communication strategy internally – we started our EU assistance mission on reform of the civil security sector in Ukraine on 1 December 2014. This is a concrete thing that the Union is doing to support Ukraine in the security sector, and I think that you should listen to the Ukrainian people and the Ukrainian authorities with regard to the recognition they give to our role in that. Thirdly, the support for Ukraine on a humanitarian level. If you put everything together – what we do on development, what we do on humanitarian assistance and what Member States do – it comes, all in all, to EUR 74 million, which makes the EU the first and most active supporter of the situation in Ukraine on a humanitarian level. Is all of this it enough? I do not think so. Again, we will need to work – including, as one of the last speakers mentioned, with the people of Ukraine, civil society organisations, young people and those who a year ago were in the Maidan. Not all of them were in the Maidan, but many of them were. We have work to do on the role and empowerment of civil society in Ukraine. Civil society can play a major role in monitoring and supporting the reform process in the country, and this is key. I was surprised when I was there last time, on 17 December 2014, at how high on the agenda the issue of reforms was for all the actors that I met, whether in government, other institutions, civil society or parliament. In some cases, reform was higher on the agenda than the security issue. This is a message coming from Ukraine that we must not underestimate. We need to work very hard on this issue, and to work at their side. A second element that I think unites us, or at least the majority of us here – and it certainly unites the Council and the Commission unanimously – is the need to keep up the pressure on Russia. Again, maybe I was not clear enough in my opening remarks. I took it for granted that we start not always from zero but from where we left off last time we met, and we do not always have to repeat and reiterate our common positions. But that is clear. Sanctions on Russia are in place and, yes, they have worked economically. Have they worked politically? Maybe they are starting to. But it is clear –and again it has been expressed repeatedly, not only by me but also by President Tusk recently – that we are going to continue working on this, as we have been working in these months, hand-in-hand, because this is not only foreign policy, it is also internal policy. Any decisions on sanctions would be based on concrete developments on the ground. This is, I think, something that no one has talked about. The real point is the third element. Many of you have insisted on the need to have a dialogue. That is the point – probably the missing point on our side. I alluded to it when I said we have to be less reactive and more proactive, when I said we need to be more strategic and to develop a comprehensive approach – a comprehensive European Union approach – towards Russia. That is what we need to do, making it clear that the sanctions are based on the situation on the ground. Evaluation of that is going to mean taking stock of the situation on the ground and of developments, negative or positive, or the fact of no development. On the other hand, it does not mean that we do not have to talk: first of all because it is difficult to negotiate if you do not talk to the people you have to negotiate with, and secondly because the Ukrainians and the Russians are talking to each other, and we need to support that dialogue. So, talking about opening channels of dialogue with Russia from the EU side – as the Latvian Presidency did at the very beginning, as some of the Member States are doing and as I have been doing by having a bilateral meeting with Foreign Minister Lavrov in December – I think this is my duty. It is the only way in which we can play our role. It does not mean we are being soft because, even for purposes of being hard, you need to talk.

name: President. -
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 15 January 2015 at 12.00. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – It is a big mistake for those opposed to the European Union to make common cause with President Putin just because he opposes Ukraine’s ambitions for closer association with the EU. President Putin is not our friend or ally: he is the leader of a gangster state. In Russia, state-sponsored terrorism, corruption, intimidation and murder are commonplace. The Ukrainians threw out their corrupt pro-Russian President and Government because they were under the domination of Russia. The Ukrainians are not absolved of all blame for things that have happened there in the wake of the revolution, but all revolutions bring chaos, injustice and suffering. However, the Ukrainians want to be free of Russian domination. The Ukrainians are between a rock and a hard place. They see no alternative to the Russian threat but to seek closer association with the EU. I regret that but I understand their position. I hope that the Ukrainians eventually achieve independence and freedom without the need to submit themselves to the undemocratic EU. I wish them well in that ambition.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The existence of national minority communities is a value that must be protected and protected, inter alia, through the media, as well as in schoolchildren and public institutions. It is of the utmost importance that everyone in Ukraine feels safe in the current situation, even in the most vulnerable communities, such as national minorities. The principle of 'zero tolerance' should be strengthened and enforced, condemning any discrimination, in particular respect for human and minority rights. Similarly, this is true in the occupied Territory inhabited by Crimean Tatars, where it is particularly important to respect minority rights. Any infringement against this national community is deeply reprehensible. They would need to be investigated by setting up an independent commission of inquiry, as the leaders of the Crimean Tatars have urged.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: – In recent months, the European public has paid close attention to Ukraine. In the interests of European orientation, Ukraine is in a serious domestic political crisis, a difficult economic situation and, foreign policy, a protracted Russian-Ukrainian military conflict that has killed many people. The war in the eastern Ukraine territories costs the country EUR 5 million per day, which is a huge burden on the already weak Ukrainian economy, with runaway inflation, price increases, unfulnisable tax burdens and utility prices for civilians, the living wage of which is not even close to the lowest level of the European living wage. I believe that radical measures are needed to achieve change: the elimination of corruption and double standards, the capitalization of the economy, the full respect of human and civil rights for both the majority and the minority. Every effort should be made to make Ukraine a democratic European rule of law. This is essential for the rights of all citizens of civil society, such as Hungarians in Transcarpathia. Legal certainty at European level is a fundamental requirement, and in order to achieve this, the EU must take decisive steps for the peace process and provide Ukraine with all the assistance it needs: financially, expertly and morally, but also to oversee and control the reform process and the implementation of the laws adopted.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. –  It is encouraging to see a strong EP position in expressing solidarity with Ukraine and its people, reiterating our commitment to the independence, sovereignty, and territorial integrity, inviolability of borders and European choice of Ukraine. It is significant that EP recognises not merely "European perspective" for Ukraine but clearly states that as a European state Ukraine may apply for EU membership. But first, EU has to provide structural, financial aid to Ukraine to best support the country´s efforts in conducting reforms, eradicating corruption, and re-building what has been destroyed last year. Secondly, EU has to be adamant in maintaining non-recognition policy towards Crimea. Also, EU together with UN need protect Tatar minority against violent and arbitrary persecution and forced exile, basically deportation. Most importantly, EU needs to maintain and in fact, seriously consider expanding sanctions towards Russia. These sanctions have had a clear effect on Russia; it would absolutely irresponsible to start to soften them. EU can only, and only then, give in, when Russia has fully and tangibly fulfilled Minsk agreement. Ukrainian and European security cannot be diluted by short-term national economic considerations. This is a war of nerves, and EU, based on solidarity with victims and European values has all the advantages if it can demonstrate strong nerves.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I would like to support the sincere assessment by the High Representative of the situation in Ukraine, underlining the need for internal reforms and for the urgent necessity to address the humanitarian crisis in this country, especially in its eastern part. The support that the EU may provide to Ukraine for reforms and humanitarian aid cannot be overestimated. The need for cooperation with Russia, for unfreezing EU-Russian relations is also obvious, regrettably not to all Members of this Parliament. The ongoing economic and energy crisis in Ukraine cannot be overcome without active and positive involvement of Russia. We should be realistic. Neither the EU nor other Western countries and institutions can provide all necessary funding. The losses to the Ukrainian economy are huge, due to a decline in trade with Russia, which may still be recovered. We need to break the vicious circle of sanctions that have proved to be largely ineffective and try to find better solutions, based on mutual respect of legal and legitimate interests, first of all the interests of the people of Ukraine.

name: President. -
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the launch of the European Year for Development (2014/2508(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Madam President, this is the first European Thematic Year to be dedicated to EU external relations, and it will give us a unique opportunity to bring EU development cooperation into the spotlight throughout the whole year. The EU has been engaged in development cooperation since 1957. It has long been the largest donor of official development assistance in the world and aspires to continue to remain the largest donor for the years to come. This is something we can be proud of, but it is also something which is unknown to many of our own citizens, however supportive they are of development cooperation. Hence we need to communicate more and better on what we do. The European Year for Development will highlight the results that the EU, acting together with its Member States, has achieved and will continue to strive for in the future. We will work to foster direct involvement and critical thinking on the part of EU citizens and stakeholders in development cooperation. We want to show that EU development cooperation is good not only for EU partner countries but also for EU citizens. In a changing and increasingly interdependent world in which major shifts have taken place in the global economic and political balance, we should spare no effort to stimulate a sense of shared responsibility and solidarity among citizens in Europe and in partner countries. The 2014 Eurobarometer paints a clear picture. More than 85% of EU citizens say that the EU should continue development cooperation efforts, and 67% think that the EU should actually be giving more aid. This is despite the current economic difficulties. At the same time, EU citizens also demand that we use public funds effectively and efficiently to achieve concrete results in terms of reducing poverty and building a more stable, peaceful, prosperous and equitable world. In 2015, the international community will have to agree on a new post-2015 development agenda. We will have the third Financing for Development Conference in July in Addis Ababa, the UN post-2015 Summit in September, and the global climate agreement at COP 21 in Paris in December. The European Year for Development will enrich the debate on the challenges we face in shaping future EU development policies. The twelve thematic months will put a strong focus on some of the most important topics related to development: education, gender, food security, demography, immigration, human rights and governance, to name but a few. The EU institutions and Member States, but also local authorities, NGOs social partners and the private sector, will be closely involved. The European Year for Development was launched in Riga on 9 January this year with the presence of Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, Ms Federica Mogherini, the Prime Minister of Latvia, Ms Laimdota Straujuma and the Chair of the Committee on Development of the European Parliament, Ms Linda McAvan. The Riga event focused on good governance as a key priority for the EU both at home and in the post-2015 process. Several Member States will officially launch their own programmes in the coming days: Belgium, Austria, Ireland and France are some examples. The Member States will organise a large number of events and activities at all levels throughout the year. In addition to the Riga event last week, in March the Latvian Presidency will hold a high-level conference in Riga on gender, women’s economic empowerment and sustainable development in the post-2015 agenda. Apart from high-visibility events in Latvia, we have centralised the activities to make the year as close to the citizens as possible. It will be implemented by all relevant stakeholders, NGOs, private sector representatives, academia, line ministries and local authorities. In May, Expo Milan will open its doors to thousands of visitors, involving them and inviting them to reflect on the theme of ‘Feeding the planet, energy for life’. This will be another unique opportunity for the EU to showcase the achievements of its development policy. I would like to underline how well the European Parliament, the Council, the Member States and the Commission have worked together in preparing the European Year for Development. The European Parliament played a key role, and Mr Charles Goerens has been a very dedicated and enthusiastic rapporteur. The discussions and exchanges between the European Parliament and the Council have always been constructive. The programme of activities prepared by the European Parliament will make a significant contribution to that success. I have no doubt that we will all continue to demonstrate the shared sense of commitment and implementation throughout 2015. I can assure you that the Presidency will do its utmost to ensure the success of this important endeavour.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, I would like to thank the Latvian Presidency very much for the launch of the year that they organised last Friday in Riga. I was personally very happy to be present, together with the Prime Minister, the Presidents of the Commission, the Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Committee, and Linda McAvan. It allowed us to highlight the important role of the European Parliament in the process and also that of many NGOs and young people. I think that one of the things that we will need to work on very much – and I really appreciate the Latvian Presidency’s focus on that – is to make this year a European Year, a Year of the European People, and not only an institutional year. We have to use, in particular, the links through NGOs, civil society organisations, schools, universities, and young people. You have also presented a couple of exciting competitions for normal people. I think this is really going to be a very unique opportunity – a unique opportunity in a unique year somehow. The year 2015 is the year in which the Millennium Development Goals come to an end. Some of them will have results, some of them will not. It is also the year in which the whole global community is going to be working on the final decisions on the post-2015 agenda. This will give us Europeans, in particular, the chance to work on our own internal responsibilities, as most likely the post-2015 agenda will also ask us to meet some goals internally – we tend to forget that we also have problems of inequality, poverty, lack of access to basic fundamental rights – and to work seriously on policy coherence internally, as I said, but also externally. I think this is going to be a great chance for us together, without partners in the rest of the world, to work on the root causes of not meeting Millennium Development Goals this year – and also on those that were met – on ways of improving results. I would only say that tonight I also speak on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Mimica, who unfortunately, due to the time could not be present, and on behalf of Commissioner Vella. They were both present at the launch of the year in Riga last week, and together with them we stand ready to work together with the Presidency, the Council, the European Parliament and all the stakeholders, starting from the international ones and the NGOs, to make this year a success.

name: President. -
text: Thank you, Ms Mogherini, for what has been a long day for you here in the Chamber, but this is an important debate so we appreciate your presence.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Madam Presidents, Europe's security and prosperity are more than ever linked to events on other continents in poorly developed countries that are often covered by armed conflicts or epidemics that they cannot control on their own and which then become global threats.  Therefore, for moral, humanistic reasons, but also for security-political reasons, Europe has a strong policy of development cooperation, and as we heard from President Juncker at the opening of the European Year of Development in Riga, and now from the High Representative, the European Union intends to maintain a leadership position in development cooperation, strengthen its global role, continue to be a force for good in the world, and thus ensure peace , safety, health and prosperity to European citizens. However, it is essential that this message reaches European citizens. To include them more than ever in defining priorities in development cooperation. This should also be the main purpose of the European year of development, especially at a time when a new development framework is being negotiated on the international stage to replace the Millennium Goals. In November, we adopted a resolution setting out the priorities the European Parliament wants to highlight in a new, global development framework, which must be transformative and focus not only on symptoms, but also on the causes of poverty and inequality in the world. These priorities are the promotion of the rule of law, the building of effective institutions, the fight against corruption. This was not the focus of the Millennium Goals, but it must now become part of a new development framework, because without it we will neither eradicate poverty nor reduce inequalities.  I would like to end the last seconds I have to congratulate the leadership shown by the Latvian presidency and let me also express our appreciation to the High Representative - not only for being during this very long afternoon, almost evening, here with us, but also for the leadership that she is showing in these particular development issues. I think it is very important, we really appreciate it and we look forward to working with you in the future. Thank you. I would like to end by congratulating the leadership shown by the Latvian Presidency. Let me also express our appreciation to the High Representative not only for being here during this very long afternoon – it is almost evening now – but also for the leadership that she is showing today in these particular development issues. I think it is very important, and we really appreciate it. We look forward to working with the High Representative in the future.

name: Linda McAvan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I want to echo those words of thanks to the Latvian Presidency for the excellent launch on Friday, and also to Mrs Mogherini for taking time out of her agenda and for showing leadership. I know she is coordinating across many departments now to lead on this issue in the next few months, and that is crucial for Parliament. We now have to build on our words tonight and the warm words in Riga to make the year a year of action. We will have the first chance in New York in September, when we will get together to replace the MDGs by the sustainable development goals (SDGs). My lesson from the last 15 years of MDGs is that development policy works. Millions of people have been lifted out of poverty, millions of people now have access to water and sanitation and millions of children are now going to school. So we need to see that same kind of commitment now to the SDGs, so that after the end of this year we have laid the foundations for a real legacy of the European Year for Development. Linked to the debate on the SDGs is, of course, the climate change agenda, and we will have the climate talks in Paris in December. It is the poorest in the world who are already paying the price of climate change, and we have to link climate change and development, which is why it is very important that we have the kind of coordination that I know you, Mrs Mogherini, are leading in the Commission. I hope we will also see support in 2015 from the Commission and the Council on an updated gender action plan for the European Union. In too many countries, progress and our rights as women are being undermined and women are being subjected to violent attacks in conflict situations: by Boko Haram, in the DRC and in Syria. We want action on that. Finally, we want to work with NGOs, which are vital to our work in this European Year of Development. It was great that the Latvians got behind this idea. They pushed the idea and now we have to work with them to deliver it here in Europe.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President. Thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for your presence here and for your words, with which I believe that we all agree substantially. On behalf of the ALDE Group, I would like to congratulate the Committee on Development of the European Parliament, and especially my colleague Charles Goerens, on their initiative to turn 2015 into the European Year of Development and to give citizens an account of what we do and how we do it. Our world, our dignity, our future. An unbeatable motto for a year that is also for the balance and evaluation of the Millennium Development Goals. In these fifteen years we have achieved some very important achievements on these eight objectives, such as halving the extreme poverty rate, stabilizing HIV and advancing the fight against malaria and tuberculosis. But it's also time to take on our mistakes, limitations and failures.  In 2015 we will not get all children to access and finish primary education; nor eliminate gender inequality. We have not improved enough in infant mortality or universal access to reproductive health. Drinking water supply remains a challenge in many parts of the world and the digital divide is actually an abyss. We can't be satisfied. That is why we must renew the commitment of the future that we entered into in 2000, of a future that belongs to children. The year 2014, the 25th anniversary of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, has been a dreadous year for them. Unicef reminds us that 230 million children live in conflict zones. Some, protracted crises, forgotten or barely news of a day by horrific episodes, such as Boko Haram's brutal actions or the Taliban massacre of Peshawar. Terrifying numbers of displaced children, mutilated, executed, abducted, tortured, recruited, raped and even sold into slavery. There is no development without education. There is no education without freedom and equality. There is no freedom and equality without respect for human rights. There is therefore no development without respect for human rights. So, that's the marker of our actions. The European Year of Development will be that of children or not. The Millennium Development Goals will be children or not. Free from fear, violence, hunger and ignorance. (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, 2015 is key to the future of international development. We will set a new regulatory framework and also determine its financial framework. In this context, it is important that the European Union declared 2015 as the European Year of Development. It is an opportunity to increase political will for development in response to our values of justice and solidarity that we so much proclaim.  People already broadly support international cooperation, as reflected in the Eurobarometers— the last one was published yesterday. It is the rulers who must apply the story and, once and for all, act consistently with what they preach. You have to stop putting on medals with development policy when you really want to use it for the interests and benefits of European corporations. It is cynical to ask citizens for more solidarity. They are the ones who are paying, through dramatic social cuts, for the consequences of a crisis they have not provoked. Solidarity must be demanded of those above and begins with the establishment of fair and progressive taxation.

name: President. -
text: I know that one of our colleagues has asked for the floor with a blue-card question but, colleagues, because the debates have overrun quite significantly I am not going to take any blue cards, which is fair to everybody. I am apologising in advance to those who wish to ask blue-card questions.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, High Representative, Secretary of State, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has We are now starting the European Year of Development. This is actually planned for this year, because we should have met the Millennium Development Goals now. Unfortunately, not everyone has succeeded in this. But I hope that this year will help to move closer to this year's goal – our world, our dignity, our future. Because it is about achieving a decent life for all on this planet. This is also the basis of the definition of the European Union's post-MdDG agenda.  When I talk about decent life, I am also concerned with gender equality. It is simply not acceptable that 21 years after the Cairo People's Conference and 20 years after the Beijing Women's Conference, sexual and reproductive rights and health for women are still not universally recognised, that women are still not paid decent wages for their work or that they are not getting a job when they become pregnant, or that they are subjected to violence. All of this contributes to the fact that women are still the ones who suffer the most from poverty in the world.  But we also need more policy coherence. This is about development cooperation. This is not just helping. After all, what good is it if economic and trade pressure is created, then local markets are destroyed and we then come and help when it burns. This is not how we get any closer to global justice. I would like to end with a short slogan – something transformed from Austria: we must not be angry if global solidarity ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 2015: we are launching the Year of Development and it is certainly a laudable initiative, it has certainly been something positive in terms of communication, certainly good results have been achieved in the past, in terms of access to drinking water, in terms of access to health, in terms of improving the state of life in some of the developing countries.  The question is: what do we mean by development, ladies and gentlemen? Because the impression I have is that we are a little hypocritical when we deal with this issue, because we let go of our European multinationals, to go and create commendable damage in these countries which we then want to help, instead, probably, in the year of development – that is, in 2015 – the communication that we should be making should be to our citizens on raising awareness of a degrowth , so to a more reasonable consumption, because we use the resources of those countries that we then want to help.

name: Hans Jansen (NI). -
text: I too would like to thank all those who have made efforts recently to make the European Year of Development Aid a success. I can assure you that, as a result of this European Year of Development Aid, champagne bottles have been flown open in the campaign offices of the eurocritical parties within the EU. Never has it been so easy to show our voters what the EU is and what the EU stands for. Instead of having a deal with the European taxpayer, the EU is going to organise a Soviet-style propaganda circus for vague plans to give away European money in corrupt countries far away. Especially in the countries affected by an after-tax on their EU contribution, this plan will baffle the electorate. I ask you: do not implement this plan! For this year's celebration. Finally, academic research into development aid barely exists. After all, it has been shown that aid does not help. Development stems solely from a society's own efforts. Help can't add or take anything off.

name: Norbert Neuser (S&D). -
text: Madam President! Many thanks to the Secretary of State from Latvia! If Mrs Mogherini could listen now, that would be nice. Mrs Mogherini, I would like you to listen because I would like to compliment you. They have been sitting here for six hours without interruption. We cannot have the debates in this way in the future. My appeal goes to the Bureau – you have now consumed the fourth or fifth Vice-President because the debate goes on for so long – that we will work more concentrated in the future. Less is more.  In my speech, I want to focus on only one point in the European Year of Development, which is the permanent underfunding of our development cooperation. I take a very different view of Mr Jansen, who comes from a Member State who has helped to ensure that we have enormous underfunding in development cooperation. Talk to the EU delegations in developing countries. Last year, development programmes had to be cut, and development programmes were stretched into the next year. We in the EU have asked non-governmental organisations, aid organisations, to pre-finance. This cannot be the way development cooperation can be. Our citizens want effective development cooperation. This includes sensible financing. If we uphold European values – such as solidarity, aid, charity, like human dignity – this includes sensible funding. That is why I appeal to the Member States: help prevent the EU from being underfunded on the issue and move closer to the common objective of spending 0.7% of the budget on development cooperation.

name: President. -
text: I note your comments on the arrangements for the debate and indeed Ms Mogherini’s comments. We shall pass those on to our colleagues.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI). -
text: Madam President, 2015, as announced by Commission President Juncker, will be the European Year of Development. But are things as rosy as the Commission is presenting them to us? You pride yourself on the European Union being the largest donor in the world. Of course, you have not been so generous to the Greek people, whom you have forced into terrible sacrifices over the last five years. You are telling us that you are proud of Europe's achievements in terms of the standard of living of third countries. Are you proud of the achievements of the memorandums in Greece? Let me remind you of a few facts: 439,000 children in Greece of the European Union are malnourished and live below the poverty line, according to UNICEF; 37% of children in Greece live in households with inability to heat; 7,500 suicides of desperate Greeks. Are you proud of these numbers? Of course we want Europe to see a rise in living standards worldwide. But this cannot in any way be done at the expense of its peoples. Let's take care of our own people first and then everyone else. As for the Year of Growth, I would remind you that Greece is in its sixth year of recession.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! Focusing on the sustainable development goals of the post-2015 agenda makes the question of a coherent development policy all the more urgent.  This means, above all, that development cooperation will be more closely interlinked with other policy areas such as human rights, immigration and refugee policy, climate change, conflict management, but also – and above all – trade policy.  I believe that policy coherence must become the leitmotif of this theme year. This goes into three steps: good coordination within the European Commission, improved coordination between the European institutions and good coordination among the EU Member States responsible for the implementation of development cooperation in the Council. In addition to the European Union, some countries, such as Denmark and Finland, regularly submit a coherence report to their national parliaments. It would be a great success of the European Year of Development if all the European nations followed suit.  We should also use the development theme year to link further national initiatives with the European level. In the Federal Republic of Germany, for example, there is a Bundestag motion "Good work worldwide", which appeals to the worldwide implementation of the ILO labour standards. In addition, there is an initiative by the Federal Development Minister in Germany for a textile alliance, but this has reached its limits.  The initiative should improve working conditions in the countries of origin by tracing the retail chains in the textile industry. However, because fair trade is so complex, such initiatives are successful not at national level, but at EU level.  I therefore call on our Commissioner for Development and the High Representative to take the lead on these initiatives from the European Commission. It would also be desirable for the Commission to be able to provide further information materials on the European Year of Development that are suitable for young people. This makes it even easier to become a European Year of Citizens. I would also like to thank you most warmly for the opening in Riga, where I was able to attend, and Mrs Mogherini for her long presence here in our Chamber today.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, it was a good decision of this Parliament to propose 2015 as the European Year of Development because 2015, with its 'Twelve Months, Twelve Goals', is an essential, crucial year, in which we have two major summits where the fate of billions of people in the world is played: the Climate Change Summit, a phenomenon that particularly affects the under-favoured , and the relaunch of a new post-2015 development cooperation period. We need to maintain the European Union's ambition in negotiating in both areas. And I would like, as permanent rapporteur for humanitarian aid, to call for the integration of this perspective into the European Year of Development. This is the first time we have had four crises of the highest level of humanitarian demand: Iraq, Syria, South Sudan, Central African Republic and, today, Ebola.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it will be a fundamental year for development policies. , but above all there will be the expiry of the Millennium Goals and the definition of the new Sostainable Developpment Goals that will be, as he mentioned before, finally universal, finally valid for everyone and therefore also for us.  This Parliament has adopted a very ambitious position, which relaunches the most innovative objectives such as the one on combating inequalities and the one on gender equality. I believe that the issue of inequality is the biggest issue of our time and is crucial to building a future that is truly sustainable for the new generations. Therefore, let us use this occasion of the European Year of Development together to better communicate this whole process and to build it together with society, together with all the stakeholders and to find the single and strong voice that Europe needs precisely to find the leading role it must have in the definition of the new agenda and for this reason we rely above all on you, Vice-President Mogherini , and also to Commissioner Mimica.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I am very pleased that 2015 has been dedicated to the issue of development, and especially about its timing. 2015 will be a year of important negotiations on how to tackle global poverty. The UN Climate Change Conference in Paris next November is one of the most important of these. This is because climate change threatens to undermine decades of development and puts future development trajectories at risk. Many of the main drivers behind poverty in developing countries are intertwined with climate change. Increased drought, for example, leads to crop failure and food insecurity, reduces opportunities and boosts inequality around the world. When dealing with the issue of development, we should strongly promote environmental initiatives, energy efficiency, exchange of technologies and best practices, investment in public education and in disaster risk reduction and, more generally, emphasise low carbon emission development. Developing countries will bear the brunt of the effects of climate change as they strive to overcome poverty and achieve economic growth. In fact, one of the top priorities of the European Union development agenda is to achieve accomplishment of the COP 21 negotiations in Paris.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the international community is called upon to take important decisions at this year's summits for new objectives and new targets for the period 2015 with regard to development policy, and the challenge we have is clear. The European Union, in to match its values, must take the lead in building the global development policy agenda, but there is no leadership without an example. The European Union cannot lead if, on the pretext of budgetary constraints, it wants to go backwards in its financial commitments or to steal from concrete commitments, so what I ask the Commissioner is whether, even before the Addis Ababa Conference, the European Union will be in a position to reaffirm its commitment to 0.7% of gross national income for development aid. That's what we've been waiting for. Maybe you can't ask for more, but you can't take any less.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the Council and the Commission for this initiative and I have time for just two very brief comments.  The first is this: we must contextualise this Year of Development and we must unfortunately contextualise it in the tragic events that have taken place in recent days, which have, however, revealed as a scenario in the eyes of many citizens who did not know the barbarity, backwardness, poverty and different living conditions in many areas of the world. So, let's also use this opportunity to explain what's in the world, how you live, what needs a lot of the world's population is bringing today, and we make sure, through initiatives, conferences and actions in schools, that you understand the value of cooperation, its function, to say that a fairer world is not only a fairer world but it's also a safer world. , is perhaps a better world also in our interest, that these are not resources taken from us but are resources to make world reality fairer for all.  The second thing, that of EXPO, has been said: a single word, the European Union is present in EXPO, the Commission is the contact person, expo issues must become the themes of international cooperation. Feeding the planet means confronting the goals, it means dealing with inequalities and many other things, it is not so easy and it is not obvious. I call for a strong commitment from the Commission to ensure that this whole issue enters EXPO.

name: Seb Dance (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I am going to decline the invitation of our colleague from the freedom party to say I am not proud of the Year of Development, because I am incredibly proud of the Year of Development. Development works, and we now have a real opportunity to put international development right at the heart of European policymaking, and I want to pay tribute to the Latvian Presidency for doing this. Specifically, we have an opportunity now to ensure that Member States deliver on their commitments for 0.7% of GNI spending on development. This is a fundamental aspect of human principle; saying that we have a commitment to those who live in the poorest parts of the world is a fundamental aspect of who we are and the values that we should share. Of course, having development at the heart of policymaking should remove the all-too-familiar problems we have with policy undermining development objectives: financial decisions taken at home that undermine tax receipts in developing countries and foreign policy decisions that fail to promote fundamental aspects of human dignity, such as rights for LGBTI people. Having the Year of Development will put humanity – humans, people – at the heart of our policymaking, and I welcome the decisions made to do that this year.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE). -
text: With regard to the European Year of Development, I think it is important to point out that the European Union and the Member States, as well as the world's largest aider, should pay even more attention to human rights than they currently do. Of course, humanitarian emergencies require rapid intervention, but in development policy we must enforce the aspects of the dissemination of the protection of human rights. I am convinced that Europe must not only be at the forefront of traditional humanitarian aid, but must also help these societies by developing the economy of the developing world in a sustainable and complex way. I find it extraordinary that, through the subjects that have been broken down into months, europeans are effectively being made aware of the most pressing problems in the world. The words education, health, migration or food security mean something completely different in less developed areas of the world than in our country.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, Europe today is at the fore leader in worldwide donations, and it should remain so. In fact, more than that, we should invite our partner-friends America, Japan and others to participate together with us in our goals, and this is as you well said, first of all, to feed the planet.  Every man on this planet is entitled to a meal, he has the right to live, and I think we need to lay the foundations of such solidarity in the world right now, and to speak openly, we should also consider our interests. We often talk here about the problems of immigration to Europe and everything it brings, and on the other hand we have mechanisms by which we can act to help countries from which afflicted people come.  That is why I think Europe should remain at the fore leader and invite its partners to participate together with it precisely in the solidarity that brought Europe first, the high place, the biggest donors in the world.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: The European Year of Development takes place in a key year in which a balance will need to be given on the achievement of the Millennium Goals. It will also be necessary to take stock of the programme for change, approved in 2011, and on the concrete results of the reforms then announced.  No one denies the european Union's important role in development. What they question are the results and the methods. According to the information available, most of the millennium goals are far from the targets set, despite some progress.  This European year should serve to inform, clarify and mobilise European citizens for this cause. Citizens, millions of these citizens who have been left without a job and have been sent below the poverty line in the light of austerity policies that affect the majority of the population and concentrate wealth and income in the hands of a minority. We can't take one hand and take it out with the other. We cannot help the Palestinian people and their government and allow israel's bombs to destroy schools built with European funds. We must also cancel the debt to the third world.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I am a strong supporter of humanitarian aid in the case of natural disasters, and the challenge for all nations must be to deliver that quickly. I think we all agree here that the aim must be to help countries develop. Much more, in my view, could be done through trade, by breaking down tariff barriers to make it easier for developing countries. For example, a higher tariff on chocolate than cocoa hardly encourages processing to be done in the countries themselves and the development of their economies. We must also be careful that policies intended to help do not end up hurting people in those countries. I refer, for example, to fishing agreements under which EU vessels are able to exploit the natural resources of other countries, and to the Pesticides Directive, which does not help in terms of the mosquito population or, therefore, the fight against malaria. There are many issues, and I think they are wider than just development. We must not help with one hand whilst hurting with the other.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I would like to underline some of the elements that were raised by some of you and try to answer a couple of questions. One is the fact that, yes, the European Union is the first donor and this is not charity. This is an investment. It is an investment on the one hand in our own stability and security – and in our prosperity as well, because those of you who may have been in this room at the beginning of the session at 3 p.m. will have heard a long debate about the fact that there are no divisions, no limits and no borders between internal and external threats, and if we do not invest in reaching the objectives we have for development – for sustainable development – and for equality in the world, the threats to our security and also the limits to our economic development will just grow and grow. So this is an investment in our own future, not just in the future of the people in the rest of the world. And yes, it is one of the most effective tools for preventing conflicts and for foreign policy, and also for following up conflicts, not to mention what was said before regarding the effects this has on other elements of global challenges and policies, starting with migration and asylum-seeker flows. So I see no contradiction between improving the living conditions of European Union citizens and improving the living conditions of other countries’ citizens. Actually I see a certain complementarity in that. I think that making it possible to keep the European Union as the foremost donor in the world is our common challenge and job. This requires a lot of work, not only on communication but also on explaining the fact that, no, this is not charity that we give when we can afford it, but rather it is a strategic investment in our own security and prosperity. Secondly, someone said, and I agree with this, that it is not just a matter of help, and this is indeed so.
