It is a matter of policy coherence, and that goes for the challenges we have in front of us this year, when we know that we will be called again to be coherent in all our choices, be this in internal policies or external policies. That means that we need to work hand in hand with many other chapters. I would like to thank Linda McAvan for reminding us of the role I am trying to play in coordinating the different Commissioners and also the different Councils – but in particular the different Commissioners – because here we have first to make sure that what we do, for instance, on trade does not contradict what we do in development or that what we do on humanitarian issues goes hand in hand with what we do in development, and that we intervene with the right tool at the right moment and in the right place, and that what we do on certain policies does not influence in negative terms what we do with other instruments that we use. So the concrete effects of this coordination will probably take a little time to emerge, but I think that this is the key issue for post-2105 – the real policy coherence of our policies. I will try to answer two issues. One is about the commitment to the 0.7%. This was precisely one of the issues we discussed in the last meeting of the Commissioners group. We will have a discussion about this, not only with the development ministers but also probably with the finance ministers and finally with the European Council. Obviously we will discuss that with the Latvian Presidency, but there is a need for Member State ownership in this because it is not only a matter of spending money, but also of setting priorities politically. Yes, we do believe that we should keep this target, but we need to develop a strategy to get there. The second point on which we will need very close coordination, not only within the Commission but also with the Council, is in managing the mix, the balance, between financing for sustainable development and financing for the climate. This year will be crucial in this regard, and we will need to play this carefully – first of all in the Commission, but I think that we will need coordinated work on this. Let me say a final word on Expo, because I commented when you introduced the debate that this is the first time that I am not the one talking about Expo because, when I started the Presidency as a Minister, that was one of my main issues. But some of your comments allow me to say that, yes, we will indeed be present, as the European Union, at Expo, and the reason for that is that, as was just mentioned, we need to put the content on our development policy, on feeding the planet, at the centre of the event. So count on the European Union to be part of that effort, together with the UN Agencies based in Rome, which I know are also going to be major players in focusing on the content of the Development Year, and to make sure that Milan Expo will also be a crucial event politically for the European Year for Development.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, this has been a really fruitful exchange of views, which I think shows once again our common strong engagement for the European Year for Development. I can assure you that the Presidency will do its utmost to ensure the success of this important endeavour. The year 2015 will be a crucial year, with the Financing for Development Conference in July in Addis Ababa and the UN post-2015 summit in September in New York. I think the common event of this year will be COP 21 in Paris in December. We have a unique opportunity to address the global challenges of poverty, education and sustainable development. We must agree on an ambitious and transformative package in September 2015. The Latvian Presidency will work towards reaching a common European position. We anticipate complex negotiations around means of implementation on how the post-2015 framework will be implemented and by whom. We need to ensure that everybody plays a part, based on shared responsibility, mutual accountability and respective capacities. We have to admit that awareness on, and civic participation in, development cooperation issues should be improved. The opening event of the European Year for Development in Riga last week was a step towards achieving this goal. We hope that the impact of this Latvian Presidency initiative will be felt long after the end of our Presidency. It is symbolic that at this time, a global alliance for the European Year for Development will be established that will bring together hundreds of European NGOs. To conclude, I would like to note that successful development cooperation leaves a positive impact on the well-being of our partner countries. This in turn will unavoidably have a positive boomerang effect on the lives of Europeans, most notably in terms of welfare, security and global position. So I really hope we will have a successful and fruitful European Year for Development.

name: Presidente. -
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – In 2015 we are launching the year of development, and major challenges lie ahead. The EU has to intervene where it is needed and where it can make a difference. EU development policy is a centrepiece of the Union’s relationship with the outside world. With 50% of all global development aid, the EU is the world’s leading donor. Now we need to define the post-2015 agenda. The overarching goal is the eradication of poverty. While the proportion of people living in extreme poverty has dropped, there are many who still live below the internationally defined poverty line. The new framework should provide for improved living standards, access to primary healthcare systems, free education and improvements in agriculture and, above all, for the existence of basic fundamental rights. Working with developing nations and emerging economies should create a win-win situation.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 2015 is a special year for development policy. The deadline agreed 15 years ago to achieve the Millennium Development Goals is now over. We are also on the cusp of the next road set by the new Sustainable Development Goals. I therefore believe that the choice of 2015 for the European Year for Development is particularly apt. As the world's largest donor, the European Union spends over EUR 50 billion a year on development aid. It is therefore extremely important that our citizens are aware of why such assistance is needed, who benefits from it and on what terms it is provided. I would also like this year to allow us to look in depth at the effectiveness of the Union's assistance, to help better define obstacles to combating poverty, and to help improve the identification of sources of poverty. I hope that over the next year we will prove that there are no limits to europe's care for human dignity, a peaceful future and human rights.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Year for Development must be a time when we are aware of the need for the European Union to be involved in solving the problems arising from underdevelopment around the world. EU member countries have undertaken the Millennium Development Goals but unfortunately have not met their political or financial commitments. We are far from the financial objective of the 0.7% share of GNP allocated to development cooperation by member countries and even further in achieving the development criteria by poor countries. The EU and the Member States must take advantage of the European Year for Development to return the issue of international development to the public agenda. I assure you in this respect of all my support as an MEP, but also as a university professor specialising in the field, and I am sure that many Europeans, many of them young people, are willing to get involved in supporting a Europe - a leader in the field of international assistance and cooperation.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Millennium Development Goals, completed in New York in 2000, will come to an end in 2015. Unfortunately, many of the challenges and objectives raised at the time could not be achieved. Major milestones such as equality between women and men, the possibility of free education or the reduction of poverty still exist or have even worsened in some parts of the world. Of course, in many areas, these objectives were too ambitious and too ambitious. Our task now is to assess the results of the development goals and to continue positive results within Europe. Europe can only lead the way in the world if we manage to tackle the problems we have and to find solutions to poverty, youth unemployment or equality. As long as we have not mastered the great challenges on our continent, we cannot look for solutions on other continents or countries!

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – The announcement of 2015 by the European Year for Development is an opportunity to draw more attention to the world's development challenges and to look more closely at how to address them. With the end of the deadline for achieving the Millennium Development Goals, it will be necessary to set development goals for the future this year. The international community will have to agree on a new approach to try to eradicate poverty, promote the economic growth of countries affected by natural disasters and conflicts, and resolve climate change issues. Although one of the Millennium Development Goals was already achieved in 2010, reducing extreme poverty by half compared to 2000, this result is not satisfactory. Moreover, the achievement of this goal has been more supported by the economic development of China and India than by work on development projects. The European Union should therefore work more consistently to improve the situation of people living in the world's poorest countries. The European Union is the largest donor of development aid in the world and member states therefore need to work together to reduce poverty in the world.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Written: In the context of the European Year of Development, the EU does not forget to recall that it is "the largest donor of official development assistance in the world" and that "every euro spent on development" is intended to help people in poor countries and also in the EU itself. While these statements sound nice on paper, the reality is fundamentally different. For example, with money from EU development aid in Belarus, the Belarusian secret services bought a technique that served to further oppress the domestic population. Even more absurdly, development aid ended up in Ghana, Africa. There, the European Union sent millions of euros for years, only later discovering that this money was to go to people who did not really exist. The EU therefore declares that every single euro of development aid helps, but it cannot realistically save millions. Moreover, EU development aid is also criticised from within the EU – for example, by the European Court of Auditors or also in the European Parliament's 2012 report. Rather, the European Year of Development should serve to shed light on how desperately inefficient the European Union's often development aid resides.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – Two key points of the post-2015 framework also relate to the terrible attacks in Paris: universality and human rights. With universality, it is distanced from an 'us and them' thinking, which divides the world into 'developed' and 'underdeveloped' countries. The problems faced by traditional developing countries are cross-border and also occur in the industrialised world. Real development is impossible without universal respect for human rights.  The conditions in which terrorism can grow are the same ones that development cooperation seeks to address: lack of a functioning rule of law, violations of human rights, discrimination, political exclusion, socio-economic marginalisation, lack of good governance and education. Weak socio-economic policies lead to greater inequality and contribute to the conditions in which radicalisation and violence are growing.  This applies outside but also within the borders of the European Union. Where governments withdraw, radical organizations fill the vacuum and promote their degrading ideas: the right-wing radical Golden Dawn in Greece, IS in Iraq and Syria, or Boko Haram in Nigeria. We must act by consistently defending human rights and by reversing conditions in which radicalisation can grow through redistribution and solidarity with the weakest in any society, both inside and outside Europe.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: Written. – The European Union plays a leading role in formulating and implementing the concept of cohesion policy for development. It is important that The Union's policy meets the development needs of developing countries. In a rapidly changing world, it is essential to continue to support development cooperation. Around 1.3 billion people are still living in extreme poverty and social development needs are still not being met. Inequalities within countries are increasing in most areas of the world. The environment is under increasing pressure and developing countries are particularly suffering from the effects of climate change. These challenges are widespread and interlinked, so meeting them requires the cooperation of all countries. It is necessary to inform how an outward-facing Union can contribute to ensuring global sustainability. The European Year of Development should foster awareness-raising. Combating global poverty will build a more stable, peaceful and fairer world, reflecting the interdependence of richer and poorer countries.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – Eradicating poverty in developing countries is an important priority for the EU. Our efforts should go hand in hand with those aiming for the achievement of the sustainable development goals. I welcome the European Year for Development initiative and I am convinced that an integrated European approach together with the involvement with the various stakeholders will result in significant progress. Instability and conflict situations are unfortunately typical for the less developed areas in Africa, South America and Asia and in many cases violent conflicts and illegal activities of local militias are financed from mineral extraction and trade. Breaking the link between mineral extraction and conflict financing is a complex challenge. The European Parliament is taking the lead in the EU action to promote responsible behaviour by companies operating in such areas. An integrated approach is entailing a trade-related EU regulation but also foreign policy action and development cooperation initiatives. As the rapporteur for the regulation setting up an EU system for supply chain due diligence self-certification of importers of 3TG originating in conflict-affected and high-risk areas I am committed to contributing to the elaboration and adoption of an efficient and balanced regulation at the core of the EU integrated approach.

name: Presidente. -
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for the Common Foreign and Security Policy on the situation in Egypt (2014/3017(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, on the situation in Egypt, this is a time that is quite symbolic. If we look back exactly four years ago, Egypt was on the brink of the 25 January revolution, with people taking to the streets calling for dignity, social justice and simply bread – their legitimate political and socio-economic rights. Ever since, the European Union has stood by Egypt and its people, fully supporting these democratic demands. Today, four years later, Egypt is still in political transition. Eighteen months after the ousting of President Morsi, Egypt is still in transition pending the parliamentary elections planned to start at the end of March, which will be a crucial step in concluding the Constitutional Roadmap. Two steps have been achieved. Egypt has given itself a constitution and it has elected a new President. Both steps were monitored by the European Union with the mission for the presidential elections in May. A delegation of the European Parliament was part of it. Now we would like to see the mission recommendations taken on board, particularly in view of the upcoming parliamentary elections. Difficulties, however, remain, and I have decided not to send a fully-fledged observation mission this time but, instead, to deploy a smaller Expert Mission (EEM). The purpose of the mission is closely to assess and report on the electoral process, including on the political environment and electoral campaign. The list of recommendations to be drawn up by this mission will facilitate constructive engagement with the authorities on much-needed reform efforts. But democracy goes beyond elections, and we all know that very well here. A parliament is key to having a legitimate legislator in place to tackle the many tasks of urgent legislative reform – including the law on NGOs and the controversial protest law – and to ensure compliance with the new constitution, which will need to be implemented. The parliamentary elections are also an important step towards providing a broad base for political engagement that can ensure fundamental rights and freedoms, security and economic reform accepted by the whole of society. Open political engagement and discussion will reduce the risk of radicalisation. Another challenge is clearly that of the deteriorating security situation spreading beyond the Sinai. We have always affirmed that the European Union stands by Egypt in fighting terrorism. There is no place for violence. The Special Coordinator for Counterterrorism travelled to Egypt in December 2014, and we are looking now into possibilities of holding a dialogue on counterterrorism and security. Let me add that this is not only in Egypt’s interest but also in our own European Union interest. Seeing the fragility, to say the least, of the situation in the whole region, we welcome and have welcomed Egypt’s re-emergence as an important regional player. In particular, the role that the country played over the summer in reaching a ceasefire in Gaza, facilitating the Israeli-Palestinian talks, and then more recently with the conference for reconstruction in Gaza that was held in Cairo in the autumn, was very important. Furthermore, Egypt is re-emerging as an important foreign policy player in the League of Arab States, in the African Union and in Sub-Saharan Africa, in particular over the Nile water issues with Ethiopia and in national dialogue efforts with Sudan. While still in political transition and facing security threats, Egypt also urgently needs to tackle an economic situation that is particularly difficult. Steps taken by the new authorities go in the right direction, with subsidy cuts and large-scale infrastructure projects such as the new lane in the Suez Canal. The EU will continue to support Egypt in addressing its socio-economic reforms. We will participate in the international investment conference planned for March. We will continue to focus our support in the socio-economic field, to help improve living conditions for the most vulnerable among Egypt’s population. These challenges and the ongoing political transition cannot allow any compromise on human rights. Egypt needs to address its human rights situation, including the lack of political space for dissenting opinion and shrinking space for freedoms of assembly and expression. Too many of the issues that you mentioned in your resolution on freedom of expression and assembly in Egypt last July have not yet been addressed. Only last December we saw another decision by a court to pass preliminary death sentences on 188 defendants. We keep calling on the judicial authorities to respect due process and ensure fair trial. A truly professional and independent judiciary is a key element for functioning and trusted state institutions. Another concern – a deep concern, as we have said in statements – is the lack of accountability and the continued crackdown not only on the Muslim Brotherhood and affiliates but also on political opponents and liberal activists, illustrated by often disproportionate sentencing. There are too many civilians tried by military courts, and too often, laws such as the new draft anti-terrorism law and the existing NGO law, which does not comply with the new constitution, give too ample a degree of discretion to the executive. We keep addressing these issues when we meet with our Egyptian counterparts. In particular, I have to thank the Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, a former colleague of some of you, who repeatedly raised these issues with the Egyptian authorities on the occasion of both of his visits to Egypt during 2014. The question for the EU is not whether we should support Egypt – there is no other option but to stay engaged with Egypt – but how best to support its transition. Therefore Egypt, like all our southern and eastern partners, will be closely involved in the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP). The outdated Action Plan with Egypt will need to be re-negotiated, taking into account the ENP review and to better reflect the reality on the ground. We will monitor the parliamentary elections with our experts, as I said, and we will monitor the further implementation of the constitution and, with a view to the upcoming parliamentary elections, the freedom of the press and media. But we will also help Egypt with its economic reform efforts and its fight against security threats. We will work with Egypt too in the context of our own efforts and our own fight against our own security threats.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Thank you, Mr. President! Thank you, High Representative, for your intervention! I would like to make, first of all, a few points about the position of the PPE Group in relation to the joint resolution that we negotiated with the other political groups, and I would like to say that we have a very detailed, very long text - that is because we wanted to introduce in this text everything that has happened since July, July 2014, when we last adopted a resolution on Egypt. This makes text difficult to follow; sometimes the figures are not very reliable, because we have quoted various sources and that is why I would like to place the resolution in a context that is described by several key facts.  And, first of all, I would call our relationship with this country in the fight against terrorism - Egypt is an essential partner and I do not think we can neglect this, as Egypt plays an extremely important geopolitical role in the Near East peace process. The second important coordinate is obviously the transition to democracy, which we want, which we support in Egypt, respect for the principles of the rule of law, respect for human rights - all this must become a reality because that is what the citizens of Egypt want. Thirdly, I believe that we must consider the implementation of the Constitution that was adopted, which came into force almost a year ago. It is a better Constitution than before, but it is essential that it becomes a fact from the perspective of fundamental rights, first of all, especially since we have these elections that Mrs Mogherini mentioned. I subscribe to what has been said about the need to implement the recommendations made by the last Observation Mission, led by our colleague Mario David.  Finally, I would like to address the issue of new legislative projects that could have a negative impact on NGOs, I know that this is a controversial issue in Egypt, but I would like to appeal to the Egyptian authorities to address these projects under the sign of openness and not under the sign of repression.

name: Victor Boștinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, distinguished colleagues, this is a day to remember. The High Representative staying in this House for more than seven hours is a gesture of respect for Parliament, who welcomes and respects this gesture. Now I will switch to Romanian. Thank you, Mr. President! Egypt is a key country, an extremely important country for the European Union - this has been said before - and we must underline its contribution to the ceasefire effort following the Gaza conflict. We must underline Egypt's contribution to the fight against Daesh and regional and global threats of this nature. From this perspective, the European Parliament is so interested in the evolution of the process of modernisation and democratisation of the friendly country, and that is why we must help Egypt to progress. We are, of course, concerned about the current situation with regard to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. We fully understand the complex situation created after the Revolution, as well as the seriousness of the terrorist threat facing Egypt. We now understand it even more after the recent attacks in Paris. We welcome President Sisi's call for the modernisation of Islamic thought, we believe that this is a courageous attempt, which must be supported and supported by all those who want a calmer world, a world less threatened by terrorism. Long-awaited parliamentary elections are essential to start the democratisation process. They must ensure free access, they must be conducted fairly and they must be inclusive, and once the elections are held, the European Parliament must engage in sustained cooperation with the Egyptian Parliament in order to ensure the developments that we all want.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, since the overthrow of President Mubarak, Egypt has undergone many changes and been gripped by much political turbulence. Following the removal of President Morsi in response to genuine public revolt against his rule and the direction in which he was taking his country, we are now beginning to see stability once again return to that great country. Since then, we have seen the adoption of a new Constitution by referendum, the election of President al-Sisi and, most recently, the announcement of parliamentary elections. These achievements are all to be welcomed. However, this is just the start of the journey rather than the end. Many internal issues need to be addressed if Egypt is to become the pluralistic Arab democracy that its people wish for and deserve. Whilst my Group welcomes the improvements to the lives of Coptic Christians, in particular, and other minorities, it is crucial that this level of tolerance be exercised in other areas too. Freedom of speech, freedom of expression, the right to peaceful protest and the rule of law are all key tenets of democracy which should also be respected. The large number of citizens who have been charged to date, and who have been detained and sentenced in Egypt for non-violently exercising these rights is a grave cause for concern. Reports that, since July 2013, more than 40 000 people have been detained and an estimated 1 400 protestors killed are extremely worrying. I am also concerned by the crackdown on media freedom and the fact that one of my own London constituents, Sue Turton from al-Jazeera television, a journalist, has been tried in absentia and is now prevented from resuming her job anywhere in the region. In broader terms, we must not forget Egypt’s role as a leader of the Arab world, and a regional power and actor, and its ability to play a part in finding solutions to the current situation in neighbouring Libya, for example, or in the fight against Islamist terrorism in the wider Middle East and North Africa. As a friend, there is much to be gained from positive relations with this great country of Egypt, and I welcome the interest of this House in seeking to support Egypt in its transition to democracy. This is a great challenge for the country.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Egypt itself made commitments through its new Constitution. In this Constitution, which is better than the previous one, human rights have their place, including equality between men and women. Therefore Egypt has to live up to the commitments it has itself made. I agree with all the previous speakers that we, as the European Union, should be on the side of those people who are fighting for freedom in a democratic way and are now being tried – to our concern – on the basis of emergency laws. I would recall what Charles Tannock said, that Egypt will play a vital position in the Arab world – and so it should. After the presidential elections we will see parliamentary elections and it would be of great benefit if they were free and fair because this is another milestone in the process leading to real democracy. Let us also see what, apart from being vigilant, we can do to help Egypt to respect human rights, for instance through the European Neighbourhood Programme. Maybe the High Representative can see what we can do together with Egypt to promote human rights.

name: Marisa Matias
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr Vice-President, in fact the diagnosis is very similar. Egypt is going through a difficult and unstable process, so things cannot be seen in black and white. We have all been able to identify the threats that are being posed to democratic rights in Egypt, namely freedom of expression or freedom of assembly, as the Vice-President herself said, but we have to learn from the lessons of the past and, above all, from the last four years in this region and I think it is necessary to learn lessons from recent events and the first of the lessons is to avoid lessons.  We must know that the future of Egypt necessarily passes through the hands and decisions of the Egyptian people. In this transition process, obviously the European Union can support and support, it can support as an intermediary, as an intermediary if the parties so choose, an intermediary to try to promote the establishment of social peace.  I understand that holding parliamentary elections is a positive step, but we have to take into account that this organisation is primarily up to the Egyptians. We certainly have common objectives and the Vice-President has rightly mentioned our question is how to better support and not enter into a process of interference. I think we must safeguard the right of the Egyptian people to decide their fate.  But I would also like to stress, Madam Vice-President, finally, your deep respect for this House, so many hours here to discuss with us. It is indeed an honour to be able to count on a treatment of the European Commission as that which is giving us today in this House.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Four years ago, the Egyptians liberated themselves from dictator Mubarak, at least that is what they were trying to do. This was welcomed in this House, without the question being asked as to how Mubarak remained in power for so long. Then they elected Morsi. These were elections that were more or less reasonable, not great and not to our liking in terms of results. Because there is no European who says, "We were so happy with President Morsi." But it was there. Then Morsi gave himself extra rights. We were not happy about that at all, because we had made agreements with him about the construction of his country. Morsi gave himself extra rights and the response was a military coup. This House didn't really want to see that. Some people said, "It's very, very good that there has been a military coup." And now we have that military regime.  I'm not saying it was good in the past. I am not saying that we should go back to Mubarak, nor that we should go back to Morsi. But I hear a changing tone in this debate between six months ago and now. Now we are talking about Egypt as a geopolitical partner, Egypt playing its part in the Mediterranean and Egypt being able to protect itself from terrorists, especially in the light of what has happened in Paris. I find that last comparison really shocking. It cannot be the case that, because we are afraid - and we are rightly afraid - we say: 'The freedom of the Egyptian must give way again, because it was actually easy for Mr Mubarak to keep his people a little quiet.' Because Sisi is Mubarak 2.0. And at a time when the Egyptian Embassy has three human rights activists on offer here and everyone in this House wants to speak, we are awake enough to understand that human rights activists are never accepted by the embassy.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Egypt is today the eye of a cyclone that is shaking the entire Middle East and much of North Africa. There is still a great deal to be done in the country on the rule of law, freedom of expression, freedom of sexual orientation and the right of assembly, civil and political rights. We must not hide, among sincere friends, the task is precisely to be one mirror and bring to the attention of the other all the necessary constructive criticisms, but we must also be objective and recognize the great role played by Egypt in the fight against terrorism, in the conclusion of a truce between Israel and Palestine that has put an end to a bloodbath, the situation of great economic and social fragility that afflicts the country. , some signs of détente and attention to religious minorities. It is certainly not enough, but it is already progress!  That is why the timing of this resolution should not be read as an early prejudice on the next elections, but should be interpreted as a stimulus, an invitation to a healthy, more for more so approach within the framework of the Southern Partnership. If there is no progress in the coming months that is now inescapable, then it will be time to criticise and with all the necessary strength. This evening, however, we are calling for a great and immediate effort, the release of the journalists and bloggers detained in the country, in order to restore the right echo to the wind of freedom that inspired its revolution.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI). -
text: Mr President, there is an Islam acclimatised to nations, which enshrines Qur'anic precepts in national cultures and accepts that the law of states is superior to Sharia law. But there is also fundamentalist Islam, which refuses history, which recognizes only the umma as a nation and as a constitution as the Koran. This Islam is making us war and, in this great struggle that has only just begun, we need Muslim allies. Our European governments have destroyed secular forces trying to acclimatize Islam to state rule in Iraq, Syria, Libya, playing the Islamists everywhere. The result is catastrophic. The regimes on which we must rely are under considerable Islamist pressure. What would be the level of rule of law of France in the Egyptian situation when we see the state of astonishment of French power caused by three terrorists? I recall that Egypt and its security forces in particular have had more than 500 deaths in the last 18 months. Abdel Fattah al-Sisi made an exceptional appeal from the largest Arab country. He called for Islam itself to be purged of its violence. He called for a religious revolution. Ladies and gentlemen, it is too easy, in the comfort of this Chamber, to throw moral lessons at the whole world. The time has come to have allies and to take responsibility for the political differences they have with us. This is not a manipulation of emotion, it is not an infantilizing slogan that people expect of us, they are courageous political and responsible choices. We sovereignist parties have long made these choices because our priority is that our peoples live in peace and keep their civilization.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, Egypt is one of the countries that can play a decisive role in stabilizing the Mediterranean region and on many other issues, as you have so well pointed out. I will emphasize five things. First of all, I stress the implementation of constitutional provisions on fundamental rights and fundamental freedoms. We are well known that enumeration of rights and principles is not enough. We need concrete action, not just election promises. But how do we ensure that the Egyptian authorities actually respect the constitution? Second, freedom of the press and expression. Neither stability nor security rhymes with a jailed press. On the contrary, media freedom will enable the emergence of an inclusive and democratic pluralistic society, as it is one of the instruments of dialogue within society. It is this dialogue that will overcome the polarization of Egyptian society.  Thirdly, it seems to me that interfaith dialogue could go a long way to reducing tensions and fostering pluralism. I encourage the Egyptian government and the European Union to support initiatives that promote mutual understanding and religious tolerance.  Fourth, the role of women. Without women's participation, the democratic transition can only be partial. Their rights must be guaranteed, violence against women must be combated and their participation in political decision-making must be encouraged. Again, we need concrete initiatives with results, with the participation of men and with the participation of the Union. Finally, the fight against human trafficking. This is a major challenge that Egypt is tackling, on which we can cooperate more. We have the instruments. Now we have to make them operational.  There, the challenges are many. Our support must be up to the task of finally strengthening Egypt's democratic institutions and society without which, we know, no lasting stability of the country is possible.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I recognise that Egypt is an important partner to the European Union, but tonight we are debating a resolution that is deliberately critical of Egypt. We want our criticisms to be heard. The mass detention campaign in that country continues to lock up tens of thousands of people. In 2014, ten thousand people were arrested on charges of rioting, sabotage and terrorism. This is not a credible approach to justice and the rule of law. Equally, the Egyptian representative told me that it is the wrong time for us to protest on the use of the death penalty. But Egyptian courts have this year meted out preliminary death sentences to over a thousand supporters of the ousted President, Mohamed Morsi. The point is not that we oppose or agree with the previous President, but that we absolutely disagree – and always will do – with death sentences. All unwarranted detentions are wrong, but Egypt should understand that the damage to its international reputation comes with the continued detention of the three al-Jazeera journalists. No one outside the country believes them to be anything other than bonafide journalists. After the highest court of law overturned their conviction on procedural grounds, they should, frankly, be released and not retried. My Group also condemns the attack on LGBT rights, represented by the raid on the bathhouse leading to the arrest of 26 allegedly gay people. I am relieved that these charges have now been dropped, but I emphasise that sexual rights must be respected, just like any human rights. Finally, it is proper for us to question the status and content of the NGO bill and to insist that international foundations and donors can have a proper role in facilitating the free flow of ideas without improper interference in the political choice of the Egyptian people. Partnership should mean partnership.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR). -
text: Mr Howitt, you take the words out of my mouth. Three of my former colleagues at Al-Jazeera are still in a cell in Egypt. I'm a former journalist. I will keep repeating it as long as it takes: these people are not supposed to be in a prison, they have just done their job and should be able to go home without further information!  The controversial laws continue to affect civil liberties. Now it is forbidden for NGOs to receive funds from abroad and the power of the army is being greatly expanded. Military courts can now also arrest and prosecute civilians on the basis of the slightest evidence. All this is legitimised in the context of the fight against international terrorism and Islamism. That's a battle that's important. But does the purpose still justify the means and is the cure not worse than the ailment? That is why, Mrs Mogherini, I welcome the emphasis you are putting on human rights and the parliamentary elections in March and our monitoring of them are crucial.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, colleagues, today we are discussing the situation in Egypt, exactly one year after the adoption of the country's new constitution. The constitutional referendum was an important first step towards a comprehensive political process and the European Union stood behind it.  But unfortunately, since june's presidential election, the political situation in the country has remained volatile, and the methods of power are too forceless and disproportionate in terms of the factor that challenged them. The isolation of a certain part of Egyptian society from the current political process in the country erodes statehood. The issuing of death sentences, human rights violations, pressure on civil society organizations and the lack of freedom of speech that has led to the arrest of students and journalists act with a destabilising effect on the democratic process and socio-economic environment.  Alongside negative domestic trends, we need to take into account Egypt's active regional role. The country has managed to mediate a halt to the 2014 war between Israel and Gaza, is making efforts for dialogue in Libya, is giving new impetus to talks with Ethiopia and Sudan on the controversial Renaissance project, and in October organized an international donor conference on the reconstruction of Gaza. That is why we need to engage in dialogue and actively cooperate with all representatives of Egyptian society.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, what had been dubbed the 'Arab Spring', a popular movement seeking the paths of emancipation and democracy, lacked real political, social and cultural support from our European institutions. It is the spirit of freedom and sovereignty that should have been supported more.  In a context where external interference in the region, such as the intervention in Libya, has liberated forces of fundamentalist barbarism, Egypt has experienced several upheavals in which freedom has not won, quite the contrary.  The muzzling of all oppositions and the press and executions after mass judgments are not acceptable. We must reach out more to the Egyptian people and take into account the regional dimension of this great country, which has long been one of the cultural beacons of the region and a facilitator, especially for the Israeli-Palestinian dialogue.  A more follow-up process must be undertaken with this country to lay the foundations for a sustainable co-development policy on both sides of the Mediterranean.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time we have discussed the situation in Egypt here.  Unfortunately, while some still dare to talk about democratic transition, the situation has continued to worsen. Egypt now has more than 15,000 political prisoners, a third of whom are non-religious activists and 147 are our colleagues.  As a former magistrate, I can only denounce the lack of independence of the Egyptian judicial system. A so-called justice, which is no more than the instrument of indiscriminate and indiscriminate repression of the state. While those who were yesterday at the helm of a sophisticated system of corruption and abuse of public property are acquitted, young peaceful activists, including Yara Sallam and Sanaa Seif, are sentenced, along with 23 others, to two years' imprisonment. Their only crime is to have demonstrated in order to denounce repressive laws adopted by the current regime.  Egypt must quickly return to the path of democratic transition or risk letting the hopes of the revolution die.

name: Amjad Bashir (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, Egypt is still reeling from the effect of the Arab Spring. It relies heavily on the tourist industry, and I can testify to that having been there myself. Any perception of instability or danger drives away tourists and increases poverty and despair. Sadly that industry now lies in ruin. About a year ago the country’s military dictatorship issued death sentences against 188 defendants, including journalists, political opponents and innocent protestors. The trials were deeply flawed. Freedom House, a much respected international organisation, recently issued a very disappointing report ranking Egypt as one of the worst countries in terms of free society. It noted with concern the lack of political and civil rights, and another charitable organisation, Open Doors, has stated that Egypt lacks any religious liberty. We now learn with shock and horror that the dictator Hosni Mubarak has been cleared of all charges of conspiracy in the killings of hundreds of protestors and the embezzlement of huge sums of money desperately needed by Egypt’s citizens. Egypt’s record with its neighbours and especially Ethiopia is appalling. It denies them the fundamental right of access to the waters from the Nile, although in fact 85% of the water has Ethiopia as its source.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI). -
text: Mr. President! First of all, a heartfelt thank you to Mrs Mogherini and a compliment for her perseverance for taking the time. The 2014 constitutional referendum in Egypt has improved the legal situation of minorities, especially Christians – but unfortunately only on paper. The life of the Copts is still a very difficult one. Legal and living protections are clearly divergent, and attacks on Coptic churches and their members remain on the agenda.  The situation is particularly dramatic in the Assiut region, where Copts are constantly kidnapped and, unfortunately, murdered without paying a ransom. In other areas, the Copts are massively disadvantaged. According to recent studies, Christians are continuously discriminated against in many areas such as jurisprudence, education, social services and care. So it is no surprise that Egypt is sadly still in the top 25 in the World Tracking Index in 2014. It is therefore the European Union's duty to take a serious look at minorities, especially Christian minorities, in the Middle East and to demand from Egypt the real and not only the legal protection of Christians and to make this a condition for further cooperation. After all, who else in Europe should take care of these minorities? I believe that this is our task here: to take on a protective role.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Egypt is a very important partner of the Mediterranean neighbourhood for the European Union, as has already been said. It traditionally occupies a leading place throughout the Arab world, which has usually had a genuine reference country in Egypt. The southern shore of the Mediterranean and the Middle East are now in a very difficult situation. There are numerous clashes and conflicts that proliferate throughout this wide space: let us think of Libya, the still-open Arab-Israeli conflict, the question of Gaza, the situation in Syria and Iraq, or the new challenge posed by ISIS. We therefore need an important international and regional player such as Egypt to work with us to find solutions in all these challenges, including jihadist terrorism, unfortunately so topical these days. We need Egypt for the restoration of peace and stability that this whole region is calling for. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that Egypt is well known that among the indispensable hallmarks of the European Union are what we call the rule of law, pluralistic democracy, the division of powers and respect for human rights and individual freedoms, including equality and non-discrimination. For us, they are values that we consider universal and we would like them to be shared and enjoyed also by all Egyptians. The new Egyptian Constitution includes these rights but, unfortunately, as has already been said, there has not been the necessary legislative development for their implementation, while laws are also maintained that are not in line with that constitutional text. Parliament which will be born from next March's elections will therefore have a very important legislative task to carry out. I hope that these elections will run in a climate of dialogue and openness, and be as inclusive as possible. Egypt is a relevant partner of the Union. We must help him in his process of transition to democracy and also help the many Egyptian citizens who still face many problems.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! There is no doubt that developments in Egypt are of fundamental importance to Europe, and it does not matter what is going on in this populous and economically powerful Mediterranean country. Of course, stability and predictability are in the interests of all sides, and it is also to be appreciated that Egypt is trying to do so. Stability, however, must be geared towards sustainability. Unfortunately, the policy of the current As-Sisi government, which came to power through a military coup, is primarily based on short-term results. It means a more or less blunt continuation of the repressive policy that existed until the Arab Spring.  Civil society activities, whether they come from the secular sector or the circles of the Muslim Brotherhood, are suppressed by authoritarian means. The legal basis is a law of December 2013, which euphemistically calls itself the right to public gatherings, parades and peaceful demonstrations. In addition, there is the practice of putting civilians before military courts more and more frequently. All the measures that are put in place on this basis contribute to the spread of dissatisfaction and thus to achieve exactly the opposite of what one actually wants to achieve: stability is becoming increasingly faltering. Egypt should also be reminded that, in its referendum-adopted constitution, it has explicitly committed itself to complying with all international human rights conventions.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to draw your attention to a particular issue, the situation of copts, Egyptian Christians, who make up 10% of egypt's population and are the largest Christian minority in the Middle East. In the last few months, many Churches, Schools and Coptic Houses have been attacked in Cairo. Religious discrimination continues to be m.in. lack of access to senior positions in the administration, the military, blocking the construction of churches, but also marking Coptic shops with a black "x" to distinguish them from Muslim shops. Members of the clergy, as well as Coptic activists, unsuccessfully asked the Egyptian authorities to protect them.  Moreover, in September 2013, it was the security services who attacked the village of Jabal Al-Deir, ransacked it and the inhabitants were beaten. I would point out in this example that it was not the Muslim Brotherhood that was responsible for this attack, but the state officials. This is undoubtedly the result of the Islamisation of the country under Mursi, which has even led to a constitutional change and the establishment of an Islamic state in Egypt. Today, state officials, whose duty it is to protect all citizens, persecute them for religious beliefs other than Islam. It is time for the international community to stop turn a blind eye to the persecution of Christians in Europe and to speak out in favour of their rights. That is what I am calling on Commissioner Mogherini to do.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE). -
text: You have found the right words in the introduction, the right balance between the importance of the state of Egypt, also for us, also for regional peace, for stability, and, of course, between our expectations of such a country. We cannot give up the highest expectations when it comes to the realisation of the rule of law, human rights – individual and collective. However, when we write resolutions – and I would say that this document of ours is a little sharper than Egypt may deserve at the moment, and as we want – when we write such resolutions, we need to know that we need a country like Egypt in the Middle East. In the turbulent Middle East. And we must be able to appreciate the potential that such a country can mean in resolving stability, fighting terrorism and a whole host of other strategic interests of our continent and the world. I therefore think it is right that we expect, including in Egypt, that it will evolve in a democratic direction, that it will exercise its constitution and that it will hold democratic elections with an elected parliament.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, as we heard yesterday, the Egyptian Foreign Minister has said there is a possibility that the three al-Jazeera journalists could be pardoned. I would ask you to spare a thought for their cellmate, Irish teenager Ibrahim Halawa, who has been imprisoned without trial since August 2013. Ibrahim, at 17, was a child when first arrested following the protests in Cairo and has since been deemed a prisoner of conscience by Amnesty International and Reprieve. Denied urgent medical attention for a gunshot wound to his hand following the protest, he is now permanently disfigured. He has been badly beaten and subjected to solitary confinement in prison. His trial has been postponed three times and today he still faces a mass trial, along with 493 other prisoners with whom he has been jointly charged, despite a complete lack of evidence. I would like to take this opportunity to remind the High Representative of my requests to meet to discuss Ibrahim’s case and the urgent need for his immediate and unconditional release.

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, I think we are all agreed that Egypt is a vital strategic partner within the region. I think we are also agreed, as we say in this resolution, that Egypt has a considerable way to go in meeting our norms, and we have a duty to the Egyptian people to be frank about the shortcomings in their governance. We have a duty to the Egyptian people, who took such enthusiastic part in the Arab Spring and the revolution, not to dash their hopes and let them down. Ms Mogherini, I am very impressed by your comments, as ever, this evening. You have a common agenda with us and I hope that we are in a position to strengthen you in your dealings with the Egyptian authorities. I would echo the previous comments made about political prisoners, journalists, LGBT people, and particularly the NGO rule as NGOs in Egypt are now in a very dangerous position. I would also specifically raise with you paragraph 17, in which we call on Egypt to cooperate with all UN human rights external organisations and mechanisms, and paragraph 6, where we go one better and call on Egypt to ratify the Rome Statute and start the process towards accession to the International Criminal Court. Have you raised that point with them? What would be your attitude towards it? It strikes me as a worthwhile effort to encourage them in that direction.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI). -
text: Mr President, the threat posed by jihadist terrorist activity is complex and multidimensional. The groups carrying out terrorist attacks in major European cities are not only made up of residents of those cities. They have partners and like-minded people in Muslim countries in Europe's mainly southern neighbourhood. If we want to contain or eliminate this phenomenon, we must help the governments of these countries to get rid of the jihadists in their own country so that they cannot come to Europe. In order to achieve this, we must help them find the right balance between security and the protection of human rights. One of those countries for which jihadist terrorism is a threat is Egypt. There, the jihadists murder, carry out kidnappings and target Christian priests, especially the Greek Orthodox monks of the Monasteries of Mount Sinai. That is why the State faces this risk both by legislative means and by military means. Terrorism and the trafficking of individuals are classified as crimes in the country's constitution. Therefore, the European Union's cooperation with Egypt will help to tackle terrorism there and make us feel more secure in Europe.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, it is clear that the European Union must support Egypt's stability and also support and encourage further development of the country's democratisation process. These two spectrums are not contradictory, but complementary. Building effective, inclusive institutions, promoting good rule, respecting human rights, fighting corruption must be a priority in cooperation with Egypt, especially if we are looking at this from the spectrum of European development cooperation policy. Without progress in building the rule of law, an effective fight against terrorism and radicalism is impossible, which at the moment are indeed the main threat to Egypt's stability and development.  In the short term, the priority must be to ensure the stability of the country, as this is of strategic importance for the European Union, if we are to prevent the creation of a band of chaos in the southern Mediterranean, from Syria to Libya that would most directly threaten the security of our continent. But I also think that it is good, that it is necessary to warn about democratic deficits, about the shortcomings in Egypt and we will do this, among other things, by passing this resolution.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D). -
text: Mr President! Thank you very much to Federica Mogherini for clearly talking about the fundamental and great challenges we face in terms of human rights and democracy in Egypt. I myself have just returned from Egypt after talking to political parties, with the press, with NGOs, with the media and with think tanks, and the message from Cairo is quite clear: now the European Union must show that we take human rights, democracy struggle, freedom of expression and media freedom seriously. What we are seeing at the moment is that President al-Sisi's grip on civil society, on democracy, on human rights is so hard that people cannot be allowed to speak out, that people are thrown in prison, and you look to the rest of the world to see if we can help. We do not want a situation in Egypt where what was the Arab Spring against democracy, human rights and greater openness is in fact just a generational shift in military rule. Many people are afraid of that at the moment. Many say the situation is worse than under Mubarak. That is why I call for the European Union to clearly call for an amendment to Article 78 of the Penal Code so that human rights activists and political opponents do not, for example, risk life imprisonment for receiving foreign aid. This should not be possible. We must put an end to the situation in Egypt.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR). -
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, president al-Sisi's government is certainly far from being considered ideal. On the other hand, it is the government that prevented the chaos that prevented the economic disruption that prevented the collapse of the state. And it turns out that in the Arab Spring countries, in the Maghrebu and Mashreek countries, we actually have two options. One option is a firm-hand government, as President al-Sisi demonstrates, the other option is to combine parliamentary democracy with the prevailing ideological and religious direction in the country, that is, Islam as Tunisia or Morocco demonstrate, in fact, turkey itself is the best example of this. Of course, the second way is better than the first, but we as Europeans should get used to the fact that neither of these paths leads and will lead to the Western model of democracy to which we are accustomed, including respect for all human and civil rights. , Libya or Syria. And we should count on that, we should work pragmatically on this, and I believe that Mrs Mogherini, because she has dealt with this subject, will be able to do it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, in 2010 million Egyptians occupied Tahrir Square and the streets of all Egypt calling for social rights and freedoms. Four years later we witnessed a wave of repression in the country, with more than eight hundred killed in the Raba Square massacre and arrests of thousands of people, death sentences in mass macro-prosecutions, imprisonment and repression of opponents, trade unionists, journalists, students and activists, arrests and oppression based on gender or sexual orientation. We value President Al Sisi's calls for the moderation of magnets in his speech and also the positive attempt to stop the Israeli massacre against the Palestinian population. We urge Egypt to open the Rafah Pass so that we can alleviate the suffering of palestinians imprisoned in the open air in the Gaza Strip. But you cannot close your eyes to the human rights situation in the country by prioritizing strategic reasons. The Egyptian army is again receiving funding from the United States. The IMF resumes its contacts and the European Union seems more concerned with deepening free trade with the country. This has happened in the past. We mustn't repeat history. The future of Egypt must be in the hands of the Egyptian people, without interference. Nor can these interferences be from the European Union.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done on this In Egypt, human rights are currently being dramatically trampled underfoot. That is why we are adopting the resolution tomorrow. But that alone is not enough. The situation is such that the Muslim Brotherhood is trying with all its might to get back into government. They make armed demonstrations, murder and kidnap. More importantly, a large part of the Egyptian population is starving. And this is an opportunity for the Muslim Brotherhood, who provide minimal aid and therefore receive great support. That is why I urge you not to stick to this resolution, otherwise it will have no effect. We need to accept the reasons for the difficulties and increase aid to the government so that the economy can get back on track. That is why I urge you, High Representative, to see that the funds are being increased so that the economy can get back on track.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Madam High Representative, i would like to thank you for your excellent work A wave of arbitrary arrests, horrific cases of torture against supporters of former President Mursi and other dissidents are evidence of the deteriorating human rights situation in Egypt. There are also widespread reports of the disappearing of people detained by the police and military. Egypt's justice system has suffered major set-up over the past year, when several politically motivated verdicts were announced. A series of mass death sentences after grossly unfair trials against detainees accused of violence reveals flaws in the justice system. In many cases, defendants were not present at hearings, and lawyers were repeatedly prevented from presenting lines of defence and hearing witnesses.  The Egyptian justice system has shown with terrible consequences that it is unable to do justice. Despite repeated promises by the current and previous president to respect the rule of law, horrific human rights violations have continued on an unimaginable scale over the past year. At the same time, the security services were allowed to violate these rights with impunity.  At all levels, Egypt shows that it is failing in terms of human rights. That is why the European Union cannot accept their violation. Decisive action and reversal of this situation is crucial in this regard by launching an independent impartial investigation into all reports of human rights violations and sending a strong message that violations of these rights will not be tolerated.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D). -
text: Mr President, after the military takeover, violations of human rights have reached alarming proportions in Egypt. The current Government led by President Sisi has undermined the democratic journey of Egyptians and is making the issue of radicalism worse by the day. More oppressive Sisi-led government policies will result in more support for ISIS. A quarter of the Middle East lives in Egypt, so what happens there will affect the rest of the region. Unlawful killing, imprisonment, torture – targeting journalism in particular, as witness the case of the treatment of Al Jazeera’s three reporters, who need to be released immediately – and the stifling of civil society are now regular in Egypt. Those responsible for human rights abuses must be held accountable for their actions. The EU cannot turn a blind eye to what is happening. It must use all its available tools to stop this. We must stand in solidarity with the detainees and harassed civil society in Egypt. Only by building a truly pluralistic society that is respectful of the diversity of views can we ensure long-term stability and security in Egypt.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner, the situation in Egypt remains particularly worrying. As a result of the wave of rebels known as the Arab Spring, the Cairo government was overthrown after a wave of violence and bloodshed. The Arab Spring has become a long Islamist winter, and the threat of one of the largest Arab states being overrun and controlled by Islamists is still relevant. Muslim Brothers is an Islamist organization, one of the first of them in the new time.  They have close ties to other Islamist militant groups and are a major threat to peace and security in the region. During the Islamist insurgency in Egypt, hundreds of thousands of Christians, Copts and Orthodox were killed and expelled, and their towns, properties and homes were destroyed. They are still under threat and Christian shrines.  If they take control of power in Egypt, the Muslim Brothers will pose a serious military threat to Europe and the state of Israel and will become another unit of the Islamist attack on Europe and our civilization alongside Hamas, Islamic State, Boko Haram, al-Shabaab al-Mujahedin, the Council of Islamic Courts, Al Qaeda and others.  It is no coincidence that the cooperation between muslim brothers and President Erdogan's neo-Muslim and pro-Islamist regime in Turkey is not accidental.  Dear Commissioner, my question to you is: What is the committee doing to support today's government in Egypt and counter the Islamist threat of Muslim brothers?

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: After four years of illusions, with countless atrocities committed against the population, we have once again at the head of the most populous Arab nation those who, in practice, have never ceased to rule in Egypt. The Egyptian armed forces are in fact the most powerful institution in the country and the West knows this. It is no accident that the Egyptian regime was largely supported by the United States with an average annual subsidy of $1.8 billion that has lasted for decades. Only Israel and Colombia receive more. While the government goes shopping to supply its army, the people are hungry for bread and a place of democracy and social rights. Our call is for them to let those people decide their future and stop supporting local oligarchies in the light of the Geostrategic interests of the West.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, in January 2012 a popular revolution overthrew Mubarak. Egypt joined the Arab Spring, a spring that summer has not followed. Complex realities continue to be used to resist simple solutions.  Egyptian society was complex in Mubarak's time, complex in Morsi's time, and is complex in times to Al-Sisi. And in its complexity, Egypt was and is a friendly people of the European Union, because it has always been an element of moderation and balance that has tuned in and tunes to the Union's objectives and ambitions in the Middle East.  This does not mean that, in the face of certain measures taken that undermine human rights and freedoms, we should not raise our voices to let Egypt know that it must rectify and return to the path of democratic entrenchment and the rule of law. On the contrary, you have to be able to tell him with the frankness of friends, but also with the understanding and warmth of those who want the friend to remain friends — best friend, if possible. And there we have a neighborhood program to which we have to give all the meaning.  I understand and share Parliament's concern about the future of events in Egypt, just as I appreciate signs of improvement — and there we have the March election as an opportunity. I therefore confess to you that I have my doubts about the need for a third resolution of the European Parliament in less than a year on the situation in Egypt, especially at the moment.  Do we have to be energetic about Egypt? Do we have to do what is necessary to make Egypt a democracy of all its standards? Yes, of course, as in every place in the world. But it is essential to be able to do so without spoiling that great engine of moderation and balance that has been and must remain Egypt in the region.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all know that Egypt is a key country in the region, a country that has played and can play an important role. The proximity to the Islamic State's hotbed makes this country's position more sensitive and I believe that we must be aware of this and use the right balance in political positioning.  For this reason, I have no doubt that it is crucial that the process of democratic transition is brought to a successful conclusion in Egypt, because it is the best response that can be given to today's challenges, particularly those posed by terrorism, and not that of restricting freedom and rights, but on the contrary of consolidating democracy and rights. Ultimately, precisely because we consider Egypt important in the regional framework, we need an Egypt that takes on democratic principles as a constituent element of its future action.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE). -
text: Because of the importance that Egypt represents, it is natural that we follow your situation with concern. In this secular nation, some of the problems that led to the spring revolution of January 2011 still prevail.  In fact, the high youth unemployment, women's unemployment, rising poverty, high illiteracy, religious tensions and doubts and serious concerns expressed by the international community about the general state of democracy and the rule of law are still part of the reality of the most populous Arab country.  However, despite this scenario, we look with hope to the future of Egypt and the Egyptians. From the outset, we will soon have legislative elections, which always means opening new windows of opportunity, in a scenario of greater political stability. Then because there is an economic recovery that could cause GDP to grow by 3.5% in 2015.  The Egyptian authorities are now expected to have scrupulous respect for the universal principles to which they have been obliged and of course we expect from the European Union, through the High Representative, a close look at the electoral process and increased attention in the implementation of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: The Egyptian leadership has a choice to make: either to integrate the international community as the rule of law and to be a responsible actor in the Middle East and North Africa region or to maintain an oppressive state of its people, putting journalists, including al Jazeera, political and human rights activists, homosexuals in prison, while freeing the corrupt dictator Mubarak. Egypt may have today a constitution that speaks of human rights, minority rights, women's rights, but that Constitution is not being enforced. These elementary rights are being grossly and massively violated. Justice doesn't work independently.  In the Mediterranean, and beyond, we would very much need a strong, influential, credible Egypt. But that can't be done by strangling democracy. On the contrary, each Mubarak manufactures his Morsi and they will reappear sooner or later. The European choice is more for more. There's a reverse: it's less for less. We will all lose in the Mediterranean and beyond it if the greatness of the pharaohs, the Islamic enlightenment of Al-Azhar, the hope reborn in Tahrir Square has little left in Egypt today gagged by General Al-Sisi.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (PPE). -
text: Mr President, of course there is a huge democratic deficit in Egypt, a country that plays a leading role in the Mediterranean and in the Arab world and is a partner of the European Union. Today Egypt is fighting along with the West against terrorism and can be a stabilising factor in the region along with Cyprus, Israel and Greece. It is an important partner in security and development issues. Especially at a time when the European Union's political investment in Erdogan's dictatorial Turkey is collapsing.  Together, the countries of the Eastern Mediterranean can be a source of energy for the European Union. Therefore, the European Union's close cooperation with Egypt spoils the plans of islamist fanatics, especially through the strengthening of democratic institutions and religious freedoms, as our report suggests. Let us not forget that no one is perfect and even within the European Union we have democratic deficits. But Egypt needs the support and support of the European Union to develop its democracy and make it better. Stability in the country will contribute to improving democracy, strengthening human rights, fighting terrorism, stability in the region.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, as we have already heard this evening, Egypt’s High Court yesterday overturned the only remaining conviction against the former President Mubarak. Given that earlier charges for killing protestors have been scrapped as well, four years of hard sacrifices made by the Egyptian people seem to have been in vain, all the more so given that, under President Sisi, hundreds are sentenced to death in mass trials, activists are punished for peaceful protests and NGOs are facing stiff repression. In August 2013, around 1000 peaceful protestors were killed in events that were on a par with what happened in Tiananmen, but unlike Tiananmen the world does not know the names of those squares. This crackdown is only pushing greater numbers into the arms of the terrorist organisation so, if we fail to act, this will ultimately hurt Egyptians as well as EU citizens. I would like to ask the High Representative what her strategy is on this. Given also that western technology and equipment are enabling the authorities to repress citizens, a useful first step would be to consider whether there ought to be a ban on exports of such items to Egypt and similar countries.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE). -
text: Mr President, in the last year, in Egypt, more than 16 000 people have been arrested, including those who took to the streets to protest. Many were sentenced to death. We are witnessing increasingly frequent mass convictions, journalists are being arrested, as we all know, and the majority of the population lives in famine and has no medical treatment in case of need. It is unacceptable and we must be firm on Egypt! We only help the authorities in Egypt if they respect human rights, if they stop executions and death sentences, if they release political prisoners. If Egypt is an important partner for the European Union, as has been said today in plenary, then yes, Egypt means first and foremost the people, the people who are suffering and who are waiting for our help today.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, I thank everybody very much for the debate and also for your signs of appreciation of my being here in this plenary. I have to say at the ninth hour that I really think you need to review the working procedures of this plenary – not for me but for you.  For me it is not just a duty; I do not know what you are used to but for me it is normal to be in the room when there is a debate concerning my issues. It is also often very interesting and a pleasure to listen to the debate because I think this feeds into my work most usefully. Let me also say that I will be here tomorrow morning too so we will meet each other again, those of you who are here, and that means that when I said during my hearing that I will work with Parliament, I meant it, and I find it also normal.  So no need to compliment me on that. That is just my duty and that is just normal. But, I really encourage the Presidency to work on a more rational way of holding parliamentary work, for the sake of the parliamentary work itself. Having said that, I believe that the discussion on Egypt tonight – obviously this is the only one I have attended out of the three you have had over the last year – has been a good sign of the balance between two different things. On the one hand, there is the regional role that Egypt can play – and has played – when you talk about the Middle East crisis, and can play even more on many different issues that are also core issues for our regional and foreign policy. On the other hand, there is Egypt’s internal transition, which is something that we need to support and encourage – and encourage to move in a certain direction, the direction that you mentioned of full respect for their own commitment and their own Constitution. And it is a transition. I would not agree with those of you who said that the Arab Spring has turned into an Islamic winter. First of all, the Islamic winter would not exactly be the case in Egypt. We might discuss whether that were an Islamic autumn or a non-Islamic winter but when we apply these categories to Arab countries we are being a little bit ungenerous.  It took many decades, if not centuries, for Europeans to go through transitions, and our transitions were also painful, non-linear, contradictory, sometimes difficult, and history is like that. So it is difficult to imagine now what the outcome will be but I would not declare closed after just a few years a season that was encouraging and full of hope in the Arab world.
