And among the Arab Spring experiences we have certainly some – and I would say many – success stories, whether the institutional transitions that were positive ones, as in the case of Tunisia and others, or the rising up of civil society movements that are really of value for the countries and societies concerned. So I think we need to develop a more complex reading of the situation there. I shall not respond to all the questions that you have raised – partly because that would probably take another nine hours and that would definitely be too much – but I want to mention two things. The first concerns a specific case raised by a Member who has now left the room, but I still want to mention it because I discussed this case just the day before yesterday in Dublin with the Irish Foreign Minister, and that is the case of Ibrahim Halawa, an Irish citizen who is in detention in Egypt. We are following the case and I wanted to inform you that I am following it closely, not only with the services and the delegation there, but also with the Irish authorities, and we discussed it just the day before yesterday.  Secondly, to those of you who asked me if I have raised one or another issue with the Egyptian authorities, I want to inform you that I still have not had an official meeting with the Egyptian authorities in my first two months in post. I have had the opportunity to meet with the Egyptian President and the Foreign Minister in a different capacity on several occasions, but not yet in my current position. Obviously there are a number of things that we are passing as messages, through our services, but I also want to give you the news that, yes, I will be planning and looking for an early date for official meetings with the Egyptian authorities because, following the suggestions made by a large majority of you, we need to find this balance of encouragement and engagement with Egypt at a direct level and I will be more than ready to do so in the near future.

name: Presidente. -
text: The debate is closed. I would like to tell you that motions for resolutions tabled pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be notified at a later date. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 15 January, at 12.30 p.m. Before the next and last debate, I want to thank you for your work today, Vice-President Mogherini. This link with the Commission and the Council is crucial for the European Parliament. Thank you very much for your engagement. I believe that the demonstration you have given today does credit to you and to the institution you represent. Having worked for several years, including on those benches, I know how difficult it is, but also important for Parliament, to have attentive and responsible interlocutors. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Egypt is a country rightly proud of its historical and cultural traditions. It is dependent upon tourism for the growth of its economy. But recent events, and the erosion of civil liberties and human rights, have led to a decline in the tourist industry. Who is harmed by this? It is not the government, or those in power in Egypt, but the people of that country who lose much of their source of income. Death sentences issued to 188 defendants appear to have been handed down in many cases for non-lethal offences and without what we might consider a fair trial. I hope that Egyptian authorities will reconsider the direction in which their administration is travelling.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. On 6 January, Egyptian President Al Sissi attended Christmas Mass at St. Mark's Cathedral in Cairo in the presence of Coptic Patriarch Tawadros II. Seas dear colleagues, what a strong and unprecedented gesture! How far we've come! For it should be remembered that in 2011, New Year's Eve was bloodied by an attack on a church in Alexandria that left dozens of worshippers dead. This was followed by a violent persecution of the Copts organized, among other things, by the Muslim Brotherhood carried by an "Arab Spring" which had all the favours of the European Parliament. I would conclude with these words of President Al Sissi: "It is important that the world sees us as "Egyptians"; and you'll notice that I only say "Egyptians." It is not acceptable for someone to ask: are you an Egyptian of what religion?" This is a message of peace, of tolerance that deserves our unwavering support, especially since the Islamist terrorist attacks that hit my country.

name: Presidente. -
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for the Common Foreign and Security Policy on the case of the two Italian marò (2014/2512(RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking members for this debate, which is not only timely but necessary, and for their contributions to the debate. The European Union has followed the case of the two Italian navy riflemen, Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone, who have been in constant contact with the Italian government and indian authorities since their detention in India began in February 2012.  We note with satisfaction today the decision taken by the Indian Supreme Court to extend the sickness permit for Massimiliano Latorre, which rightly takes into account the humanitarian reasons and the serious state of health of the military man who has imposed serious and urgent medical treatment in Italy. We are counting on this decision to mark the beginning of a path to finally find a quick, definitive, fair and shared solution to the case of both Italian soldiers, Massimiliano, but also Salvatore.  At the same time, unfortunately, we must point out that up to now, despite numerous attempts, there has been no progress whatsoe worth of progress. Therefore, we understand and share the concerns expressed by many Members of the European Parliament about a dispute concerning two European citizens. This case has been dragging on for three years now, an unacceptable period of time during which the two Italian soldiers have been and are still unjustly subject to measures having been restrictive of personal freedom, in the absence of the wording of a charge. This situation of unlawful detention violates the fundamental human rights recognised and protected by numerous international conventions.  It is useful to recall how the two Italian marò were on board the oil tanker Enrica Lexie which crossed into international waters to take part in an official mission under international legislation on combating piracy and protecting national ships. Because of their commitment to the mission, Latorre and Girone enjoyed the functional immunity of a state body in the performance of its duties. This means, in accordance with the principles of general international law, that military personnel engaged in official missions are functionally immune from the exercise of the criminal and international jurisdiction of foreign states.  It is no coincidence that the European Union has systematically called on India to find a rapid and positive solution to the dispute, in full accordance with international law and the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, UNCLOS, according to the jurisdiction over incidents taking place in international waters, it is up to the authorities of the flag State of the vessel, in this case therefore Italian. Presidents Van Rompuy, Barroso and Schultz, as well as High Representative Ashton, have raised this issue with their Indian interlocutors on several occasions in the past, underlining the European Union's concerns. Personally, I am constantly following – as you will imagine – in my new function and with particular attention to this case, and I intend to use every opportunity to continue to raise it until we finally find a solution that is acceptable and definitive to all parties.  It is important to draw everyone's attention to the fact that cases such as this risk having important repercussions on the global fight against piracy, in which the European Union has been seriously committed for a long time and it is good that it continues to be so. The Indian Navy has often been the target of criminal acts off the coast of Somalia and many hostages have been freed as a result of Operation Atalanta. International cooperation has been essential to limit the threat of piracy and to respond to attacks. The European Union and India therefore share a common interest in protecting freedom of navigation, but the principles of cooperation and mutual trust must be respected.  More generally, we share strategic values and interests with India and we want to work together on the world stage, but it is good that everyone is fully aware of how much and how the unresolved dispute over two Italian naval officers can have an impact on relations between the European Union and India, which it puts to the test. The European Union intends to honour its commitment to full and concrete protection of the fundamental rights of its citizens, of every European citizen detained in every part of the world, by promoting the peaceful resolution of international disputes and respect for human rights and international law.  Finally, let me point out that in this matter, however, there are not only legal or political considerations; this is also – for some it is first and foremost – a humanly very painful affair, for the families of the two dead Indian fishermen, to whom we are close, for the two marò and their families who have lived for three long years in complete uncertainty. A situation that is increasingly untenable from every point of view but above all I have to say for the families of the two marò to whom goes my affectionate thought humanly having had the opportunity to be by their side for many months, not only from an institutional point of view but also from a human point of view. Therefore, as the European Union, we will continue not only to follow the case closely, but also, and above all, to press ly, in close contact with the Italian Government, for a rapid, positive, shared and definitive solution to the case.

name: Lara Comi
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President, three years have now passed and the fate of our marò is still uncertain, as you have mentioned. Today we learn that Latorre, who is in Italy for treatment, has received a three-month extension of leave – it is a step forward – while Girone – alas – still remains in India. You see dear Vice-President, I believe that we have these three months to bring our marò home for good, before Latorre is forced to return to India. He doesn't have to go back to India and Girone has to go back to Italy.  Italy has not been able in these three years to bring the two marò home, it has never officially asked Europe for help, Barroso, Ashton and Schultz have intervened, as you have mentioned, but there has never been a request. Prime Minister Renzi himself said yesterday that Italy does not come to Europe for help and instead, Vice-President, I ask, together with my colleagues, for Europe's help because our marò are both Italian and European.  First comes the defence of human rights and then business and economic interests in India. Let them return home as soon as possible and there is a fair and rapid process that takes place in Italy or with international arbitration. That is why, tomorrow, we are voting for the first time on a resolution which will enable you to facilitate the resolution of this matter with the support, for the first time, of the European Parliament. Dear Latorre, dear Girone, you are not alone, Europe is with you and we demonstrate it in words and also in deeds!

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for the things you have said, for your style and for your role. I think it would be useful to stress the meaning of this resolution, which deals with the case of the marò involved in this sad accident which unfortunately claimed two lives.  I mean, it is not and does not want to be a hostile resolution towards India and the Indian people to whom our feeling of friendship goes. Instead, it is a resolution which calls for a balanced solution to this affair, which has been dragging on for far too long. In the meantime, I too welcome the decision of the Indian Court, which granted Sergeant Latorre an extension of his stay in Italy for medical reasons.  We therefore want to work – and this is our objective – to resolve the problem by following certain guidelines that we consider reasonable in order to overcome the accumulated delays and the way in which the case has been handlinged so far. There is a need, in accordance with the rule of law, to work to open an international arbitration procedure that serves to decide on the conflict of jurisdiction and on which authority is entitled to judge the case, favoring the return to Italy of the two marò; We call, within the framework of our relations with India, for your office to be able to identify the actions necessary to achieve these objectives. We are convinced and hope that the European Parliament's decision tomorrow will be useful in this respect.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the trouble is that the resolution that is on the table is neither going to help the marines nor improve our relations with India. I respect the Indian legal system and have the deepest sympathy for the families of the fishermen that were killed, but as a former military officer I have sympathy for the plight of the marines. Military personnel often have to make life-or-death judgments in very difficult circumstances and sometimes they get it wrong. These marines were part of an on-board armed protection team to counter piracy. It is such teams that have been the decisive factor in the major reduction in piracy in the high-risk areas of the Arabian Sea and the Gulf of Aden. Of course I cannot make any judgments about the circumstances and legalities of this particular tragic incidence; nor can anyone else in this Chamber. This is not a court of law and we do not know the answers to a whole range of legal questions and technicalities. It is certainly most distressing that this case has lingered on for three years now. This is unacceptable and every diplomatic effort should be made to bring the case to a rapid and fair conclusion. I urge the High Representative particularly to use her good offices with the Italian Government, and also with the Indian Government, to help bring this about, and I would request our Indian friends that we settle this matter quickly now with the best possible outcome for all concerned.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. " Mr. President, February 15, 2012 was a truly unfortunate day. An unfortunate day for the families of the indian fishermen who died, but also an unhappy day for the suspected Italian Marines.  Regarding the events that took place on the high seas, today it is quite clear to everyone that neither the poor Indian fishermen were pirates nor did the suspects think there were fishermen on that small boat. The Italian Marines fought for Italy's interests, for the interests of the Italian economy, for Europe, and were convinced that they were doing something to protect and protect the vessel, that is, the ship they were on, and the property they were carrying. A process that takes so long, or rather a process that is not there, is something that we really have to say today that the negligeny that happened is the fact that there is no process and protocol.  We should definitely request the return of the Marines to Italy, the possibility for a court in Italy or an international court to deal with the case. I strongly believe that this is a good path, and what has been done so far by the Italian government and what our resolution does in relation to India and Indian citizens, is an approach by which we show our great solidarity with this great state.  Finally, I would like to warn you on behalf of the ALDE Club that we have another case of fourteen Estonian nationals and eight British nationals who are also in India under strange circumstances. I'm asking you to deal with them, too.

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, it has been three years since two Italian sailors have been awaiting legal proceedings after they killed two Indian fishermen. Three years! Three years without the slightest announcement of a trial.  This is contrary to the European view of human rights.  It is legitimate for the European Union to defend the case of these two European citizens. Its mission is clear and our resolution clearly affirms it. Our two Italian citizens must be repatriated to European soil and tried in Italy by their national courts. But all this shows something else.  The European Union, if it is to be credible, must act in a coherent manner with all its partners. Yes, India is a major player and a key trading partner, but that is where the European Union can weigh in. The free trade agreements concluded by the Union are conditional on our trading partners respecting some of our values. I therefore invite you, Madam High Representative, to remind you of this in your forth future exchanges with the Indian government. The lives of these Italian sailors must not be sacrificed on the altar of free trade.  Finally, Mrs Mogherini, this House is asking you to intervene without waiting for consultation by the Council, as is usually the case. And that is what is new about this European Parliament. This is brand new and we environmentalists will remember it and we hope that you will not forget it when we ask you to intervene on other international issues.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that Mr Mogherini has taken a strong and decisive position on this story of the marò, on this case that is difficult to judge, but surely the fact is that these are European citizens and that it is right that it should be dealt with as European and not Italian diplomacy, which has, moreover, proved to be unsuccessful in this matter.  We are talking here – as Van Orden said well before – not about being a judge or the lawyers or supporters of one side or the other, it is not the policy that has to judge whether the marò are guilty or not, it is a question of applying basic international conventions such as that on civil and political rights and it cannot be accepted in any way that European citizens are left in India without charge. , without a trial being started for three years, this is something that cannot be accepted under any rule of law and I believe that we are all aware of this.  I am sorry that we are holding this debate at this time and that there are few people present in the Chamber, but I am pleased to hear speeches such as mrs Delli's, who has shown herself to be on this issue with a European aspect, because these citizens, whether they were French, German or British, I do not think they would have been there for three years without certainty. I believe that Italy needs to feel europe's neighbour and united on this case.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is a great national issue and it weighs enormously on the responsibility of those who represented our country during the Italian Presidency: having failed to prioritise this issue, we are debating it now and we must pay tribute to those colleagues – especially those non-Italian colleagues – to the Italians, perhaps I would have asked the High Representative to stress that the two marò are innocent. , this is another kind of Dreyfus case. Because we do not know why, for example, radar tracks are not being declassed, which would show that there has been a huge traffic jam here. Who knows what's behind this?  It is a national question that shows how serious, how many serious consequences result from the loss of the sovereignty of the nation, and here there is also the offense to the dignity of the uniform, of the history of a great national navy such as the Italian navy. Someone must have the courage to make it clear that there are these responsibilities and these reflections, which must be done because sovereignty is an important thing. We have given it away, we have distributed it to a body which, until now, with all the goodwill and also the maternal tone of our High Representative, of whom I must acknowledge a personal commitment, has not concluded anything. That is the reality!  Then let us remember that one of the two brave maròs is being held hostage, as they clearly say, by the Indian authorities. But the hostages are taken by pirates or terrorists, not by states! And what does Europe say on this point? Europe has a very weak, very imprecise, very general voice, it does not serve a tube! I signed the resolution in a patriotic spirit, so as not to stay out, but it serves no reason, it takes much more! Mr Solana, take it in a different tone, because the total ineffectiveness of Europe's role is proving to be completely ineffective! This is the 8th of September of politics ... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I fully support, on behalf of the Estonian delegation, the initiative by my Italian colleagues to achieve a rapid and fair solution of two Italian ‘maròs’. I would also take the opportunity to present the urgent problem of 20 EU citizens – 14 Estonians and 6 British – detained by the Indian authorities for almost 16 months by now. These are also anti-piracy security guards of the Seaman Guard Ohio vessel arrested on charges of carrying weapons on board – legal weapons. In July last year, the Madurai High Court cleared them of all charges. Despite that, they are prevented from leaving India and have their documents and belongings returned pending an appeal by the Indian police. The health of several men had seriously deteriorated. Their families are deprived of any income. Given the fact that these crew members have not been involved in any criminal offences, the indefinite detention in India amounts to gross violation of their human rights. In fact, they have become victims of a huge and clumsy bureaucracy. Therefore, I appeal to you, as High Representative, to do your utmost to contribute to their quick and safe return home. The fundamental rights and security of EU citizens in third countries should be safeguarded also by the EU diplomatic representations.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I rise to express my disappointment about the way in which this matter has been addressed by this House. I have strong reservations about the resolution proposed. I agree that we need to speed up developments to ensure legal certainty for all sides involved, but my concern is that the failure to address Indian issues will do just the opposite. At the heart of this case is the fundamental question about how we treat our partners. While the EU has a duty to stand up for its citizens, it is hard to understand why the lives of two Indian fishermen should be valued lower than the liberty of two EU citizens. That is the message that could be construed from our actions, and I not think that we can drown out Indian calls for accountability. It is important that we remember that at the basis of this there is a legal dispute about jurisdiction, which needs to be addressed if we are to make headway. Yesterday’s decision of the Indian Supreme Court to allow Mr Latorre to extend his stay in Italy is an indication of India’s goodwill. I urge my fellow MEPs not to reject that open hand. I call on Ms Mogherini to avoid further escalation of this case, which is fundamentally a bilateral issue between Italy and India. That would only hurt all the parties involved, including the marines, and it could have far-reaching consequences for our foreign policy at a time when the EU is struggling to kick-start relations with Delhi.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Mogherini, the two Italian maròs, as we have mentioned, are two European citizens and have been illegally detained for too long in a country, accused of a horrendous crime without evidence, pending a trial or judgment that no one knows, if and when it will arrive. I am happy to see that we all agree on this issue and have spent more or less the same words.  I would like there to be no words left, and I wonder why nothing has been done in these three years and only now is Europe moving. Because you see, India is violating the right to a fair trial that is enshrined in the International Civil Rights Convention that it signed and the European Union is simply ridiculed for it. Because, ladies and gentlemen, all the speeches, all the commitments and all the conventions that we fill our mouths with in this Parliament are simply waste paper if we are not the first to ensure that they are respected.  Europe is also the world's leading trading power and is currently having a free trade treaty with India. We in the 5-star Movement, of whom I am the spokesman at the moment, are ready to call for a freeze on negotiations if our two countries are not guaranteed a fair trial and a return to Italy. Europe's citizens in difficulty have the right – whoever they are and wherever they are – to have a Europe that supports them and that does everything in their way to get them home, and we will take them home.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about the marò, let us show some people who are here because, given the time, we have already got off to a bad start, Mrs Mogherini. These are the two marò: you remember them, you see them, don't you? Do your relatives know them? We're here talking about the marò, after three years at 11:35 p.m. There are four cats in this room. Is that how we talk about marò? It's a disgrace! Europe must be ashamed of the way it treats this situation.  Tomorrow morning, however, we will be discussing kyrgyzstan's problems with the law against homosexual propaganda, which is very important unlike the marò. But what is Europe? Is it an ostrich that puts its head in the sand? It's a disgrace! Mrs Mogherini, have you been the Foreign Minister in Italy, what have you done for the marò? Now she's coming here, she's rightly done, as she's paid for that, all day in here. But for the marò, what concretely did he do? I'll tell you: zero! Like the report card! If I were a professor today I would give her zero because she has combined zero and because one marò is still in India and the other is only here in Italy (not here because we are in Strasbourg) because she has a heart problem. Italy has done zero. You and Renzi failed.

name: Presidente. -
text: For information, it is not for the High Representative to set parliament's agenda and work. Mr Buonanno, we have listened to you, because there is something about the work on the agenda, so it is parliament's business, I repeat, that it is not the responsibility of either the Commission or the Council to set the agenda and the agenda.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE). -
text: I am taking part in this debate because I supported the oral question to the Commission with the wish that the case of the Italian Marines Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girona, respecting legal and humane standards, be resolved as soon as possible. I take yesterday's decision by the Supreme Court of India as a positive sign in relation to a sick Marine in an otherwise complex and sensitive case. I would like to see action and atmosphere on both sides in the following, which would allow for the swift resolution of a case unresolved for many years in a bilateral context.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, like my colleagues, I speak as a Member of the European Parliament of two European citizens who see their fundamental human rights trampled underfoot in a third country. The two marò have long been held back in legal and human uncertainty – as you said – without those basic legal guarantees for every individual in the world. That is why we must force the traits, which are also at national level, there has been and will continue to be. That strength that can come from a European authority that can express more forcefully and more forcefully, along the most effective paths with the most appropriate measures, which we leave to its assessment. Very comforted by his words and the way he said them. I do not know if he is maternal, it is certainly the way of a very conscious and very humane politician.  We are aware of the complexity and sensitivity of the case, which is why we are not asking for the Moon, nor are we asking for acts of conflict with the institutions or with the people of a country which, because of the uncertainty of its judicial bodies, is holding these two European citizens. We are only asking, and it is little, but it is everything: clarity, certainty, just justice and full respect for human rights.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Dear High Representative, anyone arrested or detained on criminal charges must be brought before a judge as soon as possible and must be tried within a reasonable time or released. This is Article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which was also signed and ratified by India. No, ladies and gentlemen, three years is not a reasonable time to start a process, especially if there is a doubt that the delays are due to reasons quite different from legal ones. Especially if there is a risk of undue conditioning and pressure.  Respect for the rule of law is non-negotiable and we therefore believe that it is fairer for them to be tried in Italy, or at least for the determination of jurisdiction to be referred to an international arbitration. We do not express prejudice, but we call for a calm, regular and transparent judgment, and we are also humanly close to the families of Indian fishermen, other victims of this sad story.  The Union cannot fail to address this situation, because Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone are not just two soldiers of Italy, they are two European citizens and Article 47 of the Nice Charter cannot remain a dead letter. This resolution was a due act. Solidarity with our two marò and with the suffering of their families is a moral duty. Making the rights of European citizens prevail over commercial interests is a categorical imperative. It is for all Member States so for Europe, human rights do not trade for two rupees. Let us never forget that!

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that at least two aspects must be stressed: the first – and without wishing to raise polemics or provocations – in these three years has no group ever tabled any resolution in this Parliament. This is the first time that if one speaks, I believe that we must – without exploiting anything – give credit to those who have wished to raise the issue at the moment.  Just as I believe that we now have an historic opportunity, a central and fundamental opportunity, in the evolution of this dramatic situation, namely that this Parliament can feel united. I believe that the centrality of this aspect must prevail over every other issue, because in times of terror, in times of terrorism, in terms of fear of lack of security, I believe that we must look to these two men as men who worked in security, as men who activated a role exercise in a situation that was certainly delicate, which tended to defeat acts of piracy. , which was intended precisely to eliminate further criminal and criminal situations.  Therefore, there can be no comparison with ordinary criminals or any delinquents or with men to whom one must turn one's back or make comparisons between family pain or the pain of other families. I believe that this centrality must be emphasized, because this Parliament can talk about human rights, it can certainly talk about jurisdiction, it can certainly talk about centrality, about the need for sanctions in relation to the strength that the European Union can express, but even more so we cannot turn our backs on men who risk their lives for the safety, not only of their own country. , but for the security of the whole of Europe at a time when operations and roles of this level are being carried out.  I therefore believe that in this respect this Europe must move in the direction in which the various groups have today wished to represent their argument and motivation, but I also believe that, as I know President Mogherini, there will be the opportunity to make a strong, rigorous, effective change and finally achieve a result that is not equal, that is to say, to bring the marò back to Italy. , so that they can be judged in Italy.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D). -
text: Mr President, first I would like to thank the High Representative for this long day and for expressing the very strong feeling of solidarity and cooperation which we have witnessed throughout the whole of today. The case we are discussing now, almost up to midnight, is in some sense symbolic because it is not about some abstract matter, but about the fate of human beings – individuals and co-citizens – and is why we, two Estonians, have joined this effort, because it is not a national issue. It is an issue of human rights and of trust in the EU among people – among citizens and every individual – and we really want to emphasise that the EU has to safeguard the security and fundamental rights of every EU citizen, no matter which Member State they belong to and in which third country this kind of thing may happen. It is also important that we have high respect for the Indian nation. We hope that in relations between India and the EU this spirit of solidarity and human rights will also be respected. Regarding the separate case involving 14 Estonian marine mercenaries – and also six British – this has also been pending for more than a year. Your predecessor was informed about it, including by letter, and we see that the EU is not very effective in helping citizens in this situation. So we hope very much that, under your management, the European External Action Service will be much more effective in helping to solve cases of this kind. It is with this hope that we are here, we raise this issue and we support our Italian colleagues, and hope that our Italian and all our other colleagues from all the other countries of the EU will support the Estonian marine mercenaries. By the way it was again, in this case, because they were fighting piracy that they happened to be in that tragic situation, so that is another problem – how people who sacrifice their security for the security of other people are not protected in such circumstances. That is also an issue to be raised.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, for three years we in Italy have been experiencing with anguish the story of these two riflemen, Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone, among other things two fellow countrymen, two Apulians like me. No diplomatic or political solution has succeeded in having an outcome to this affair, in an endless political and diplomatic swing, and our frustration and that of all Italian and European citizens has grown over the years.  The continued referrals of india's Supreme Court have demonstrated the inefficiency of India's justice system, which is incapable of deciding. This unacceptable situation is a serious and serious violation of human rights. I am addressing this meeting, once again, as I have done in previous years, in this Very Parliament, to remind you that the two marò are not two terrorists, they are not two criminals: they are two European soldiers who have embarked to defend our freedom and trade, and that is why we must all react and make our voice heard.  Here I join the High Representative Federica Mogherini, and I congratulate her on the work she has done today, but above all on the commitment that I am sure she will put in place for this problem, which grieves us as Italians but as European citizens all. I would therefore like to express my special thanks to the High Representative, because a few weeks ago you reproached New Delhi for too many postponements to resolve this case, saying that this could affect EU and Indian relations. So for the first time since this 15 February 2012, a member of the EU government has made his voice heard by threatening retaliation. So, I ask myself: how much longer will we have to wait to see these trade sanctions implemented, when we can review our two riflemen at home, when this agony comes to an end? And I wanted to thank once again our foreign colleagues, our Estonian colleagues and all those who are taking part in this debate because they remind us that this is not an Italian battle, this is a battle to bring two citizens, two European soldiers, home to Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think there is little to add to what Lara Comi and other Members have said brilliantly. The affair of the two marò is truly paradoxical! It would be tragicomic if the lives and dignity of two Italian soldiers, arrested three years ago, were not at stake in the performance of their duties in international waters during an anti-piracy operation. They were certainly not there, engaged in a simulated softkey war. They were engaged in an operation that allowed Italian and European merchant ships not to be subjected to the constant onslaught of piracy.  India is behaving completely irresponsibly, trampling underfoot the most basic principles of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. Europe can no longer allow this and must bring the two marò back to Italy, suspending – as has been stated on several sides – the negotiations for the free trade agreement with India, where expressly provided that Europe cannot sign treaties or agreements with countries that do not respect human rights.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my voice will be out of the chorus: I believe that patriotic rhetoric has been built around the affair involving the two navy riflemen Latorre and Girone, which is not only not in my ropes but also, I believe, of little use in solvinging. This is, of course, a very complex issue and it is a sad case of the case and certainly not a question of human rights.  It is right - and I think it is almost incredible to say so - that Mr President, i.e. that we should not be able to do something about it. Borghezio: this is a huge national issue. It is certainly not about the European Union, it is certainly not about this Parliament and it is certainly not about the very hard work that the High Representative is doing, whom I too thank for the day he has spent with us, for the things he is doing. For all the crises and dossiers he is facing. This is a matter that must remain and must be resolved only at judicial and procedural level.

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too am very concerned about the right to a fair trial and the uncertainty in which the marò have been living for three years. I believe that the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, has really never shown that she underestimates the drama of this issue. That said, my voice will also be out of the chorus.  I agree with what Mrs Gill said: the life of the two Indian sailors is worth no less than the life and honour of the Italian riflemen. Even less do I believe that we parliamentarians can judge here whether the marò have acted well or badly and what their function was. For this reason, I have many doubts about the resolution, because the text does not clearly link the release of riflemen to the need for a process, international or national. We are simply talking about lengthy indian justice, and I am sorry about that.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for the commitment you have already made, I believe that it is very important politically to have an alliance, strong, for the first time, I would say, of the unity of Parliament and with the Commission on this painful matter.  Of course, we are relieved at the recent decision of the Indian Supreme Court to grant for health reasons to extend La Torre's stay in Italy by three months, but the persistence of such a condition in violation of international law, referred to by many colleagues, with continuous postponements of a solution, is truly unacceptable. We, as Italian citizens, welcomed the initiative which, with international arbitration, had already taken the then Foreign Minister Mogherini and which today, in her capacity as High Representative for Foreign Policy – together with the Commission and the Council I hope – gives her the strength to take all the initiatives to protect the two riflemen and certainly guarantee - I say this to Mrs Spinelli - international arbitration.  Protection means this: protecting the rights that we have in a certain process and also – I believe – threatening to suspend the European Union's trade negotiations with India and bearing in mind, as some Estonian colleagues have reminded us, this is also an important issue concerning the fight against piracy, which is an international issue and which I think should also have very strong pronouncements in the international agreements that are taking place.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. - (IT) Mr President, as you rightly pointed out, but I too would like to remind Mr De Clercq of this. Mr Bonanno, it is not my personal responsibility to organise the agenda and agenda of this House just as it is not my responsibility or ability to organise and guarantee the presence of Members of this House, including those of Mr Bonanno's group. Bonanno. However, I would like to thank the European Parliament for this debate, For this reason, and also for having shown that this issue is not just an Italian issue, but an issue that concerns several European citizens – some Estonian and British citizens have been mentioned – and it is generally a problem that concerns the protection of the human rights of European citizens, whatever their nationality, respect for the principles of international law, the protection of soldiers engaged in anti-piracy missions and therefore the very credibility of our anti-piracy actions.  It is therefore a matter for the European Union, and in this respect I am taking responsibility for it – although, of course, the decisions on the legal management of the case remain fully, and rightly so, in the hands of the Italian Government, with which I believe I must continue to link very closely. Just as I undertake this evening, although this is not the specific case of the resolution that you are going to vote on, to link closely with the Estonian Government and the British Government on similar cases and any other similar cases that may take place in other circumstances. I will therefore personally take initiatives which I hope will be useful not only in the solution of the case, but also in the prevention of other possible similar cases in the future.

name: Presidente. -
text: The debate is closed. I would like to tell you that motions for resolutions tabled pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be notified at a later date. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 15 January, at 12.30 p.m.
